PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Video Cassettes
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the undersigned, having great concern over the effect that increasing availability of pornographic material is having in hastening the spread of moral pollution in our nation, call upon the Federal Government to:

1. Dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's guidelines for classification of video tapes/discs, which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and especially mailing by Australia Post, so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video cassette, or film which exploits or degrades women as sex objects, or which obtain child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex or violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc. or which promotes homosexuality or lesbianism;
2. Resist moves to have Federal Funds granted to subsidise the production and export of X-rated videos; and
3. Implement the decision of all State Attorneys-General to have the distribution of X-rated videos from the Australian Capital Territory outlawed.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect our society, especially women and children, from moral pollution and its harmful effects.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Lithuania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the honourable members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Australians believe in freedom and democracy for all people.
2. The annexation of the Baltic states of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia to USSR is not recognised as lawful by Australia; these Baltic states were illegally occupied by USSR.
3. Lithuanians have suffered their own `Katyn massacres' after the infamous Stalin-Hitler pact of 1939.
4. Lithuania's restoration of independence of 11 March 1990, is a peaceful and democratic expression of the desires of the overwhelming majority of the peoples of Lithuania.

5. Australian Government should support the democratically elected Government of the Republic of Lithuania, headed by President V. Landsbergis. Australia should extend humanitarian aid to Lithuanian peoples and full recognition of the Lithuanian Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Air Landing Fee: New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed air landing fee for regional and commuter airlines landing at Sydney Mascot Airport during peak times discriminates severely against people in rural Australia and will force many airlines to either revise their schedules, cancel flights or increase passenger fares to cover this additional financial impost of the Federal Labor Government. This will result in less accessibility for country businessmen and travellers alike, will increase the costs of business for rural people and threatens the viability of many smaller airlines who provide valuable services to rural towns. We therefore call on the Federal Government to abolish all plans for the introduction of this discriminatory fee and allow commuter airlines to continue to provide their full range of services to towns throughout New South Wales.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Otway Forests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Leader and members of the Senate of Australia, the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that the Governor of Victoria has set aside 219 hectares of Reserved Forest in the Apollo Bay water catchment forest to be the West Barham Big Trees Flora Reserve.
We humbly pray that you consider protecting a larger area of the Otways from logging by listing it as National Estate forest so that botanical, water and tourist values may be preserved.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitions request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Disability Services Act
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate:

That the Employee Advisory Committee of Aware Industries Ltd., 22 Maloney Drive, Wodonga, Victoria, representing 111 disabled employees in three facilities which provide supported employment for people with disabilities in the Albury and Wodonga area, hereby petition the Senate, and in particular the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, because we object to the direction of the Disability Services Act (1986) in the area of supported employment options owing to the withdrawal of the business factory model as an option.

The Department states that no disabled person will be disadvantaged by the changes, but many of our employees and their families are fearful that their employment status after June 1992 will be jeopardised as we cannot see all our co-employees finding places in the new models, even if they could be developed by then, or in the future.

Your petitioners therefore ask that the Federal Parliament amend the Disability Services Act (1986) to include the business factory model as a choice of supported employment type. It is within the power of the Federal Government to amend the Act if sufficient support is demonstrated. We demand that our voice be heard.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Closure of Medicare Branch Office, Kings Meadows

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WATSON

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present to the Senate the following petition, from 1,736 petitioners, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form:

SPEECH.PARA: We, the undersigned, hereby register our protest at the proposed closure of the above mentioned office, which is likely to cause great inconvenience to many people particularly the elderly and infirm in the Southern suburbs of the City of Launceston.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) welcomes the visit to Australia by 6 Penan tribespeople from the Sarawak rainforests as the first leg of their world tour to draw attention to the plight of their people;

(b) supports the Penan tribespeople's plea for what remains of their rainforest heritage to be freed from the 24-hour logging operations which are causing rapid decimation of their habitat and culture;
(c) deplores the wanton destruction of a lifestyle which should be appreciated as a pure example of ecological sustainability;
(d) calls on the Australian Government to:
(i) ban the import of rainforest timbers,
(ii) encourage the use of alternative materials in the Australian building industry, and

(iii) give financial assistance to the Malaysian Government and other governments which are still logging their rainforests, in order to reduce the pressure for this exploitative but finite resource usage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes with total incredulity the Government's call for a white paper on science policy, when there are already six Government agencies dealing with scientific matters and the Government's scientific activities are spread over nine Departments;
(b) further notes that, since the Government came into power in 1983, there have been numerous reviews and inquiries conducted dealing with major issues relating to science and technology; and
(c) calls on the Government to create a portfolio of science and technology so that the Government's scientific activities can be properly co-ordinated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Papers are tabled in accordance with the list circulated to honourable senators. With the concurrence of the Senate I ask that the list be incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The list read as follows-
1. ADVANCE TO THE MINISTER FOR FINANCE-SEPTEMBER 1990.
2. SUPPORTING APPLICATIONS OF ISSUES FROM THE ADVANCE TO THE MINISTER FOR FINANCE-SEPTEMBER 1990.
3. ACT FORESTRY TRUST ACCOUNT- Annual Report 1988-89-including the Auditor-General's report-section 41(D) of the Audit Act 1901.
4. STATE AND NORTHERN TERRITORY LOCAL GOVERNMENT GRANTS COMMISSION RECOMMENDATIONS FOR 1990/91-section 13 of the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1986.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the fourth report of the Selection of Bills Committee. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the report be adopted.
I also seek leave to have the report incorporated in Hansard and to make a short statement.
Leave granted.
The report read as follows-
REPORT NO. 4 OF 1990

The Selection of Bills Committee reports that it has considered the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990 and the Social Welfare Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill 1990 and has resolved that there would be merit in referring these Bills to a committee for further consideration.
There are differing views within the committee about which committee would be most appropriate to examine the areas of particular concern contained in the legislation.

The committee recommends that the Social Welfare Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill 1990 and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990 should be referred to the Standing Committee on Community Affairs forthwith, that is, before the Bills are read a second time. The committee should present its report to the Senate by 15 October 1990.
The committee also recommends that the Senate (Quorum) Bill 1989 [1990] be not referred to a committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —My statement will be very brief. This report, the fourth from the Committee, is the first actual report in which the Committee registered disagreement about how we proceed in the referral of Bills to committee. At our Committee meeting last evening we determined that it would be better that debate around the disagreement should take place in the chamber rather than in the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, that is correct. There was disagreement among the Committee members on this matter. I wish to move the motion that has been circulated in my name, with the addition of the words at the end of paragraph (1), and that the balance of the Bill be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: In talking briefly to this matter- there are four separate issues within it and the Opposition in principle supports all of them. But we have significant reservations about the manner in which the apparent proposals would operate and for that reason we consider it desirable that each of the issues be further examined by the relevant committee. We propose that clauses 9, 10, 11, 24, 37 to 42 relating to the tax file number be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, and that the balance of the Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Community Affairs.

This would enable organisations such as the Australian Privacy Foundation, the Privacy Commission, the Australian Council of Civil Liberties and the New South Wales Council of Civil Liberties, the Australian Council of Social Service and the Welfare Rights Centre to address a range of issues such as the adequacy of the powers of the Privacy Commissioner to participate effectively in public debate so as to contribute to a better understanding of the implications of the proposal. It would enable the possibility and desirability of the extension of the tax file number system beyond the social security system to be discussed; the relationship of the tax file number system to proposals for parallel matching and enhanced computer matching facilities; the privacy implications of the provision of information transfer from the Department of Social Security database to other government agencies and departments; the extent to which the proposed extension of the tax file number system will contribute to savings to revenue; the basis for the Budget estimates and other ministerial pronouncements regarding the extent of revenue losses through fraud and overpayment; and the estimate of likely savings from the introduction of the proposed initiatives.

We propose, as I said, that clauses 9, 10, 11, 24, 37 to 42 go to the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee and the balance of the Bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. I refer to the motion moved by Senator McKiernan in relation to report No. 4 of the Selection of Bills Committee and move:
Omit all words after `That', substitute the following:

(1) Clauses 9, 10, 11, 24 and 37 to 42 of the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990, which relate to the proposed extension of the Tax File Number system, be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for inquiry and report by 6 November 1990, and that the remainder of the bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Community Affairs for inquiry and report by 6 November 1990.
(2) The Social Welfare Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill 1990 be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs for inquiry and report by 6 November 1990.
(3) The Senate (Quorum) Bill 1989 [1990] not be referred to a committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I put the amendment moved by Senator Reid, there does seem to be some confusion about it. We will have to have discussions about it, because it seems that Senator Reid has moved to refer the whole Bill to a committee and then also parts of it to another committee.

—No, Mr President, that is precisely what I did not do. I have moved to refer a portion of the Bill to one committee and the balance to another committee. There are four issues in it: one to go to one committee and three to go to another committee.
—I think we understand the intention.

—The Australian Democrats are extremely concerned about the implications of clauses 9, 10, 11, 24, 37 and 42 of the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) and believe, with the Opposition, that the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs is the appropriate committee to investigate those aspects of the legislation. Speaking as a former member of that Committee who has been involved in some of the ongoing work in that area, I particularly support that view. We are supporting this amendment by the Opposition because we believe particular scrutiny needs to be given with regard to the expertise of that Committee. We believe that the social welfare legislation also ought to go to the Standing Committee on Community Affairs. We therefore support the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —As we develop this new committee system, it is important to ensure that Government business still manages to get through the Senate, and we need to ensure, in doing that, that particular committees are not overloaded when it is unnecessary to do so and that other committees can continue with their work so that Government legislation can be passed to enable start-up dates to be met. When one looks at the legislation that is referred to in Senator Reid's amendment, one sees that we now have a portion of this legislation going to Senator Cooney's Committee. Senator Reid, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats are well aware that Senator Cooney's Committee is also dealing with the privacy legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: We are going to find it very difficult, given that, to have Senator Cooney's Committee deal with all of that legislation-with privacy plus now aspects of this other legislative package. The Department of Social Security has to get ready for some 1 January start-up dates. There is considerable gearing up to be done for that. By doing what we are doing here this morning, on the assumption that the Opposition and the Democrats stick together, we are going to make it very difficult for those start-up dates to be met. We make that difficulty occur while all still having the certain knowledge that, no matter which committee the legislation is referred to, all of the same witnesses can appear, all of the same questions can be asked, and exactly the same amount of scrutiny of the legislation will take place.

The Government is not about preventing that scrutiny, but it is about ensuring that the scrutiny can occur in a minimum period of time to enable the Senate to deal with the legislation, and then so enable those start-up dates to be met. Already one start-up date will not be met and will have to be altered. But to get legislation through the Senate in time for those start-up dates and to have all of that gearing up done by the Department that is necessary, we are now going to run a great risk. I still cannot understand why this course has been proposed because, if all the legislation is referred to the Committee of Senator Zakharov, all of the same questions will be asked and all of the same witnesses will be called. It is just that we will get it done more quickly.

I would hope that no-one in the Senate is simply about delaying tactics. I would hope that no-one here is seeking to delay for delay's sake. What we are all about is a quest for information. That search for information will be satisfied by sending all of the legislation to Senator Zakharov's Committee. The Government is determined to see that this new committee system is not used during the course of the next few months to frustrate the passage of Government legislation. Already we face serious problems. Already we now face an extra committee stage added to what we used to have, if the Opposition were to continue in the same vein that it did on the Maritime Museum Bill a few weeks ago. That is a matter of grave concern to us because, if that were to continue, there is no way that the Government's legislative program during this session can be met.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't keep your legislation up to us.

—So far as legislation is concerned, Senator Watson should look at the Notice Paper today. There is plenty of legislation here to keep this place going. But now when we get legislation coming in, we will be delaying it for weeks because of the decision the Opposition seeks to take.
—What rubbish!

—It is a fact. Senator Archer would not know a fact if it hit him in the mouth. But the difficulty that we face is that we are now going to refer extra material to a committee already overburdened with other legislation which all senators regard as very important. The Government simply believes that this delay cannot be justified. Every single question will be answered and every witness will be called. We simply ask that the process be speeded up by sending all of the legislation to the appropriate committee, and that is the committee of Senator Zakharov.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, that is one of the most astonishing presentations that I have heard in the nine years that I have been in this place. If there is a problem-and we are not sure as yet whether there is a problem-it is simply as a result of the mismanagement of the Government of its own business program. We knew at the end of the last parliamentary session that in all likelihood the credit provider provisions of the Privacy Amendment Bill would be referred to a committee. There were some of us who were of the view that the Bill should have been referred then so that in the months that this Parliament was up it could have been dealt with properly. That was not the Government's view, and so now only this week has it been referred to the appropriate committee for consideration and report. We have the totally unsatisfactory position that witnesses who are to be called before the Senate tomorrow still have not even been advised. As of last night, the relevant committee was still in the position of having to determine what witnesses it intended to call. How can the Senate be properly expected to conduct its business in a reasonably efficient way in those circumstances?

SPEECH.PARA: Then we get to the question of the second Bill, the tax file numbers Bill. I do not think Senator Richardson understands the legal consequences of these privacy matters. I do not know that he is even aware that already the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee has dealt with the tax file system as it was first put into the Parliament. There was a very lengthy inquiry that Senator Powell, Senator Alston and I all participated in. There has been an expertise built up not only among senators but also in the staff of the Committee. These are very important matters.

This Committee is logically and sensibly the Committee to which the Bill should be referred if we are to produce the best quality legislative result. That is our responsibility. It is not our responsibility for the Government to get its program in order; that is what it must do. That is what it grossly failed to do in relation to this parliamentary session. Senator Richardson is quite wrong: there is an enormous bulge of legislation building up for later in this session.

Yesterday, Mr President, you had to announce to the Senate that we could not get the Hansard printed because the Government was only introducing its legislation to the printers as of yesterday. It is a totally unsatisfactory situation. We have said that we will make this committee system work provided that we are able to make it work. That requires organisational competence on the part of the Government. We need to know what legislation is coming up. We need notice as to when it can be referred. We will provide senators on our committees to do the job properly. It has to go to the most appropriate committee, the committee that has the expertise, otherwise we are taking short cuts and we will end up with a poor quality result. That is not us meeting our responsibility. We intend to meet our responsibility.

We still do not even know which is the priority of the two Bills which will be before the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Which is the higher priority? Which Bill does the Government want the Committee to deal with first. Does the Government want us to deal first with the credit providers legislation, which has now been in this Parliament for about a year and has only reached this stage, or is Senator Richardson saying, because of the start-up dates, that the tax file number legislation is of the greater urgency? Is he asking the Senate to deal with that legislation first?

The Government has not even had the courtesy to tell us that. I suspect that it is not a question of courtesy, because the Government simply has not considered it. It has not worked out its priorities yet. So, before Senator Richardson tries to blame the Senate for the slow passage of legislation, it is important that the Government directs itself to its program and gets that in order, and then we will cooperate to ensure the orderly passage of the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment moved by Senator Reid may not be entirely in order. What Senator Reid has said in support of her amendment is logical. Clauses 9, 10, 11, 24, 37 and 42 contain provisions about which, as has been agreed, the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs has developed an expertise. It is very important, as the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) has said, to address these questions of privacy and to do so against the background of the expertise that has been developed amongst the honourable senators on that Committee and amongst the remaining honourable senators-and I think that includes the lot of us-who have kept an eye on this privacy area.

SPEECH.PARA: I see nothing too much wrong with the amendment to place some sections of the legislation before one committee and some before the other. I do not agree with Senator Richardson that all of the questions will be asked again in each committee. The sections being referred are different. However, I foresee one problem. If these committees are to meet concurrently, for example, if I have, as I do, an interest in this piece of legislation, it will be impossible for me to sit in on both committees at the one time. I defy anybody to suggest how I could do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —These things have to be planned well in advance.

—I acknowledge that point. But I raise the issue as to whether Senator Reid's amendment as it now stands is in order, because page 137 of the Senate Standing and Other Orders of the Senate, which details the orders of the Senate as at 5 December 1989, says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a standing committee, to be known as the Selection of Bills Committee, be appointed to consider all bills introduced into the Senate or received from the House of Representatives, except bills which contain no provisions other than provisions appropriating revenue or moneys, and to report-
(a) in respect of each such bill, whether the bill should be referred to a Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committee; and
(b) in respect of each bill recommended for referral to a standing committee:
. . . the standing committee to which the bill should be referred-
not the standing committees-plural-to which the Bill should be referred but the standing committee to which it should be referred-
. . . the stage in the consideration of the bill at which it should be referred to the standing committee, and
. . . the day which should be fixed for the standing committee to report on the bill.
The orders of the Senate do not suggest that a Bill should be referred to more than one standing committee. It is in the singular, not in the plural.

Senator Reid's original motion was probably prepared with that in mind but, as the motion now stands, I am not too sure and I seek guidance as to whether it is in order. If it is in order, I would prefer, frankly, to vote for Senator Reid's original motion as it was circulated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal with Senator Harradine's point first because I understand his concern. I think the Acts Interpretation Act is the starting point. That normally requires that the singular embraces the plural. It does that for the very simple reason that if we started saying `a committee' or `committees' in every situation, we would simply clutter up legislation. The classic example would be an omnibus Bill. Clearly there would be a desirable way of handling that, which would normally involve referring the legislation to the committees that might have direct relevance to certain parts. All that is contemplated here is that `a committee' allows us to refer it to a committee but, indeed, we can go further if necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: I will deal with the substance of Senator Richardson's comments. I find it extraordinary that jet lag still seems to be operating after four days and that he has the hide to come in here and to suggest that the chamber has plenty of work to deal with. We have already adjourned early on one occasion this week and frantic attempts have been made on a number of occasions to find enough work to keep us going. As Senator Newman has pointed out, three of the listed items under Government Business are committee reports. We are very short on legislation.

One of the most important points of all is that Senator Richardson is somehow endeavouring to say that the Government's program ought to take priority over the business of the Senate. That is contemptuous of the parliamentary process. He talks about a deadline having been set by the Government on legislation, 1 January being the operative date. We all know that Senator Richardson's Department is very busy gearing up in a whole range of areas in anticipation of legislation coming into effect. Why the Government chose 1 January is a matter for the Government. It is certainly not something that should cause us to shrink and to throw in the towel simply to accommodate that convenience.

It is very revealing because it shows that Senator Richardson could not care less about the real privacy implications or, indeed, about the other political or social implications of these provisions. All he is concerned about is some flash timetable that he has worked out behind the scenes and that he wants to see put in place, come what may. That is why his Department will go ahead and do things as though legislation were already in place. I cannot believe that the Department will do nothing until 1 January.

The most important thing is that on the one hand, Senator Richardson professes concern for privacy, wrings his hands and says that he will do nothing to set up central data banks and all the rest of it, but on the other hand, the minute that we want to refer very technical aspects of legislation to the obviously most appropriate committee, Senator Cooney's committee-the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs-he turns around and says, `No, it should go to the community services committee because otherwise we will have a whole series of duplications of questions and witnesses'.

That is preposterous nonsense. I do not know whether Senator Richardson means it seriously. By treating these matters discretely we are quarantining the tax file number legislation. We will have certain witnesses with expertise in that area-mainly civil liberties groups, such as the Australian Privacy Foundation, the Welfare Rights Centre and others, who may or may not have concerns in those other areas. One of those areas is the amnesty, and it has already expired.

It does not involve anything like the degree of rigorous legal scrutiny that the tax file number involves, particularly when we recall the sorts of downright lies that have clearly been told when we look back and see the promises and assurances that were given two years ago about the tax file number never being extended beyond the tax system. We now have Ministers quite blithely saying that it ought to be extended to the social security system and that this is what they propose to do.

We understand the logic of that extension but we cannot wear the hypocrisy of it. Therefore, it is terribly important to understand all those legal implications that may allow even further extensions down the track. I find this sort of hypocrisy and cant quite breathtaking. I hope that Senator Richardson will address himself to the seriousness of the issue and the way in which the committee system ought to operate. If we did not have the Senate Standing Committee on the Selection of Bills the Senate could still have chosen to refer it out, as it used to do, under the old system. That is not a matter of the Government's timetable any more than it ought to be now. It is a matter of the Senate getting it right and the community understanding what is going on.

Whether we are operating under the old system or the new system, we want to make sure that the Senate at least is fully appraised of the implications and not simply forced to rely on shoddy assurances of people like Senator Richardson.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to speak about a particular concern of mine in relation to the referral of the Social Welfare Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendments Bill to the standing committee on the issues of the Pharmaceutical Remunerations Benefits Tribunal (PRBT) and those sorts of issues, but I guess I have changed my mind because I see it as more important to discuss the amendment that Senator Reid has put. To have Senator Richardson stand here and accuse us or imply that we are going to hold up the legislation by this technique, is offensive. I find it offensive and I am sure my colleagues do. To argue that we will slow down the process by referring the Social Welfare Legislation Bill and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) to two committees is a nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that we are referring them to two committees will ensure that those two committees will speed up the process by having people who are knowledgable on those committees to deal with the issues, and to call witnesses who are knowledgeable. Senator Alston has already said and argued that, yet we have been accused of delaying the process. I believe this will facilitate the process; it will make the scrutiny of legislation much better; and it will mean that the committee process will work. I do not believe the Government wants this process to work because it does not want the tax file number and all the privacy issues to be put before the public.

TALK.START.PARA: —They do not want expert advice.

—It does not want anybody to know and it does not want expert advice because people might find out. I strongly support Senator Reid's amendment that we direct the legislation to two committees. I am glad that the Australian Democrats will support that amendment. I hope that this little argy-bargy we are now engaged in will not detract from what I think would be an appropriate scrutiny of legislation by those two committees when it goes to those two committees.

—I refer to the points raised by Senator Harradine. Senator Alston was correct, the singular includes the plural, as he indicated. But also the power of amendments are covered in paragraph (5) on page 138 of the Senate Standing Orders and Other Orders of the Senate. They are not limited. So the amendment is in order. I remind honourable senators that the time for this debate will expire at 10.37.

—I ask the Senate for a moment to get away from short term gain and look at what is happening this morning. There have been established rules of this game that have been adopted by all sides. What is happening this morning for short term gain is the throwing away of those rules. The precedent that has been established this morning is one that will damage this Senate and this institution of government. What is happening is nothing less than a total covert hijack of Government business. The Opposition knows it.
—Show us some Government business. Tell us what the list is for today. Are the tax Bills on the list? Tell us the list for today.
—Look. For God's sake, shut up.
—Order! Senator Bolkus.
—I have two major concerns. One is the precedent that has been established.
—Mr President, I have a point of order. Did you ask the Minister to withdraw?
—Order! A point of order. Senator Bolkus, I ask you to withdraw.

—I withdraw, Mr President. The second thing I am concerned about is that we have, and have had for 18 months in this place, privacy legislation, something that those on the other side have opposed, and something that demonstrates quite explicitly their hypocrisy on this issue. It is something that will once again be frustrated because of this short term mechanism. I ask Senator Alston to remember that one day further down the track-it might be five, six, seven or eight years-if this committee system is in place then legislation that any government wants to get through this Parliament will be frustrated endlessly. What honourable senators opposite have lost sight of this morning is that that will happen because of their short term political interests at the moment. So be it. We have had this system in the past and have had problems with the committee system in the past. This Senate will become unworkable because of the Opposition's short term interests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-We have great concern on this side of the chamber about what is happening at the moment and with the procedures of this new committee system. The Government is determined to make the system work, as has been proved with hours and hours of discussion that have gone across parties. We have done it. In only recent times we came out with an agreed procedure which has now been circulated within the parties for discussion. There are four elements in that package of how the Bills could be referred. We find today that we are now getting a fifth element injected into it. Within that fifth element we are splitting up the Bills on the grounds of expertise, so the argument goes. But there are financial implications in this Bill. Could the argument not be used that sections of the Bill be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration? There may be employment aspects of the Bill. Could elements of the Bill not be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training? Could the Bill not be split into eight separate parts and sent off to eight separate committees? We are concerned about the way in which this procedure is working.

SPEECH.PARA: The experiences we have had to date do not indicate to the Government that this new system is speeding up the passage of legislation. I have one final comment concerning the fear and trepidation that we have: Will we be into two further committee debates in the Committee of the Whole after the two separate committees report on this matter?

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1990SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Bolkus) agreed to:
That these Bills may proceed without formalities, may be taken together and be now read a first time.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That these Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1990
In his Budget speech the Treasurer announced a number of changes to the wholesale sales tax system.
This Bill, and one other I will introduce shortly, will amend the sales tax law to give effect to two of those changes which apply from 7.30 pm, 21 August 1990.

Given the comments made by the Treasurer in his Budget Speech, the details contained in Statement No. 4 of Budget Paper No. 1 and the explanatory memorandum being circulated to the honourable senators, I will do no more than outline briefly the changes proposed.
First, the Bill will amend the Sales Tax Acts (Nos. 1-9) to provide for a more effective imposition of sales tax on luxury motor vehicles.

Under existing arrangements, once the wholesale value of a vehicles exceeds $30,233, the rate of sales tax applying to the entire wholesale value increases from 20 per cent to 50 per cent. This results in a sudden increase in retail prices beyond that wholesale point.

This situation has encouraged wholesalers to adopt a number of undesirable practices to artificially reduce wholesale prices below the threshold level, in some cases by removing safety options from vehicles.

To reduce these distortions, the Government has decided to introduce a marginal rate structure for such vehicles. Under the new arrangements, a rate of 30 per cent will apply to the wholesale value up to the threshold, and a rate of 75 per cent will apply to the amount in excess of that value.

At a wholesale value of $54,419, an average rate of tax of 50 per cent will apply. Vehicles with a wholesale value in excess of this value will be subject to a flat rate of tax of 50 per cent, as per current arrangements.

The effect of this measure will be to provide a progressively increasing average rate of tax for vehicles in the wholesale value range of $30,234 to $54,418. This will remove the present discontinuity in the retail price of vehicles with a wholesale value just in excess of $30,233.

This measure will also benefit those primary producers and others living in remote parts of Australia who use four-wheel drive vehicles that have a wholesale value in excess of the luxury car threshold.

Secondly, the Bill will amend the Sales Tax Assessment Acts (Nos 1-3, 6 &7) to ensure that otherwise taxable printed matter is not exempt from sales tax simply because it is inserted into an exempt publication, such as a newspaper or magazine, for delivery to the final consumer.
By these amendments printed matter inserts will be treated as goods separate from the exempt publication for sales tax purposes.

The inserts will be subject to tax, unless they are specifically exempt, at the time of their final wholesale sale or deemed sale on a sale value equal to the sale value specified under the existing sales tax law for goods applied.
This proposal will ensure that all printed promotional material is subject to sales tax irrespective of who prints it or how it is delivered to the final consumer.
I present the explanatory memorandum and commend the Bill to the Senate.
SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1990

This Bill will amend the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act with effect from 7.30 p.m. 21 August 1990 to ensure, in conjunction with amendments made by the Bill I have just introduced, that printed matter inserted into an exempt publication is only exempt from sales tax if, as goods separate from the exempt publication, it is specifically covered by an exemption item in the First Schedule to the Exemptions and Classifications Act.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.PARA: Does the Government recognise that this is an impossible situation in which to put honourable senators? Why could the Estimates Committee not have met last night so it could have continued with its considerations, or why can it not meet, say, next Wednesday night or at another time that is convenient to honourable senators, rather than in effect take from honourable senators their legislative responsibilities as the Government, through its rather incompetent planning, is pressing with this program? —by leave-Mr President, I ask you when this subject will come up for debate in the chamber. It is terribly important that it be before lunch time. We need it to be able to set the time that the standing committee meets tomorrow. I understand that as a consequence it has already been put back.

—It is not a matter within my power to determine, but I assume the Government has taken note of Senator Hill's comments and that some time today Senator Richardson will make a statement on the matters raised by Senator Hill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 10 October.
The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Committee's consideration of the Customs (Detention and Search) Bill was suspended last night the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins), who was at the table, was just about to respond to a point I had made about the numerous references in the Bill to `as soon as practicable'. I had explained that I had read the letter by Mr McInnis to the shadow Minister and how that dealt with the final part of the Bill for an internal body search. The Committee had been in the process of getting an explanation from the Minister at the table as to what would be a reasonable time for someone in the earlier subdivisions A and B where there is either a frisk search or an external search to be carried out. As I understood it, although I may be wrong-I have not yet seen the Hansard-the Minister rejected the suggestion that an interpretation of forthwith would be a reasonable interpretation. Therefore, on those grounds I would be interested to know the Government's latest position on interpreting what `as soon as practicable' means for a passenger coming through.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that on 17 August this year the Australian Customs Service did contact Mr Prosser, the shadow Minister for small business, housing and Customs. I am further informed that in its correspondence to him this point was canvassed. It is probably best for me to read out the relevant two paragraphs of that correspondence which does canvass advice from the Attorney-General's Department. The letter goes:

SPEECH.PARA: As indicated at the meetings, the original draft Bill proposed an initial detention period for the internal search regime of a maximum of 4 hours within which a person must be taken before a magistrate or judge, and failure to do so would result in a reference of the matter to the Commonwealth Ombudsman.
Then there is a sentence referring to the relevant provisions. The letter continues:
This was subsequently changed on the basis of advice from the Attorney General's Department. The relevant part of the advice states:

`The provisions which require a report to the Ombudsman where delay in seeking orders occurs (sub-clauses 219p (3) and 219r (9)) afford the detainee no real protection. The legislation which requires applications to be made without delay or, preferably the more usual formulation of as soon as practicable, will, where this requirement is not complied with, have potential affects on the admissibility of any evidence subsequently obtained under the principles laid down in Bunning v Cross.'
The letter goes on to say:

Further, there is clear Judicial authority to show that the proposed formula would not allow any undue delay in extending the detention before making application before a magistrate or judge. In the High Court case of Williams v The Queen (1986) 161 CLR 278, the Court had to construe section 34A(1) of the Justices Act 1959 (Tas) which stated:

``Where a person has been taken into custody for an offence, he shall, unless he has been released under section 34, be brought before a justice as soon as is practicable after he has been taken into custody.'

In essence therefore we are talking about the application of common law rules and principles which would ensure that the particular person involved would in the circumstances of the case be brought before a justice as soon as practicable. We are talking about a flexible provision which will allow judicial interpretation depending on the circumstances of the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have the original copy of the letter. I understand that the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) is in difficulty coming here not having knowledge of what transpired last night. A careful reading of the Hansard, when it appears, will show that this is not the point in dispute. What Mr McInnis is saying in his letter relates to an application to a magistrate or judge. That applies only in subdivision C. The third case is where a person is going to be detained or subjected to an internal search.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no difficulty with that and I accept all the common law arguments and the rest of it. But the point I made yesterday was that we are dealing with five million or seven million passengers a year coming through Australia. I am not interested in what someone's legal rights are to sue the Australian Customs Service afterwards for undue delay. I accept that recourse is there, but that is after the act. I am interested in getting some idea of the most likely cases, the numerical majority, which is the frisk search and the external search. How long does the Australian Customs Service or the Government see is a reasonable period, in hours, for which an external search or a pat-down can be made? That is the simple question I am asking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is that, hopefully, judicial authorities-and I think they do-interpret the same words with the same meaning. Senator MacGibbon is right in saying that the context in which the advice is given is in a different set of circumstances. What, however, is consistent is that in proposed sections 219m, frisk search, and 219q (2), detention for external search, the term used is `as soon as practicable'. That is the precise term that is canvassed in the correspondence from Mr McInnis and it is contended-I think quite confidently contended-that judicial authorities would interpret that phrase in the same way in these particular provisions as they have in other cases. That is the basic principle of the law. I refer also in this context to another paragraph of the letter:

SPEECH.PARA: The decisions of the other judges support these views, and the authorities and precedents referred to illustrate that the formula of `as soon as practicable' is to be interpreted consistently with the common law, which places an onerous duty on the detaining authority to not extend the time-
in this case-
before which the detainee is taken before a judicial officer . . .
or, in the cases which Senator MacGibbon refers to, before a frisk search or external search.

TALK.START.PARA: —If 2,000 passengers were at Sydney Airport at eight o'clock in the morning waiting to get through the barrier and a Customs officer decided to proceed, on the correct grounds, to carry out a frisk search would it be a reasonable assumption that that Customs officer would then proceed to carry out that frisk search straight away or would he ask the passengers to wait for an hour or two hours or three hours before the frisk search was carried out? That is the nub of the question.

—I am informed that where we talk about frisk searches, the expectation, given the interpretation of the law that we talk to, is that the frisk would be made almost immediately. What I ask Senator MacGibbon and the Committee to recognise is that we are talking about a whole range of different circumstances that will be covered by this particular law, and that is why laws are written in this way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that. I appreciate that the circumstances would be very different in Darwin from what they would be at Sydney International Airport. As long as the general intention is that the search is carried out more or less straight away, I am quite happy to accept the assurance of the Minister on that.

SPEECH.PARA: When a frisk search, an external search or an internal search is carried out the Act defines that it shall be done by a person of the same sex. I am interested to know whether there is any intention to have two Customs officers present at the time the examination is made. An external search is a simple case but when a detainee is taken to a private area and required to remove his or her clothing in front of a Customs officer of the same sex is there any requirement that there be two officers present so that in the event of any dispute as to what actually occurred, there is corroboration?

TALK.START.PARA: —The law in this case is that the officer has to be of the same sex but I am informed that it is also the practice that the officer will be in the presence of a superior officer who will also be of the same sex.

—I thank the Minister. That satisfies that concern. I would like to move to the subdivision which deals with medical practitioners. One of the requirements here is that consent be obtained in writing from the detainee, if possible, for the search to be carried out. I would like the Minister to explain whether this would be in the form of just a simple written consent for examination or whether it would be written informed consent?
—I am further informed that the practice as administered at the moment is that written consent is in order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why has the Government not conformed to what I understand is accepted medical practice in requiring written informed consent from the detainee rather than the written consent standard, given the great differences that exist legally between those two states?

SPEECH.PARA: If the Minister is not familiar with the practice, in simple words I would say that in the case of written consent all that is required is that the examining officer says to the detainee, `Do I have your approval to conduct an examination?'. In the case of written informed consent the medical practitioner has to inform the patient in some detail-and the detail depends on the circumstances-as to what is proposed to be done and, in so far as is practicable and foreseeable, to outline the consequences and any complications that may take place in that examination. It is generally accepted in medical circles that a simple written consent form is of limited or no value because the patient can then come back and say to the medical practitioner, `I simply was not informed that that was a consequence of what you proposed to do'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure Senator MacGibbon understands the context in which I am replying to him this morning. The distinction the Senator is drawing is between informed consent and the consent that is provided for in the Bill. The advice I am receiving is that throughout the Bill there is consistent provision for legal representation when an internal search is required. I am also advised that provisions also apply in the Bill for a person to be a protected person and to have someone look after that person's interests. I do not know whether those two provisions satisfy the concern that Senator MacGibbon raises. Judging by the way he is shaking his head, they do not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, that is a different issue. My simple point-and I will restate it-is that if a medical practitioner asks a patient for his or her approval to carry out a procedure and he or she agrees to that in writing, all that person has done is agree that the procedure be carried out. In the case of informed consent a practitioner is required to take the time to explain in adequate detail to the patient what he proposes to do and also explain any of the sequelae or consequences that might result. In other words, the patient is informed whereas in the other case, it is a blank cheque; the patient says, `Right, you can do it'.

SPEECH.PARA: In the former case, under our legal practices the practitioner is open to a charge that the patient agreed to something the full consequences of which he or she did not understand. In this case this is important because there is obviously a degree of coercion in the situation. The passenger who is suspected of concealing drugs internally denies, in effect, that he or she has them, otherwise a declaration would have been made; when the Customs officer at the barrier had asked, `Do you have anything to declare?', the passenger would have said no. The Customs officer would then have said, `We wish to proceed through the various stages of these search procedures'. Implicit in this is the passenger's lack of cooperation with the authorities.

In those circumstances, it becomes very much more important that the detainee be informed as to what will happen when a search or an examination takes place, in so far as it can be explained beforehand, and what the sequelae might be. For example, if the examination ruptures the packaging containing internally secreted narcotics, that can and does lead to instant or rapid death in certain circumstances. If patients are not cooperating, it becomes important that they be advised of the procedure.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the advice I have covers Senator MacGibbon's point. The advice is that the tests that Senator MacGibbon talks about will be conducted, of course, by medical practitioners. The practice is and will be that they act in accordance with the practices Senator MacGibbon has mentioned. What Senator MacGibbon is talking about will not happen.

—I do not follow that. I do not think there is a parallel with normal medical practice. If there is a parallel with normal medical practice, then the parallel is for written, informed consent; not for written consent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator MacGibbon elaborated on the situation in which medical practitioners conduct these sorts of tests. We expect that that procedure will continue. In that context, I refer Senator MacGibbon to clause 219v (11), which also gives judicial override in circumstances where a medical practitioner is not satisfied as to informed consent. In essence, the prerequisites that Senator MacGibbon wants to apply in these circumstances are those that we expect will apply.

SPEECH.PARA: Further, this matter was also raised by Senator Coulter, I think, during the second reading debate. A response was given to him in these terms: the question of a medical search on a non-consenting detainee in fact received quite a deal of attention in the drafting of the internal body search provisions. The Australian Medical Association, AMA, made the point, in discussion on the Bill in 1986-87, that doctors would not perform any examination of a person without that person's consent. This applied irrespective of whether the doctor was employed or performing professional services for an agency such as Customs or the police forces or was engaged in a more common doctor-patient relationship and irrespective of the fact that the order for the medical search of the detainee was in existence.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is meant by an internal search?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In about an hour's time we will all be presumed to know that because it appears in the Bill. I am informed that there is a definition of `internal search' on page 3 of the Bill. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: `Internal search', in relation to a person, means an examination (including an internal examination) of the person's body to determine whether the person is internally concealing a substance or thing, and includes the recovery of any substance or thing suspected on reasonable grounds to be so concealed;

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the limit? Does that include colonoscopy, sigmoidoscopy, gastroscopy and x-ray examination of the patient? I want a clear definition of the extent of what `internal search' means. Does it mean vaginal examination, rectal examination or oral examination? It is too imprecise. Further clauses in the Bill show that any apparatus may be used.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 219zf (1) answers Senator Herron's question in legal terms. I do not need to quote it. Basically, we are talking about internal searches using any medical procedure or apparatus that the medical practitioner considers to be reasonably safe in the circumstances. Clause 219zf (2) states:

SPEECH.PARA: The medical practitioner must not use any medical procedure involving surgical incision unless he or she considers it necessary to do so because the detainee's life is at risk.
I refer Senator Herron to the other provisions of that part of the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —That does not answer my question. I do not think that the Minister understands what an internal search means. It needs to be defined; there needs to be a limit. That is the point I am trying to question: just what is the limit of `internal search'? It is not clearly defined. I understand that that is the legal aspect. It mentions apparatuses that may be used without defining them. I have mentioned those other procedures. If the Government intends to proceed along these lines, we need to know the limit. The limit is surgical incision to save the person's life should rupture occur. But prior to that occurring, we need to know how far the internal examination proceeds.

—We seem to have a conflict between lawyers and medical practitioners in this part of the debate. The law is written, as laws are, in a general sense. To be fair, Senator Herron should acknowledge that I did answer his specific question by referring him to clause 219zf, in which the law provides for the use of apparatus and so on. I think that it would be understood by most people that for a number of reasons one cannot specify the actual apparatus to be used. Here, we have left it to the judgment of the medical practitioner. That is pretty standard provision in any piece of legislation.
—I see the conflict and I thank the Minister. He is answering me in legal terms and I am asking a question in medical terms.
—Don't bulk bill me.
—I have never bulk billed anybody in my life.
—That would be right.
—And I won't start with the Minister; but can I get an answer?

—We could stay on this particular issue for a while. In essence, the answer is that the provision is in the legislation. Of course, there is the capacity for judicial override. In all circumstances, not just in this particular Bill but in any legislation going through any Parliament, there are problems in terms of immediacy. I can only say that the provisions of clause 219zf go as far as any legislators can go in defining the sorts of internal searches and apparatuses. Of course, the definition of `internal search' in clause 4 goes as far as any legislator can go in being definite in the circumstances.
—My interpretation is that there is no limit, in medical terms; that the examining practitioner can go as far as he or she likes in detection--
—In as far as they like.
—Thank you, Senator Baume-in as far as he or she likes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The protection within the Bill is in the best mechanism possible. I am sure that Senator Herron would acknowledge that. The provision basically ensures that the medical practitioner considers the approach to be reasonably safe in the circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: Many matters are left to the judgment of the medical practitioner, but there is a test that the practitioner must consider the procedure to be reasonably safe in the circumstances. We feel that this is the best protection to afford the persons who are being inspected. Of course, a further protection is provided for in the proposed legislation: the provision for judicial assessment of the medical practitioner's decision. I think that those two mechanisms together provide both a medical and a judicial protective structure to individuals who might be going through this process.

I think to go further than that and to try to limit in any more definite way the use of apparatus or to try to define the circumstances and to proscribe some and prescribe others would be quite impossible. We have provided these two structures in a protective regime which relies on the medical practitioner's judgment and also affords greater protection by the provision of judicial overview.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to move to the selection of medical practitioners. In the Customs (Detention and Search) Bill there is a requirement, inter alia, which provides that, if a medical practitioner conducting an examination gets into difficulties or is faced with a situation which he feels is beyond his competence, he can seek--
—Which clause is this?
—Clause 219ZF(3).

—Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman. Why does the Bill not provide for a selected list of medical practitioners who are prepared to carry out these examinations and who have the experience and competence to conduct them safely? We should bear in mind the fact that the principal demand will be in the large capital cities of Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane as the principal gateway ports to Australia. In outlying entry ports it might be a difficult matter to find suitably qualified medical practitioners, but statistically the incidence of cases there would be so low as to be negligible.

—I am informed-and I agree with this-that the sort of proposal that Senator MacGibbon puts up is one that would be extremely difficult to prescribe in regulation or legislation, if he is talking about lists of medical practitioners who would be called upon. I am advised that it is the practice to have a defined group or a general group. It should be acknowledged that it is reasonable to expect some flexibility in this area. We might instance the cases of Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane as major incoming ports, but there are places such as Cairns and Townsville, which Senator MacGibbon would know about, and other places-even Hobart. It should be acknowledged that, even though there is a practice of relying on a general well of practitioners, to be more prescriptive would impose difficulties. I think it is also fair to acknowledge that we do expect a person with a medical degree to have a certain amount of competence. I do not know whether this is disputed by the Chair, but we, as legislators, have to take cognisance of that and, accordingly, we have that further protection to fall back on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite astonished at that answer. Just dealing with the last point-the assumption that anyone with a medical degree would be qualified to carry out an internal body search-the fact is that such a person has to cope with the emergency consequences. What will happen if a condom ruptures internally? It requires a knowledge of pharmacology, the appropriate resuscitation procedures, and much else. It is quite reasonable to expect that that would be beyond the knowledge of an ordinary general practitioner.

SPEECH.PARA: I come back to the first point, that of preparing a list. Given the numbers of medical practitioners now in places such as Sydney, Brisbane and Melbourne, where there is a pool of suitably qualified people available, I see no difficulty at all in calling for practitioners who have the ability to put their name forward so that they can be appointed on a consultant basis when the need arises. Quite clearly, these medical officers are not going to be employees of the Australian Customs Service or the Department of Community Services and Health, or engaged in any other Commonwealth full time employment. They will certainly be on an `as required' basis and, if it is on an `as required' basis, they will be there on a consultant basis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did presume a certain degree of knowledge of the provisions of the rest of the Bill and, to that extent, the provisions that provide that internal searches be conducted on judicial order. I also made mention of the fact that we do have lists of surgeons who are normally used to conduct these sorts of examinations. Given those two points, it could be reasonably expected that, if a judicial order is to be obtained before an internal search, there is protection in the court process to ensure, if anyone is concerned about the sort of medical practitioner who might be conducting the tests, that those concerns are taken into account at that particular point. As I said, in practice we do have lists of surgeons and they are used both by Customs and the Australian Federal Police.

SPEECH.PARA: I make the point again that to prescribe a list does remove the degree of flexibility that would be needed, given the circumstances, the varying instances, the locations and the times in which and at which these searches can, and may, take place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to take the time of the Committee much longer because it seems as if the Minister and I are at cross-purposes. I will just put a simple case to him: a passenger comes through Sydney Airport this morning and, on the available evidence, an internal search is ordered. How will the senior Customs officer on duty get a medical practitioner to examine that passenger?

—I go back to the point I made earlier in response to this question; that is, the person would be detained to enable the authorities to obtain an order for detention from a judicial officer. As I mentioned earlier, in that process the question of the appropriate medical practitioner can be raised. It is not as easy as someone coming off the plane and an internal search being conducted by the time he leaves the Customs hall, for instance. There has to be that intervening process of judicial intervention. As I said earlier, given that time span and the judicial authority deciding that there should be an internal search, there is a general list that is used by the authorities on which the Customs officer can rely. One might find that half the surgeons are busy doing other operations and other sorts of things, but that pool is gone to in the first instance.

—I thank the Minister for that response. Subdivision D deals with detention places. Through the Bill there is a definition of what is required. Given the fact that lifesaving measures may well be necessary during the detention of the detainee, why has the suitability of the place in which the detainee is held not been subjected to approval by a medical authority?
—I presume that Senator MacGibbon is specifically or primarily concerned with those circumstances where internal searches are to be conducted.

—No. If a detainee is being held, the presumption is that illegal goods are concealed within the body of that person, and that therefore, the possibility of emergency procedures might arise. My question is that, given those grounds, there is a case for lifesaving and life support procedures to exist in the place where the detainee is held, and the place ought to be approved by a medical practitioner as suitable for those circumstances, in so far as it is possible to do that, having recognition of isolated ports of entry on the coast.

—The answer is a little unsatisfactory, but I am informed that in terms of detention places for the purposes of internal searches, those places will be as prescribed in the Bill in the provisions in clause 219zb (1). I am further informed that those places will be prescribed as medical institutions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move to clause 219zh which states:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Subject to subsection (4), at any time during the period during which a medical practitioner is involved in doing anything under this Division, an officer of Customs or police officer may ask the medical practitioner questions relating to whether an internal search of the detainee should be carried out, the manner in which such a search is being carried out or the results of such a search, and the medical practitioner must answer those questions to the best of his or her ability.

My question is: does that clause mean that while an internal examination is being carried out by a medical practitioner, an officer of Customs or a police officer will be present in the examining area?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct.

—Would not the Minister consider that, given the extensive and invasive nature of these searches, it would be more appropriate that the people present at the time-apart from the detainee-should be restricted to the medical team?

—The problem is a very simple one in that the person we are talking about is actually in detention. By definition, that means that that person is being detained by either Customs or police. The first point is that the person is in detention, so a detaining officer must be present. At law it causes another problem if, further down the track, there is a dispute as to what has actually been found. The detaining officers-the law enforcement authorities-would then not be in any real position to be authoritative about periods of time when they may not have been present. Those two points necessitate the capacity for, or ability or power of, a detaining officer to be present.
—I understand the Minister is now saying that the word of a medical practitioner or a nursing sister is of less standing in a court of law than that of a law enforcement officer-is that true?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is fair to say that in some cases there have been rulings where the aims of the law enforcement authorities have been frustrated because of time spans during which a person is technically out of detention. I ask Senator MacGibbon to look at, particularly, clause 219zc (4), which explicitly spells out that what we are talking about here is someone in detention and, while being detained, that person is regarded as being in the custody of three different sorts of authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: It would be very simplistic for me to say whether I believe a medical practitioner would have the same credibility in a court of law as a detaining officer. The fact is that the detaining officer needs to be present for the purposes of satisfying the continuing detention. A by-product of that is the necessity at law, sometimes, to ensure continuing detention rather than detention which has been broken.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect to clause 219zc (4), the matter of detention as defined in that clause would be met by a detention officer being outside a locked room to which there was only one exit or entry point. I do not read the requirement of that clause to be that the detention officer be physically in sight of the detainee. I think that is a literal interpretation of the clause and taken to absurd limits.
—Could I have that again, please?

—I think the Minister is taking a literal interpretation of clause 219zc (4) which means that the detaining officer has physically to be present-almost within arm's length of the detainee-whereas that surveillance, and the intention of the clause, could be maintained quite clearly if there was a locked room and the detention officer was outside, or numerous detention officers were at the exits.

—What interpretation I put or Senator MacGibbon puts on the clause at this stage is probably irrelevant to the sorts of interpretations a court will put on it further down the track. What we are doing here is formulating legislation which will be interpreted by courts. That is why I say the reality is that we need to have continuing in time detention. Senator MacGibbon maintains that might just be someone standing outside the door. I would argue, and courts have had it argued before them-sometimes successfully-that in circumstances such as these there needs to be closer detention, especially when the detainee is in contact with other people. As I say, my interpretation is irrelevant. We have to have legislation which can withstand those sorts of quirks of legal interpretation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am unable to accept that interpretation, but I will let that matter pass. I will come to another two points in relation to detention.

SPEECH.PARA: There are qualities of detention, and I might use that description. There is the detention of someone who has been convicted of a crime-but we are not talking about that position here. We are talking about someone about whom some suspicion exists. To apply the same standards as those applied to someone who has been convicted of a crime like murder or theft is quite inappropriate in the circumstances, and the legislation ought to reflect that.

The other thing is that a person who is detained even for the most horrendous crime is not subjected to the invasive nature of an internal body search. This is quite a different circumstance to taking someone's clothes off in a prison cell to see whether there are any weapons strapped to the body, or anything like that. This is a major procedure. I would have thought that any reasonable concern for the dignity of the detainee would have demanded that the people present at that time should be restricted to suitably qualified medical people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think there is anything more that I can add to what I have already said to Senator MacGibbon. Basically, the point is that legal authorities quite often can and do demand continuing custody. We are talking about a person being detained. The honourable senator makes a distinction between someone convicted of murder and someone suspected of murder, and I suppose in this instance between someone convicted of importing heroin and someone suspected of importing heroin. Unless we have both protections and powers in the first instance we may not get to the stage where someone is convicted.

SPEECH.PARA: The basic point here is that we are talking about someone who is being detained for the purpose of assessment as to whether he or she should be further detained for an internal search, and someone who is the subject of an order by a judicial authority to have that search conducted. There is a reasonable case, therefore, to expect that that person should be both protected by the law and held under legislation which ensures that the detaining authorities have powers which are fair but potent. I think the honourable senator's distinction between a suspect and a convicted person is not really relevant in these circumstances, although it might be in others.

TALK.START.PARA: —The very great difficulty the Government faced in drafting this legislation was the protection of the individual rights of travellers, and I think it has done that very well. But we really get to the whole nub of the argument when an internal search is demanded. I am at a loss to understand why, when such an examination is carried out, the Government, when it has a simple recourse available to it, will not grant privacy to the detainee in what is a very invasive and very undignified procedure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point has been made, and it is a point with which I am always sympathetic. I just draw the Committee's attention to the fact that this legislation has been surveyed by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, which gave it a tick in the knowledge that it provided a balance between the protection of individuals' rights and reasonable powers for detaining authorities. I think that should be taken into account.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators do raise points and principles such a those that Senator MacGibbon raises. I sympathise fully with Senator MacGibbon in the point he is making and the principle behind that point. However, I say that here we have a balance between giving reasonable power to authorities and protecting the privacy of individuals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Apparently the Government is not prepared to accept my point of view. I read the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, and I say with the greatest respect to members of that Committee that probably none of them has ever had a sigmoidoscopy performed on them.

SPEECH.PARA: I move to the other part of proposed new section 219zh, which states that the law will require a medical practitioner in the course of the examination to discuss, in effect, what he is doing. To me it seems absurd to be placing a legal requirement on a medical practitioner to answer questions relating to whether an internal search of the detainee should be carried out, the manner in which such a search is being carried out or the results of such a search, and to answer those questions to the best of his or her ability.
