That provision, in the way in which it is written, means that a Customs officer or a police officer can demand, while the examination is in progress, that the medical practitioner explain his findings in the course of the examination. I find that quite absurd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot believe that any medical practitioner would be willing to subject himself or herself to disruption in the course of a medical examination of the sort that Senator MacGibbon is concerned about by having to advert to questions or demands, as Senator MacGibbon put it, by Customs officers as to how he or she is undertaking that medical procedure.

SPEECH.PARA: The medical procedure is quite properly totally within the competence of the medical practitioner, and I do not think that he or she would be disrupted in undertaking that procedure by the asking of questions, but I think it is legitimate for the law enforcement officer to ask whether a particular procedure is being undertaken and what the results of that procedure are. That seems to me to be legitimate. I guess that there will be a working understanding which will enable the medical practitioner to be fully professionally competent in the undertaking of the medical examination, and the practitioner will certainly not be acting in some sort of disrupted way in accordance with whatever questions might be asked by a Customs or police officer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not challenge the central line of the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) that it is proper for a medical practitioner to give the advice that is required under proposed new section 219ZH. I am not challenging that at all; it is the timing that is of concern to me. I understand from the Minister's reply that he does not expect that the medical practitioner will be interrogated by the Customs officer or the police officer in the course of the examination. If that is so, why is it written that way in the Bill?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In looking at that proposed new section one has to see a working situation where somebody is accused of a serious offence. Obviously, the Customs and police officers have an interest in the outcome of the medical examination which is being undertaken, but the obligation on the medical practitioner is to answer the questions `to the best of his or her ability'. I take it that that refers to the competence and professional expertise of the medical practitioner, but it must also carry a recognition that he or she will not be able to answer questions in the course of an examination. It would be quite wrong to think that it was within the ability of a practitioner both to concentrate on an intricate internal examination and to answer questions coming over the shoulder from some Customs officer.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure, as I say, that the working arrangement will make the latter part of proposed new section 219zh (1) work, and I am quite confident that, if any difficulties are experienced by the medical practitioners, they will bring that to the notice of their professional organisations and possibly even the judge. We should not forget that the medical practitioner has, as I understand it, to report to the judicial officer who authorised the examination on the result of that examination, and I believe that the medical practitioner could quite properly indicate either in that report or in some other appropriate forum some dissatisfaction concerning the disruption or interruption caused by a Customs or police officer asking questions.

Quite frankly, I think this will work out. I think the medical practitioner will be very jealous of his or her reputation in carrying out this procedure without disruption by questions from an officer of Customs or police.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept that the practicalities of the matter are probably as the Minister has stated them, but I ask the Minister why, when there is a simple remedy in the form of amending that clause to read `prior to and after any examination', in addition to the written report which is required under a different section of the legislation, `the examining officer shall answer fully and to the best of his ability any questions and all questions asked by the Customs officer or the police officer'. That would seem to be a simple solution.

SPEECH.PARA: My final question to the Minister on this point is: if a Customs officer or a police officer chooses to interpret the powers given him under the proposed new section 219zh and demands an answer while the examination is being carrying on, what will happen?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would imagine that the medical practitioner would, in a robust way, tell that particular police or Customs officer to wait.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, we are here to pass legislation, and I would hope that in future legislation we will try for a little more precision on points that are easily definable.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to deal with clause 219zj, which deals with proceedings against medical practitioners. It reads:

Proceedings, other than proceedings concerning negligently causing injury, do not lie against a medical practitioner, or any person assisting or providing facilities to a medical practitioner, in respect of anything done by the medical practitioner under this Division.

I was wondering whether the Minister would explain what limits the Government would place on the word `negligently' in the phrase `negligently causing injury', given the fact that we are dealing with a person who initially sought to conceal a fact, or may have. I must use the word `may' there; the person may be quite innocent. In either case one is dealing with a detainee who is probably uncooperative, and some of the examination procedures would require a high degree of cooperation from the detainee if injury is to be avoided for the detainee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The law relating to negligence causing injury in relation to the carrying out of their responsibilities by medical practitioners is well regulated by the tort rule. Quite clearly, the medical practitioner is required to exercise a duty of care such as a competent medical practitioner would be able to offer to a person. Obviously there is a whole body of understanding of how that particular standard of care is to be achieved by the person possessing or holding himself or herself out as possessing competence in a particular professional field, in this case medicine.

SPEECH.PARA: I am fairly confident that what is being done here is preserving the legal liability of the practitioner for acting in a way that does not accord with the duty of care which the person being examined is entitled to expect. But in regard to the non-negligent examination, the medical practitioner is protected against any legal proceedings.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister at the table is a lawyer, and a good one, he would be aware that in the past 20 years there has been an enormous increase in litigation against practitioners in the health field. Given a trend which, sadly, seems to be developing for even greater recourse to litigation, why did not the Commonwealth undertake to accept all responsibility for any charges relating to injury that might be a consequence of this examination?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would imagine that the various professional bodies associated with the practice of medicine in this country would not themselves seek to create a situation in which the members of their profession are not held liable for negligent activity. This is something which I believe doctors are willing to bear; they hold themselves out as being especially trained in the practice of medicine. I believe that the community and the doctors themselves have a quite proper expectation that, should they fail in the ordinary way to exercise due care, they should be held liable. I do not see any reason why the Government should give a guarantee of payment of damages in relation to any injury caused by negligent activity by a professional, in this case a doctor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the Minister is quite right in the generality of what he says, that none of the professional bodies would seek to exclude their professional members from taking due care and precaution in the discharge of their professional duties. But we are not talking about the general case here; we are talking about a very difficult particular case involving probably a non-cooperative detainee. There are risks in two dimensions: there is the risk from the actual invasive nature of an internal body search, of movement of the patient and great damage to the patient's body arising as a consequence of that if the patient becomes violent. The second dimension of risk is that we are dealing with lethal substances, and the rupture of one of the containers could lead to the death of the carrier of those substances, and has done so. The circumstances are very different. I would have thought that there was a very good argument to be made for the Commonwealth's picking up the responsibility for this, except in cases of gross negligence-I use that term in its legal sense-as opposed to the lesser charge of negligent practice.

SPEECH.PARA: The examination of a detainee is is not something that the medical practitioners of Australia look forward to having to perform. I would think that nearly every medical practitioner who carried out this examination at the request of the Commonwealth did so out of a sense of public duty and public obligation-not out of any desire to practise his or her professional abilities.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the latter point put by Senator MacGibbon, but of course no doctor will be compelled to participate in such a procedure. As I am informed by the officers, clause 219zj is the result of quite long discussions with the Australian Medical Association (AMA), which was concerned that its membership would not undertake these sorts of internal searches without some sort of legal protection, except in cases where the practitioner was negligent. Apparently, the AMA recognised that in the case of negligence, ordinary rules of legal liability should obtain. But the sorts of misgivings that Senator MacGibbon expresses, apparently on behalf of the medical profession, have been taken into account in consultation with the representative body of the medical profession. Clause 219zj is thought to be sufficient to allay the fears of those medical practitioners who might undertake these duties out of a sense of public duty, as Senator MacGibbon has said. This is part of a regime which is designed in particular to stop drug trafficking into Australia. If they wish to cooperate in that policy objective of the Government of stopping trafficking of drugs into Australia but may have some misgivings, I believe that this clause helps to allay some of those misgivings in a way which apparently has been thought to be satisfactory to the Australian Medical Association.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I assume that the Government is not prepared to move on this point. But just to put the record straight, I have before me a letter written to me by the Federal body of the Australian Medical Association dated 5 February 1990. I would quote only one part of a paragraph entitled `Proceedings against medical practitioners'. It says that the Australian Medical Association `considers that proceedings should not lie against a medical practitioner except in cases of gross negligence'-and the `gross' is underlined.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Tate) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 14 September, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Senate take note of the statement and documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address my remarks on the Budget to road funding and the Inter-State Commission (ISC) report. I was surprised on Tuesday that the Cabinet meeting mentioned the new directions for road transport espoused by the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) and the Inter-State Commission. This subject has not received a lot of publicity and I doubt very much whether the average Australian even understands what it is all about.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I want to go through some of the details and point out what will happen if this Inter-State Commission report becomes a fact of life. It is going to have devastating effects on the rural economy, and that economy is already battling against high costs and low commodity prices. Mr Brown seems to be going to use economic blackmail to force the States into agreeing with the proposals. Mr Brown has threatened to withhold $1.6 billion annual road funding from the States unless they agree to transfer their vehicle registration powers to the Commonwealth. Mr Brown is hoping to persuade the Premiers to give up all their vehicle registration power and their collection of local road funding, and he will do try to do this at a special Premiers Conference at the end of this month.

It came as a breath of fresh air yesterday to see that the New South Wales Government will not hand its car registration over to Canberra. But Mr Brown has said that he believes he has powers under the Commonwealth Constitution to wrest the registration fees away from States. I suppose that that will be tested in a court, but I am very hopeful that it will not be able to happen. It is time that the whole of Australia realised what the Government is trying to do with the land transport system. The Inter-State Commission report recommendations mean much more than just a national vehicle registration scheme. Today, I want to point out to the Senate what they in fact will do. The ISC report recommends the end of the land transport system as we know it today. It recommends the end to the dominance of an efficient road transport system over the inefficient and, in many cases, non-existent rail in the inland areas of Australia.

This report means a complete change to Australians' land transport system: a national system of registration of all motor vehicles, including private cars; a national system for allocating road funds; and a national system of applying the user pays principle to all those who use Australian roads. Road transport will now become a Federal problem, not a State problem. Vehicles will be registered in Canberra; taxes and charges will be paid to Canberra; and funds for road maintenance will be allocated back to the States by Canberra. That means that road spending will be concentrated in the areas where most votes are. For the transport operators themselves, it means an increase in fuel taxes, an increase in costs to run their vehicles and an increase in paperwork.

There will be three components to the charges and the taxes that the operators of heavy vehicles are going to pay to the Government. Firstly, the registration fees: these are greatly reduced and will be around $50 to cover the cost of plate stickers and administration. That is the good news. The bad news is that mass distance charges are to be calculated according to the size and weight of the trailer plus the load, and each trailer is assessed and charged separately. For example, for a 40-foot freight trailer registered at, say, 34 tonnes, including the weight of the load and the weight of the trailer-and that is about the average size of the trailers used to shift about 70 per cent of the freight commodities around Australia-the annual mass distance charge will be $18,600. For a type 2 road train, the annual mass distance charge will be a massive $52,700, compared to the current Queensland registration fee of $6,200. The 40-foot trailer that I alluded to earlier has a registration in Queensland of about $2,500, and now that is going to be massively increased to $18,600.

A new schedule of charges for road trains and trailers permanently fitted with stock crates has been drawn up, and an average livestock transporter will be paying about $3,000 less in mass distance charges for a trailer than a general freight carrier. This is because there is a large amount of time that livestock operators travel empty. These charges will be payable quarterly and will be based on the average distance travelled. If an operator drives further than the average distance, then he will have to pay even more; and if he drives less, a rebate will be given at the end of the year. What that means is that transport operators will need to fit hubmeters onto their trailers to monitor the exact number of kilometres travelled.

One concession that the Inter-State Commission has made is that, in the first two years of the scheme, the operators will be charged only half of the mass distance charges to make the transition easier. From July 1992 to July 1994, operators will be paying about $9,300 annually to register a 40-foot trailer rather than $18,600. Then from July 1994 they will be paying the full $18,600.

The third part of the equation comes in terms of the Federal Government fuel excise. Currently, there is a 24.9c per litre Federal Government fuel excise and the original report proposed that this not change. However, in the latest report, the Commission has recommended that a further 6c per litre be added onto the cost of diesel fuel to compensate for the loss of revenue while the initial charges are being phased in. This is going to apply a massive increase to the cost of freight, particularly in the outback areas of Australia. In other words, while the Commission has accepted that the charges are going to be a big burden and need to be phased in, it has introduced another charge, this time on the cost of fuel, as compensation for it. It is hitting the transport industry both ways and, to use an old analogy, what it has decided to give on the swings it is getting back on the roundabout.

On current figures diesel fuel excise will rise to 30.9c a litre. Petrol has also been hit with a rise of 9.4c per litre in government tax, taking the amount of government excise on petrol from 24.9c to 34.3c per litre. This will increase the charges in all States. In New South Wales the increase will be 6c a litre because the Inter-State Commission recommends the reduction of all State fuel taxes. In Victoria it represents an increase of 5.3c a litre, in Queensland 9.5c a litre, in Western Australia 5.3c a litre, in South Australia 5c a litre, in Tasmania, which is affected less than most States, 3.2c a litre, and the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory will pay up to 6c a litre.

If the Government goes along with the recommendations of the Inter-State Commission it will make fuel more expensive. It has also decided to abolish the diesel fuel excise for rail. The plan is to make rail cheaper and road freight more expensive in an effort to push more freight onto the rail system and off the roads. But we cannot make the rail system more efficient by making the road transport system less efficient. We cannot take Australia's freight task away from an efficient privately owned and operated system and put it into the hands of a government controlled monopoly. Senator Collins is at present trying to straighten out the inefficiencies that we have on the wharves. Now we have the acceptance by Mr Brown, the Minister for Land Transport, of the recommendations made to the Government, to place a barrier against road transport and to push the freight onto rail which is in the hands of a government controlled monopoly.

It will be very difficult for rural Australia and, for that matter, all parts of Australia. I do not believe there is a great future in this proposal. Some of the concessions that have been made include the recommendation to reduce sales tax on new trucks and tyres from 20 per cent to 10 per cent, the acknowledgment that transport operators, especially livestock carries, travel extensively on private roads, and provisions have been made for rebates on this type of freight. The Commission has recommended transferable and temporary licences for operators who find themselves with a job requiring a heavier trailer or more trailers than they have registered.

The inner city motorist who averages about 20,000 kilometres a year will be paying far less to maintain Australia's roads than those motorists in rural areas where long distances are the norm. Local councils and government vehicles, which currently enjoy concessional registration through the State government registration schemes, will also be affected by this scheme. All vehicles will be registered through the national scheme, costing about $50, and council cars will still be paying the Federal Government excise through the fuel pump.

The proposal was discussed by the State and Territory transport Ministers on 7= September and a fair amount of reservation was expressed. But Mr Bob Brown, the Minister, received an in-principle agreement on the concept of a national land transport system. Some State Ministers have objected, but the timetable has now been set in motion for the State and Federal legislation to be drawn up. Mr Brown will push for that in a meeting at the end of this month.

Some of the implications have to be examined. A great number of rural towns in Australia are not serviced by rail. A great number of rail lines that run from east to west do not service the adjoining towns that may run from north to south. The people of such areas will be heavily disadvantaged. Commodity prices to the consumer will increase dramatically. I have been told that the cost of bringing cattle in from a place such as Quilpie will increase to 40c a kilogram and that will be passed on to the consumer in the capital cities. Increases will also occur in the cost of a number of items that will be required in rural Australia. The cost of everything from Weetbix to cattle dip, any freight carried into rural Australia, will increase by 10 per cent. This will impact heavily on the people in the city because they will be paying an increased price for commodities- fruit and vegetables, meat, daily groceries. But it will impact even more heavily on rural Australia. Some rural towns will almost disappear.

The plan went ahead in September with an in-principle agreement and the Minister wants to have it operating by July 1992. The Transport Minister, Mr Brown, is setting up an all-government task force to work on the establishment of a national vehicle registration scheme. The task force will examine the recommendations of the Inter-State Commission report and the national uniform road charging principle.

I have gone into rural Australia and told people about this ISC report and it has caused them massive worry about the future of their towns and the cost that it will impose on their standard of living. Before the Government goes any further in trying to implement this ISC report, it should and must do a social impact study on the ways in which towns in rural Australia will be affected. All over rural Australia people are starting to understand what this means to them. They will lose their privately owned transport operators. A lot of freight will be forced onto rail. A number of transport operators will go broke. Some operators have told me privately, and publicly at meetings, that there is not much point in trying to carry on now-they are operating on only a 5 per cent margin-because increases in the cost of registration by up to 800 per cent will put them in an unworkable position.

I hope that the Government will see reason on this proposal. A lot of people believed that it would not happen. When members of the press contacted Mr Brown, initially, when the first report came out, Mr Brown put them off by saying, `It is only a discussion paper; it will not happen for two years'. But now we find that there is a revised Inter-State Commission report and it is just as bad. The press is now running with a story that the recommendations of the report will be implemented very soon and that Mr Brown will invoke his constitutional powers to override the States. If that happens, it will be a matter of court judgment. But the Bill will have to pass through the Senate. I am relying on the Senate to have a deep sense of looking to the future of rural Australia and not imposing this threat on the country people. Not only rural Queensland will be affected; the whole of rural Australia is serviced by a road transport scheme and will be affected.

The Interstate Road Commission is part of the Government's economic reform package. I do not believe it will result in a decrease in the cost of production. The recommendations state that it will force efficient, privately owned, operated and controlled road transport operators who are prepared to drive and work hard and long hours-road transport operations I believe carry 70 per cent of Australia's freight-into a government-owned and controlled monopoly. Anyone with any business sense will agree that those efficiencies of the road transport system will not be able to be obtained from the rail systems.

The purpose in raising this very important issue today is to make the Senate aware of the situation. I see that Senator Kernot is present. It is her responsibility, as the person representing the Australian Democrats in the area of transport, to take into consideration the issues that I have raised today. I cannot state how important this matter is. The recommendations will mean an increase in the cost of freight considerably both to and from rural Australia. I cannot see how any benefits can be obtained for the consumer or the farmer if this Inter-State Commission report goes ahead, as Mr Brown seems determined that it will.

As I have said before, if the Government is determined to push ahead with it, as it seems it will, then the least it can do is to conduct a social and economic impact study on how the changes will affect Australia's primary producers and people who live outside the metropolitan areas.
Debate (on motion by Senator Button) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Button) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows -
This Bill makes a number of amendments to the Child Care Act 1972, the Health Insurance Act 1973, and the National Health Act 1953.
The amendments to the Child Care Act in this Bill give effect to the far reaching child care reforms promised by the Government during the election.
The measures promised during the election, and delivered in this year's Budget, build on a record of considerable achievement.
When this Government came to office, there were only 46,000 funded childcare places in the country.
There are now 122,000. We have tripled the numbers.
When the Government came to office, there was no systematic means of fee relief to support affordable childcare.

An estimated 90,000 families using non-profit community based centres will benefit from a more generous, targeted fee relief system from 1 October this year, and a further 35,000 families using commercial centres will benefit from the beginning of next year.
When the Government came to office, there was no planning to support the ever growing need for more community childcare.
We are now implementing needs based planning for 80,000 new childcare places in the community based centres.
By any measure, these are significant achievements.
We have produced one of the best integrated childcare systems in the world-and done it in less than a decade.
We have achieved this by pursuing three basic objectives:
- affordable care
- equity of access
- quality care
These three objectives are the basis of the Government's childcare policies. They lie at the heart of our election commitment on childcare.
The Government believes that a significant barrier to opening up opportunities for women has been, as the Treasurer said in the Budget Speech, `the lack of decent and affordable child care places'.
Our childcare policies are helping to breakdown that barrier.

The main challenges facing the Government in the l990s in childcare are, therefore, to increase the supply of quality childcare places and to make sure that ordinary Australian families are able to afford care. The proposed amendments promote these objectives, and enable the introduction of fee relief arrangements that are equitable across the non-profit community based sector and commercial sector of the childcare industry.

The Government will be tackling these issues in cooperation with the States and local government, and will be encouraging all sectors of the childcare industry-commercial, community and employer-provided-to participate in providing new places.

Implementation of the childcare election commitments will see the number of places almost double by 1995, involving the largest expansion of childcare ever undertaken-some 108,000 places over the next five years. It is estimated that the extension of fee relief as proposed in the Bill before the Senate, and changes to the fringe benefits tax legislation, will lead to around 28,000 of these new places being established in the commercial and employer childcare sectors.

An improved fee relief system, as promised in the election campaign, will be introduced for non-profit childcare services now covered by the program of services for families with children on 1 October this year. This Bill extends the improved system to commercial, employer-provided and other non-profit childcare centres not currently covered by the program from 1 January 1991. Many thousands of families currently using these centres will become eligible for help with their fees.

The cost of extending fee relief assistance to commercial centres and employer-provided childcare will be some $28m in 1990-91, increasing to about $105m in 1995-96 as more commercial childcare centres are established.

The opportunity is also being taken to tighten provisions in the Act to protect the Government's interests in land, buildings and equipment acquired by sponsor bodies through grants made under the Act.

At present, the Act provides for repayment of the whole or part of a grant if an agreement under the Act is breached. The amendment protects the Commonwealth's equity in its grant by providing for it to be repaid at an indexed rate if the agreement is breached, rather than at its original fixed rate. Without protection of this kind sponsors may be tempted to realise the value of capital assets, which have greatly increased over a number of years.

An associated amendment concerns power to approve transfers of land, buildings or equipment. The current provision is limited by a requirement that transfers only be approved on conditions set out in the original grants. The amendment will allow greater flexibility for transfers to be approved.

The Bill also seeks to amend the Health Insurance Act to change the maximum patient contribution under Medicare-that is the difference between the Medicare schedule fee and benefit from $20 to $26 from 1 January 1991. There has been no increase in the maximum patient contribution since the increase to $20 in November 1986.

Further where a person reaches the safety net threshold of $150 in a financial year by accumulating maximum patient contributions, Medicare pays benefits equal to 100% of the schedule fee for services rendered during the remainder of that year. The Bill will also increase the Medicare safety net threshold from the current $150 to $240 from 1 January 1991. This will be the first increase to the threshold since the introduction of Medicare in 1984.
In subsequent years, both patient gap payments, and the safety net threshold will increase automatically by CPI, in accordance with the provisions of this Bill.
The Bill also repeals section 21 of the Health Insurance Act 1973.

It is the Government's intention that non-residents of Australia, whether they be Australian citizens residing abroad or long term visitors from overseas, should not have access to Medicare eligibility. The Government believes that only persons who actually reside in Australia legally should have Medicare entitlements.

Since the inception of Medicare in 1984, Australian residents have been able to claim Medicare benefits in respect of the cost of medical services incurred overseas while they are temporarily absent from Australia. Where there is an equivalent item in the Medicare benefits schedule, such medical services have to date attracted benefits at the Australian schedule fee rate. No financial assistance is available in respect of hospital costs incurred overseas.

The Government has decided to discontinue the payment of Medicare benefits for medical treatment received overseas. In practice Medicare rebates are often very little more than token payments against the very high cost of medical treatment overseas. Indeed, Medicare rebates paid in respect of services rendered overseas often provide little more than a Commonwealth Government subsidy to the local insurance industry. The Government believes that a more appropriate and effective way of protecting Australian residents who travel overseas is to extend the network of reciprocal health care agreements with other countries. Such agreements provide Australian residents with access to both medical and hospital treatment on the same basis as residents of the host country.
Australia is currently party to agreements with the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Malta, Italy and Sweden. Negotiations are under way with a number of other European countries.

It is of great concern to me, and to my Ministerial colleagues, that many Australians undertake overseas travel without making appropriate arrangements concerning comprehensive travel insurance which includes a health insurance component in the event of illness overseas. Indeed, I am informed that less than 50 per cent of Australians travelling overseas take out adequate insurance with health insurance cover. Health costs overseas are often high, particularly in the United States of America where hospital charges in excess of $2,000 a day are not unusual. Thus, a 10-to 15-day stay in hospital can result in a devastating outlay of $20,000 to $30,000 for the patient. Very often people who incur these costs have no insurance whatsoever. The Government is unable to assist such persons, and nor should it. It is the responsibility of the individual to purchase adequate travel insurance cover, just as it is to make arrangements covering all other aspects of overseas travel such as obtaining travellers cheques, foreign currency, booking accommodation etc. The former availability of Medicare benefits may have provided a false impression in the minds of travellers that they were adequately protected against such costs.

Henceforth, from 1 January 1991 medical benefits will not be available for overseas medical treatment, and the Government will focus its efforts on further developing reciprocal arrangements with countries which have health care systems which are compatible with, and comparable to, Medicare. This amendment is expected to save approximately $5m a year in Medicare benefits from 1 January 1991.
A further purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the Government's structural reform of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.

This Bill introduces one of the key elements of the agreement between the Government and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia as it relates to restructure of the retail pharmacy industry. The Bill establishes the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority which is to be empowered to make recommendations to the Secretary to the Department of Community Services and Health for the payment of essential pharmacy allowances and on payments in respect of pharmacies that amalgamate with one or more other pharmacies, or close.

The Authority will also make recommendations on where new approvals to operate a pharmacy under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will be granted. The Authority will cease its activities on or before 31 March 1995.

For some time the Government has been concerned that there were too many pharmacies approved to supply pharmaceutical benefits. In 1972 the Pharmacy Guild of Australia suggested, to a House of Representatives Select Committee, the establishment of a committee to regulate approvals under the PBS. Several of the inquires which have been conducted involving the PBS, eg. Ralph, BIE and IAC, have drawn attention to the high pharmacy to population ratio.

The Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal in calculating the remuneration to be paid to pharmacists has continued to use an average cost structure and not the most efficient cost structure, with the result that inefficient and marginal pharmacies have continued to be supported.

The Expert Advisory Panel on Pharmacy Changes, a panel of pharmacists set up by the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services last year to assist him, were convinced that controls and limitations were needed on all new approvals to supply pharmaceutical benefits.

The Government has accepted recommendations from these bodies that it is clearly in the best interests of all Australians, both as taxpayers and patients, that pharmacy numbers be reduced by encouraging pharmacists to either amalgamate or close to reduce the numbers of inefficient pharmacies who are a drain on the Government, and to strengthen those more viable pharmacies that remain. Where an amalgamation or closure payment has been made with respect to particular premises, no new approval for the use of these premises as a pharmacy under the PBS will be granted without the approval criteria being met.
Clearly such proposals will be limited to those pharmacists where there is another approved pharmacy within a reasonable distance.

The Government is very aware of its responsibility to continue to support the adequate provision of pharmaceutical services to all Australians, but this clearly must be within the resources at its disposal. The Government has, however, included in this Bill provisions to provide financial encouragement for those small isolated pharmacies which are providing an essential service.

The membership of the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority will be made up of Government and industry nominees with an independent Chairperson, all appointed by the Minister. The Pharmacy Guild of Australia will make four nominations, two of which will be appointed.
The Authority will make its recommendations in accordance with guidelines to be determined by the Minister. These determinations are to be tabled in Parliament.

The Bill before the Senate, also amends the National Health Act 1953 and the Health Insurance Act 1973 to extend the secrecy provisions of these Acts to persons in receipt of information obtained under the Acts.

I refer to reports in the media last year about police investigations into an arrangement between a mercantile agent and Commonwealth officers whereby personal information was unlawfully made available by officers to the agent. The reports indicated that the mercantile agent then sold the information to financial institutions.

Legislation exists, both in the Crimes Act and in specific Acts, which makes it an offence for a Commonwealth officer, without lawful authority, to disclose information obtained in the course of duty. The Crimes Act also contains a provision which would enable action to be taken against a person who aided, abetted or was directly concerned in the commission of the offence by the Commonwealth officer.

It is a matter of concern that while a Commonwealth officer, and a mercantile agent with whom that officer may have had an arrangement to supply information, may be subject to prosecution, there is no offence by the purchaser of the information from the agent where that person may have known that the information had been unlawfully obtained.

This legislation extends the prohibitions in the two Acts to cover the dissemination of confidential information to third persons where these persons know or reasonably ought to know that the information has been disclosed to them in contravention of the legislation.

A further amendment is proposed to the secrecy provisions of the National Health Act 1953 to allow for the release of data pertaining to the sale of pharmaceutical benefit drugs in aggregate form, even though such a release would identify the manufacturer.

The present provisions, as now interpreted, prevents the release of data that would identify the affairs of a manufacturer. This has meant that information pertaining to a brand of a drug cannot be released where there are less than three manufacturers of that drug. This affects several of the major drug groups.

Clearly the presentation of statistics pertaining to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme are meaningless without the full data. This lack of data has hampered the management of this major high cost social welfare program, which requires continuous monitoring of drug usage to ensure that subsidised drugs are being used in ways which reflect both sound medical practice and cost effectiveness.

Recent legal advice suggests that the current provisions prevent the release of such data, even to meet the accountability and information requirements of Parliament. The needs of external research have been severely handicapped by the prohibition on the release of some data on drug usage.

This amendment will allow the release of aggregate data pertaining to the sale of drugs listed as pharmaceutical benefits, but such statistics shall not be published in a manner that enables the identification of a patient or pharmacist or medical practitioner but will permit the release of data that identifies the manufacturer.

A further amendment to the Health Insurance Act 1973 will make it clear that where a person is supported by a foreign government or company while in Australia that person is not entitled to a Health Care card. A decision of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal cast doubt on the existing provisions of the legislation and this amendment will make clear that persons in Australia and supported by an overseas government cannot have the benefits of Australia's social welfare programs.

I take the opportunity to announce to the Senate that from 1 December 1990 the existing provision of the National Health Act 1953, introduced on 1 July 1985, to allow for the continued listing of unique drugs, will provide the legislative framework to allow for the introduction of the minimum pricing policy. Under this scheme the Government will only fully subsidise the cost of the lowest priced brand of any drugs. With the costs of the PBS escalating at an ever increasing rate the Government has been forced to introduce such measures to reduce the actual and potential high cost of multi-brand drugs to the Scheme.

This provision allows the Minister to determine, after the normal negotiating process with all manufacturers of that drug, the base price for the particular brand of a multi brand drug. This will become the 'approved price to pharmacists' which forms the base for the reimbursement price to pharmacists. Should medical practitioners prescribe a dearer brand of the same drug, patients, including those receiving drugs at the $2.50 rate or free, will all have to pay the difference between the base price and the higher manufacturer's price.

I am happy to announce that the Government is intending to extend the benefits of the concessional category to all persons in receipt of part Family Allowance Supplement. This is an important expansion of benefits as it takes account of the needs of families who are struggling to make ends meet. This move will go a long way to help these families.

The restructuring of the pharmacy industry is expected to produce net savings of $43.2m in 1990-91 and $93.5m in 1991-92, noting that the Pharmacy Guild of Australia has offered to fund half of the closure and amalgamation packages which are a feature of restructuring the pharmacy industry.
The extension of concessional status to persons in receipt of a Family Allowance Supplement will cost an estimated $2.50m a year.
The new minimum pricing policy, while not an element of this Bill, will produce net saving of approximately $16m in 1990-91 and $47m in later years.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I now present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

(i) Consideration of Government documents; and
(ii) General Business notice of motion No. 69 standing in the name of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) relating to the rural economy.

That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Broadcasting Amendment Bill 1990 and the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990. These are very different animals and I want to make clear that we oppose the first and essentially support the second. I will be moving a second reading speech amendment to the first Bill in due course.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say that the politics of the legislation are quite transparent; they have been overtaken by the recent election. The only reason this Bill was ever introduced in late 1989 was to honour the promise of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) given prior to the 1987 election that the Government would urgently reform this nightmarish legislation, as he described the Broadcasting Act. I think there has been heated agreement in the community that the Broadcasting Act has been a walking disaster for a long time. But the Government had consistently refused to do anything about it. It finally dredged up this Bill in a blatant attempt to pretend that somehow there was some activity going on.

The legislation was supposedly primarily about giving the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) additional powers in the event that the High Court of Australia ultimately held that Bond Media and Mr Alan Bond were not fit and proper persons to hold television licences. In my judgment that has always been a beat-up. There was adequate power in the Tribunal to cope with that situation, either by way of simply adjourning the matter until other arrangements had been made or by way of securing undertakings from the licensee.

In the event, of course, that is not proven to be necessary with the disposal of Channel 9. But, certainly, we have taken the view that the Broadcasting Amendment Bill gives the Tribunal extremely wide and unnecessary powers and discretions which would enable it to intervene in virtually all aspects of the broadcasting industry.

As I have said, the spectre of mandatory revocation in the event of a finding that a licensee is not a fit and proper person is a sham. As the Federal Court of Australia made plain in the Bond case, the Tribunal does have a wide discretion to take into account all aspects of the public interest in deciding whether to suspend or revoke, to impose conditions or to accept undertakings. The Tribunal did not challenge that aspect of a full court ruling. The true situation was, therefore, markedly at odds with the second reading suggestion that the Tribunal was faced with extremely limited options in the event of any adverse finding.

The Bill is also totally inconsistent with two basic propositions which have the support of all the major political parties and the broadcasting industry-in other words, the need for a fundamental overhaul of broadcasting legislation on a considered and not a piecemeal basis and, secondly, the need to reduce the present plethora of extensive and inefficient legislation.

We regard this first Bill as nothing more than a smoke screen to disguise sustained inactivity over the last three years. It does not do anything to address the very real and continuing problems. It is in stark contrast, as my colleague Mr Brown pointed out in the House of Representatives during the debate on these Bills, to the second Bill, which does contain a number of extensive reforms and does attempt to sell itself as being in the business of substantial deregulation and refinement. But the first Bill is a token gesture that really does not add anything at all to the debate. We therefore take the view that it is quite unnecessary.

There are, I might say, still a number of fundamental problems in the radio and television industries that neither Bill addresses. I think we can essentially characterise the Government's attitude under the new Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) as still fiddling while the industry burns. His predecessor might have been known as Rip Van Willis but I think the present Minister has probably simply been distracted in other areas. But he has made a very inauspicious beginning in terms of reforming the Broadcasting Act.

Despite all the rhetoric about deregulation and wanting to make the system operate more efficiently, we still have this determined refusal to ban the introduction of pay television. Indeed, I think probably one of the most extraordinary examples of standing by and watching the radio industry bleed to death is the way in which the AM and FM industries have been not just left to their own devices but put in regulatory straightjackets. This has meant that the only real extension of FM licences has been in the area of public broadcasting. The whole licence tendering fiasco that has taken place that saw licences changing hands for extraordinary sums of money only to be demonstrated to be worthless a matter of months later has meant that the Government has been marking time in that area because it has not been prepared to tackle the real problems.

The Weekend Australian of 6-7 October contained a fascinating article by Mark Day in which he talked about what he describes as yet another revolution that is likely to overtake FM broadcasting as well as AM-that is, digital audio-broadcasting. This involves music being placed on digital discs or digital audio tape and played through digital equipment. It would seem that this is able to be done much more quickly and much more cheaply than is the case with current technology. It is likely to cause a lot of people in the industry to quiver in their boots because current commercial values will be rendered, if not worthless, certainly very much in jeopardy.

There is simply no sign at all of the Government being aware of this latest technological revolution. Indeed, it is still bogged in the mire of the damage that it has done in relation to the sale of FM licences. I think there is tremendous scope for the Government, if it is serious about deregulation, to start addressing some of these difficulties. What they really show, I think in many respects, is that if we attempt by regulation to guide the direction of the industry we will inevitably fail because we will be overtaken by technological developments that are usually a long way ahead of the ability of lawyers and regulators to define where the boundary ought to be.

That is a classic lesson that is being learnt, or will be learnt I am sure, in the telecommunications industry where this Government has bent over backwards to ensure that Telecom Australia maintains its de facto monopoly of telecommunications by, on the one hand, pricing the potential entrant in such a way that there will be enormous start up costs and, on the other hand, imposing very serious limitations of movement. We will see, in effect, one monster competing against one small player with one arm tied behind its back.

That all comes about because of the Government's desire to draw boundary lines and to regulate the industry in a way that simply does not allow technological progress to take place. In the area of broadcasting, I think that is precisely what Mark Day is identifying. There we have the latest technology that the Government will have to confront and yet it still has not even satisfactorily resolved how it will address what might well be yesterday's technology in terms of AM and FM radio.

The first Bill that we are debating today is thoroughly inadequate in its ambit. It simply gives the Tribunal a whole range of discretions that seem to me to be verging on the extraordinary. It gives the Tribunal powers to impose conditions on third parties so that they have virtually no recourse and to make orders against foreigners in such a way that there will be serious interferences with their ordinary businesses. If these powers are taken at face value, the legislation will put the industry into a regulatory straitjacket.

I have enough confidence in the good sense of the Tribunal to believe that that will not take place, that there will be commonsense exercised. But before one gives someone such sweeping powers, one needs to demonstrate why it is necessary. There is very little on the public record to justify any of these extensions of power. We conclude that this first Bill will simply not tackle any of the serious reform issues but, rather, will put in place further labyrinthine hurdles in the way of competition.

One recent case study which has come to my attention deserves some consideration by the Government. I hope that, in view of the fact that this debate will not proceed beyond the second reading stage and that the committee stage will be taking place, at the earliest, next week, there will be ample opportunity for the Government to address this matter. I stand to be corrected if either of these Bills do in fact cure the defect to which I propose to refer, but it is my information that they do not. Therefore, I want to draw attention to a difficulty that I think is still alive and well in terms of prescribed interests.

As the world knows, Harlin Holdings is a company with extensive interests in Elders IXL Ltd. For some time this company has been anxious to reduce its debt burden by selling off a portion of its shares. What it has done recently-and I am simply going on what is in the newspapers-is effectively sell a proportion or a parcel of shares to a Japanese brewer by the name of Asahi. Asahi, by virtue of very complicated tracing provisions, ends up having a prescribed interest in Austereo Radio. That seems to be an extraordinary and unintended state of affairs.

My information is that if Asahi buys something of the order of 20 per cent of Harlin Holdings, which still has a 36 per cent, or thereabouts, interest in Elders and Elders owns 18.5 per cent, or thereabouts, in South Australian Brewing Co. Ltd, which owns more than 15 per cent of Austereo, which holds a number of radio licences, by virtue of this complicated chain that is in place Asahi is deemed to be in control of Austereo.

As I say-and I would be happy to be corrected-it seems to me that this is a legacy of what was presumably a quite well-founded concern in the old days to ensure that particularly foreign corporations were not able to acquire controlling interests in what was regarded as a fairly sensitive industry. But to apply those rules in such a rigid manner that actual control could be deemed with no let out does seem to be quite counterproductive. Yet, as I understand it, that is what happens in this instance and, I presume, others.

So Asahi's attempt to purchase and, indeed, Harlin's attempt to sell, could be injuncted by the ABT simply on the basis of what is technically a prescribed interest. I suppose it could also be that the Foreign Investment Review Board could come into the proceedings in the same way. I am indebted to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) for indicating that I seem to be on the right track.

If that is the situation, there does seem to be one fairly straightforward way of dealing with the problem and that is to apply the discretion that applies in the area of companies legislation. Where there is a situation where someone had apparently unintentionally acquired an interest and the view was taken that the major concern was to get into another industry altogether, that there was no apparent level of expertise that might even justify thinking about getting an interest in that area, one would allow the relevant authority-and that is probably the ABT-to grant a waiver for technical non-compliance. But, as I understand it, there is no provision in respect of the Tribunal for that to occur and the Tribunal, in one sense, has no choice but simply to step in.

What has happened in the past-and this is why this whole regulatory imbroglio has been getting worse and worse over the years-is that the Tribunal effectively defers these sorts of decisions. It puts them in the too-hard basket until they are ultimately resolved by other means. That is what we have seen with Bond. I suppose the slow legal processes have contributed to the length of time from when someone first took the view that Mr Bond might have been not a fit and proper person until the High Court finally resolved the matter. But, nonetheless, it took the Tribunal quite a deal of time to get around to that.

In the same way, it has taken a great deal of time to get around to other issues. That can, in part, be, of course, because of scarce resources and one is not critical of the Tribunal for that. But, in effect, it is quite a legitimate tactic, if it shares the community concern that there ought to be a waiver or that it ought not be compelled to inflict what could be quite a devastating corporate outcome on a company for technical non-compliance, for it simply to adjourn the matter. And that, I think, is what has been happening to date. But it is not at all a satisfactory situation.

There are percentage interest multipliers that can apply on the way down. So, if Asahi has 20 per cent and that is multiplied by the 15 per cent that Elders might have or that South Australian Brewing might have in Austereo, we end up with an effective figure that can be below the level of prescribed interest-the 5 per cent threshold. That can apply in a number of areas. But, again, my information is that we cannot apply that reducing multiplier in this area. So, once it is determined that at some stage in the chain someone is in excess of 15 per cent, that person is gone.

I hope that the Government will take the opportunity of the time that will be available between the conclusion of the second reading debate and the committee stage to give some serious examination to this issue and, at the very least, to report to the Senate on what it proposes to do about situations such as this.

I would now like to turn to the second Bill-the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990. There will be, as there were in the House of Representatives, some amendments moved to this Bill at the committee stage. But, essentially, the so-called efficiency package which has finally been introduced by the Government does contain a number of desirable improvements along the path of deregulation and we, therefore, welcome those initiatives, belated though they are. I think the industry itself has had some involvement by way of consultation and, as a result, I think what we do see in this Bill is a worthwhile endeavour to free up the system.

Certainly in the area of licence renewals there has been a crying need to reduce the number of unnecessary applications. The way it used to work-and I suppose it still does, in a sense, until this Bill comes in-is that we can have, as I recall the Chairman of the ABT, Deidre O'Connor saying, the same effective decisions made on 54 occasions simply by looking at the technical licence holders around Australia. One is dealing with the same issue. They may be simply regional licensees or suburban metropolitan licensees but all of them could be in the Channel Nine stable and applying the same rules and principles. The Tribunal is making essentially the same decision. Yet, technically it has been required to conduct all these separate licence renewal applications, to call for submissions and generally clog up the system.

This Bill will reduce by something like 90 per cent the number of share transactions that currently have to be approved by the Tribunal. We think that is a very desirable state of affairs. It will also allow for licences to be held for a period of up to five years instead of the current three. As I recall, there have been maybe one or two instances where licences have been granted for less than three years.
My view would be that one could almost justify the granting of licences in perpetuity. If this happened, we would not need these automatic licence renewal hearings.

One would introduce much more flexibility into the system so that, if at any stage it was thought there was sufficient reason to justify the withdrawal or suspension of a licence, one would put the licensee on notice that it would have to show cause why its licence should not be revoked or suspended. That seems to me to be a much more sensible system than the one that we have in place at the present time.

This Bill will allow the three years to become five years and that is an improvement. But, nonetheless, I still think licensees will have to go through some hearing processes that will not be altogether necessary. Like it or not, hearings involve very serious preparation. One has to start with the presumption that, unless one satisfies the Tribunal and satisfies all the concerns and the interest groups that might pop out of the woodwork at the renewal hearings, one might not get one's licence renewed. That, in many ways, is a fiction but, technically speaking, that is the way the system operates. I do not think that is particularly satisfactory. I think there ought to be a strong presumption of renewal unless there is material to indicate that the licence might be in jeopardy or ought to be placed in some jeopardy. Therefore, I think, this is a step in the right direction but the system could be freed up even further.

There is a change to the prescribed interest test in the application to television licences but, as I understand it, it does not address the particular case that I have been adverting to. The prescribed interest threshold being raised from 5 per cent to 15 per cent does go some way in that regard. Nonetheless, as I have described it, we would still have the same problem that exists at the present time because each of those holdings exceeds 15 per cent, no matter how remote they might ultimately be.

There are improvements in the area of loan arrangements. But one of the serious anomalies in this area which has not yet been addressed by legislation but to which my colleague Mr Brown referred to in the earlier debate was that this Government, pursuing no doubt its ideological desire to pander to the left wing, has brought in this extraordinary limitation on foreign ownership. But it has not, at the same time, suggested that there should be the same level of limitation on loans.

So, as things stand at the present time, if and when that legislation finally surfaces, we are going to have this across the board limit of 20 per cent on both licensee and holding companies but we are not going to have a limit on loans from foreigners who could ultimately be regarded as being in effective control. That is a nonsense situation. No doubt the Government will ultimately get around to making that a 20 per cent limit and will claim consistency. All it will be is a classic overreaction because it thinks that there are a few votes in xenophobia. But it will do nothing for improving the quality of input from foreigners.

There is all the power in the world, as we know, for the Tribunal to investigate any situations where it thinks that there is an excess of control, be it foreign or otherwise. It is a regrettable state of affairs that the Government has simply taken the sort of classically political response that it has. At least I would hope that it will try to address the inconsistencies that currently operate between ownership and loan arrangements.

There are a couple of other matters that are dealt with by the Bill. But I do not think I need to deal with them in any detail other than to say that we will oppose the amendment in relation to networking because, as it stands at the moment, what the Government is saying is that, by virtue of network agreements which are not quite exclusive arrangements but give rights of first refusal, we can effectively have regional operating stations as slaves of the metropolitan networks, or tied to the chariot wheels of the networks, as Mr Brown described it. If that is the case, the audience reach limitations have been breached. The Government is, in effect, by this amendment saying, `Let us ignore all that. Let us allow these networking agreements to override what otherwise would seem to be a strong limitation'.

We do not understand the rationale for 60 per cent any more than the Government does. We know how it came about but the fact remains that what the Government is doing by way of this amendment is to ignore its own theoretical limit of 60 per cent. At the very least, we believe that it should not have sought to change the rules in midstream whilst there was litigation in process. It is a very undesirable state of affairs, in effect, to take away people's existing rights by changing the law in this way. I think at the end of the day it will need to resolve that contradiction between network agreements and the appropriate limits of audience reach. But, at the moment, they are fundamentally incompatible and we, therefore, oppose that particular provision.

We do think the Government has simply allowed for renewed uncertainty surrounding the foreign ownership proposals. It is extraordinary that we end up with this 20 per cent deal in broadcasting. I am not sure what we will ultimately see in the legislation, but my reading of what passed for a debate in the Australian Labor Party was that at one stage Mr Beazley was prepared to allow unlimited foreign ownership levels in relation to the new entrant. That is not even something that most of the major overseas telecommunications companies were seeking. It seemed to be an extraordinary attempt somehow to demonstrate that the Government was bending over backwards to accommodate a second entrant. It is a classic overreaction in the sense that this is a classic underreaction.

We think the Government is wrong on both counts. We hope that ultimately sanity will prevail. I do not think anyone wants to see majority of foreign ownership in the telecommunications industry any more than they want to see majority of foreign ownership of radio and television stations.

But there has to be a much more sensible limit than the arbitrary 20 per cent figure that the Government has plucked out of the air. We do not believe that there have been terribly many problems in recent years that would have justified that happening in any event. Mr Acting Deputy President, I wish to move the amendment circulated in the name of the Opposition. I move:
At end of motion, add:

``, but the Senate deplores the Government's hasty and ill-conceived attempt to bestow a vast new range of unpredictable and unnecessary powers on the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in a desperate attempt to divert attention from its total failure to introduce any meaningful reforms of broadcasting regulation despite the Prime Minister's unequivocal 1987 election promise to `urgently reform this nightmarish legislation' ''.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the state of our economy, our exporters and their markets are indeed a matter of crucial public interest. They are not just important to our future -they are imperative. Australian exporters can and do have amazing successes. Just two weeks ago, for example, the British media carried a story that the viability of the much heralded channel tunnel of the future was now in doubt. This was not because of any downturn in the English Channel traffic. Quite the contrary. It was all because of an Australian export-a Tasmanian designed and built catamaran which can drastically cut both cost and time to the public between the United Kingdom and France, so much so that research has determined that the public would be much more likely to opt for the catamaran trip than the tunnel charges.

SPEECH.PARA: The huge success of the catamaran export out of a small, determined and tenacious Tasmanian boatyard is something all of us ought to be proud of. In fact, I am sure my colleagues across the chamber, not the least yourself, Mr Acting Deputy President, would admit to feeling some pride at its success on the international market.

So it defies logic that during this session of Parliament we expect the Government to preside over a Bill-the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill-which will most definitely spell the death of many Australian export ventures similar to that of the Tasmanian catamaran. Even worse, the man presiding over the damning legislation is none other than Senator John Button. His determination, despite months of lobbying from exporters, to barge ahead with the legislation, based on the recommendations of the Committee for the Review of Export Market Development Assistance-better known as the Hughes committee-is not easily understood.

After all, this sort of action is not expected from a Minister who professes to be so worried about the effect his Government's economic policies are having on our `good' manufacturing industry that he breaks ranks and says so to the media. How could he make such statements when his own actions, by ignoring the problems of the Hughes report, are themselves threatening to `wipe out'-to use his words-many small `good' Australian manufacturers fighting for a place in the world's export markets?

The recommendations of the Hughes committee are so out of kilter that in my State, South Australia, we will have the crazy situation of small companies which have won prestigious State awards for their hard won export successes being denied any further aid from the export development grants scheme. In other words, in many cases, thanks to the Federal Government and the proposed legislation, it is unlikely that they will be able to stay competing in the export arena. Award winners, hard workers, are in effect finished.

As Senator Button has already pointed out, many of these companies are already battered and bruised by the Government's high interest rate policies. So on the one hand he is apologising but on the other hand he clearly has no compunction about adding to the pain and the suffering of those industries.

So what is wrong with the Hughes report? South Australia illustrates exactly what is wrong with it. Either it ignores or it refuses to accept that it is not only big companies that are battling for our much needed export dollar. Its views and its recommendations are aimed at big companies with big dollars to spend chasing and maintaining export markets around the world. Also, its views and its recommendations seem not to take into consideration the difficulties companies encounter hanging on to the export market once they get a grip of it. Again, this applies much more to small companies with fewer dollars and less resources to fall back upon.

In my State it is not just big companies but, in fact, mainly small to medium companies that are battling away to carve a name for themselves, their State and their country by selling quality and innovative goods that the world market wants. But what does Senator Button, with his Hughes report and his legislation, say to them? He says, `You must spend more than $50,000 chasing the export market instead of $10,000 before we will help you'. He says, `Even when you do, we will now only help with 50 per cent of the costs, instead of 70 per cent and we will then tax the grant at the corporate tax rate of 39 per cent'. Then he says, `After we have helped you eight times, no more-you are on your own'. So the picture becomes somewhat clearer.

The Government, which has so crippled the domestic small business sector, the very engine room of our economy, strikes again. And again-no surprise-small companies are the ones that are principally suffering. The reality is that many small companies do not have $15,000 to spend chasing an overseas market, let alone having to find $50,000. That does not mean their quest for a market cannot be successful; often it is. But the Government is saying, `We will not help you unless you spend a lot of money you cannot afford to, given the current economic circumstances in this country. And once you have established your overseas markets and the locals there have decided they can make a cheap copy of your product, we will withdraw financial support just when you need it to fight to keep the market that you have established overseas'.

Yet we know that, especially in South East Asia, Australian firms are constantly fighting the cheap local copies which spring up in the marketplace usually some three to four years after the Australian product has accessed that market and has been introduced. That simply does not just halt after eight years of export grants.

In today's economic climate of adverse exchange rates and high interest rates, the Australian exporter is struggling continually to maintain competitiveness and stay in the marketplace. Maintaining markets is a costly and time consuming task. Exporters generally agree that that is even more expensive than to set up the markets in the first place. Having accessed the markets, maintaining and expanding those markets does require-and clearly, this is demonstrated-continual effort on behalf of exporters.

Does the Government seriously believe that this, too, just stops after eight years? And where is the consideration in the Hughes report that small to medium firms may also be using each grant to attract new business as well as maintain existing markets? There is none. If the committee and the Government had set out to find a way to discourage small companies from venturing into exporting and to encourage many firms to retire from exporting, it could not have tried harder or perhaps more successfully. Incentive is not an ugly word if used correctly. In today's economic climate it is essential.

Australian exporters suffer far more than those in other countries. We have got geographical problems in that we are remote from export markets. Our geography also means that we have very high shipping costs and long lead times. We suffer waterfront delays and added costs because of inefficiencies.

I know that the Government is saying that it is going to address some of these matters and micro-economic reform. Senator Collins has indicated to the Senate publicly that if he does not achieve substantial reform by the end of this year he will resign. I will just remind him that he has only a few weeks to go to deliver on that key promise and statement that he has made publicly.

I hope he achieves in that short timeframe the benchmark that he set publicly, not so much so that he can keep his ministerial post but for the people, the exporters and job opportunities for Australians. That is the more important reason why I hope that over the next few weeks he actually achieves some of the objectives that he has put down for himself.

Our inflation rate versus that of our competitors is also a problem. It lets us down at every turn. Of course, we have already canvassed the Government's monetary policy and the high interest rates which are crippling business. Through all this we expect our exporters to cope. We are encouraging them to go out to assist us with our balance of payments and the like. And now Senator Button wants to make it even more difficult and frustrating for them. For someone who is supposed to be aiming to reduce the balance of payments, he is instead going a long way to ensuring it worsens as companies give up the fight. And give up the fight they will because it will become impossible and too difficult for them.

In South Australia many national companies such as Wolf Blass Wines and ROH Industries, which has made a name for itself by exporting car wheels to both Japan and America, have made vocal protests about the damage the Hughes report and the subsequent legislation will cause to their companies' export programs. Last year's State Bank export award winner, Concraft (S.A.) Pty Ltd, a small company which has cornered the Japanese market in garden ornaments, would now find itself ineligible for the very grant which enabled it to venture into exporting. It would disqualify itself from the grant that enabled it to establish a market in Japan. Where is the logic in that?

Already it is estimated that some 50 per cent of companies that set up an export market fail or withdraw within three years. That figure can only increase if Senator Button will not listen to sense and if the Government is hell bent on proceeding with implementing major recommendations of the Hughes report and introducing legislation.

Senator Button has had the courage-and I think that ought to be acknowledged-to own up to a number of the Government's mistakes and publicly acknowledge them. Only this week we have seen him publicly acknowledge how the high interest rate policy direction of this Government over a number of years is starting to bite to the point that many businesses are being forced into bankruptcy. Personal trauma is being inflicted on individuals throughout this country. Thousands upon thousands of people are losing their jobs in this country. And the Government will not turn that around in five minutes. The point is that we have on the agenda, over the course of the next few months, a piece of legislation that will only compound the problem in the future.

As Senator Button has had the courage to acknowledge the failings of the Government in another area, does he have the courage to own up to his own in this particular field in proceeding to legislate to implement the Hughes recommendations?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to seek leave to table a couple of documents relating to a matter which has now been wound by the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. In my view it is sad that the inquiry into the reference of drugs in sport has now finished because a few other things should have done, not the least the process of education within the community.
