A number of surveys that have been undertaken show that there is a clear lack of understanding--
—Do you want to table some documents?
—Yes.
—Have they been shown to anybody?

—No, I just brought them in. One is a document entitled A Survey of Community Attitudes to Drugs in Sport carried out by the Australian Sports Drug Agency. The other is a transcript of public evidence given before the inquiry. I seek leave to table the documents.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is regrettable that the community is not more aware of the insidious effects of these drugs. The survey goes a long way towards demonstrating the absence of understanding in the community. Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 1 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Social Security aware that forms have been sent to family allowance recipients-and I have already given him a copy of one-advising them that if their assets exceed $300,000 they will be ineligible to receive further payments? Is it a fact that currently there is no asset test on family allowances and that the legislation which would authorise such a change has not yet been introduced into the Parliament? Did the Minister authorise the distribution of these inaccurate and misleading forms and what does he propose to do about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, like most Ministers here, try to take a charitable view of the undertakings given by the Opposition. I still like to believe in honour, not among thieves but among politicians. Given this fundamental belief that I have in honour--

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Harradine interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I still believe in honour, Senator. Given this fundamental belief, I would like to think that those things which are said by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hewson, can be believed. It is kind of hard sometimes as one's faith does tend to be broken and shattered when the Opposition walks away from all that Mr Hewson might say. I can recall listening to numerous interviews of Mr Hewson -that tough, hairy-chested dry-after the Budget was brought down when Mr Hewson said to us that he supported the measures that we had taken: the tightening that we had undertaken in the Budget on this issue, the tax file numbers and computer matching, which so many on the other side now seek to walk away from. I would have thought that honour might have been maintained. If there is a suggestion in what Senator Alston has to say that this will be a thing of the past, that that honour has now gone and that the Opposition intends to honour nothing of what Mr Hewson has had to say, then certainly I will have to make some other arrangements for my Department.

ANSWER.PARA: I have not personally authorised the sending out of this form. It is very hard to authorise the sending out of the thousands of forms that are sent out by my Department. However, I am not operating under the view that this tightening, supported by Mr Hewson, is about to be dropped by the Opposition and opposed in the Senate. If honourable senators opposite are walking away from their Leader's undertakings once again, I am delighted that we are being told so today. However, it must be understood that for a whole welter of changes that have been introduced in the Budget-

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. I think we have all been remarkably tolerant. I presume that the Minister is referring to Dr Hewson and is deliberately trying to downplay his credentials by calling him Mr Hewson. The real point of my objection is that we have now had about three minutes worth of everything but an answer to the question. Mr President, I invite you to direct the Minister's attention to the requirements for relevance. The question is simply whether or not the form is misleading, whether the Minister played any part in it, and indeed on what basis it was sent out.
—Whilst there is no point of order I remind the Minister of the amount of time that he has spent in answering the question so far.

—I am delighted that you would remind me, Mr President. I have, of course, already said that I did not personally authorise the issue of this form. That, I thought, was a direct answer to Senator Alston's question. However, it then comes to what we will do about it and where we will take it from here. It is necessary, when one has start up dates some months down the track for this change and for a number of others, to begin preparations as early as possible. We have to let the people of Australia know what is in store for them; they have to make plans. I would assume that if this form has been sent out, obviously, the Department has made the assumption that it is better to notify people as early as possible of a budget change that hitherto has not been suggested as being opposed by the Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: I will find out from the Department now when this form was sent out and to whom it was sent. I hope, however, that nothing in Senator Alston's remarks would suggest that he or the Opposition will walk away from the undertakings given by Dr-and I stress `Dr'-Hewson. No insult was intended in not referring to Dr Hewson as `Dr'. I will discipline myself to call him `Dr' henceforth.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Implicit in that answer is the suggestion that the Minister has not the slightest concern about this Parliament being circumvented. I invite him to indicate whether that is the Government's view, that it does not care whether legislation is actually in force to authorise this sort of action, because the form says quite explicitly that `If the total . . . of your . . . assets is less than $300,000 . . . you will continue to get FA...'.

QUESTION.PARA: That seems to me to be a complete and absolute denial of the need for legislation. I invite the Minister to indicate whether he takes a negative view of that sort of behaviour, what steps he will take to make sure it does not happen again, and whether he will espouse to this chamber the importance of all departments ensuring that no further action is taken before legislation is in place?

I finally invite the Minister to indicate, if he is really hooked on the idea that somehow there is some sort of commitment on our side, whether he or his Department made any attempt at all to communicate with the Opposition in any way whatsoever before these forms were sent out?

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no requirement on the part of my Department nor myself to have the Opposition's permission to send out a form, this form or any other. I do not intend to introduce as a precedent that permission. I have already said that I did not authorise the sending out of this form. That does not mean, however, that I will not seek an explanation for its being sent out, which I will provide to the Senate. At the time of the providing of that answer, I will talk to Senator Alston about my approval or disapproval.

—My question is also addressed to the Minister for Social Security. As part of the Government's plan to use tax file numbers to increase computer cross-matching of Commonwealth income support payments, will a central data bank of information be created? I further ask: How will any information gathered be treated and who will have access to it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in this chamber Senator Bishop tabled some pages of a tender document. Subsequent to that Senator Boswell got himself into a bit of a lather about what was in it and proceeded to go on radio and tell people that this represents--
—And television, too.
—I hope he was not chewing a muesli bar when he was on that.
—He was communicating with the nation.

—I am glad to hear that he was communicating to the nation; our vote will go up every time he does that. When Senator Boswell was telling this breathless nation, waiting for everything he had to say, that we had the provision of a central databank, unfortunately he got it a little bit wrong. Given that we are in politics, I do not mind everybody desperately searching for a headline. But there must be some accuracy in this debate because it is of crucial importance to our Budget preparations. One wonders how the Opposition would ever cut $3 billion off government expenditure, as it claims it would, if it did not take the option of getting $400m from some cheats.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me go through this draft tender document. It is a very thick document. Only a couple of pages in this document--

TALK.START.PARA: —Are we going to get the rest of it?

—Yes, Senator Bishop can have the rest of it; definitely. Only a couple of pages in this document actually relate to our computer matching program from the Budget; most of it relates to an upgrading and an updating of the material of the Department of Social Security (DSS); its commitment now. There will be-there has always been-a central databank of our own information. That is what this is about. Obviously, we will continue to update our own programs and our own capacity to collate and use our own information; not the information from any other agency-just our own.
—What?
—What is wrong with that? I reassert it--
—Say it again.

—We will have a central database of our own information; not that from other departments-just our own. That is what we will have. We always had it. There is nothing new in that. It has always been there. But there will be no central database for any other department.
—No, because you will have it all.
—No, because we have information only from our own. That is what--
—Enhanced by other departments, including the tax file number.
—Order! There are too many interjections, which are adding to the length of the answer.

—Trying to suggest that this is some sort of secret document is quite extraordinary, given that we have had 40 representatives from the industry sitting in a room going over it and that we have had newspaper advertisements calling for people to give us further comments on it. We are having it produced here as some sort of secret weapon. That, it is not. As I said, only a few pages of it actually refer to the computer cross matching proposal. This is a draft document only-a draft. It is a draft that has already been supplied to the Privacy Commissioner. Before this can become a real document, it will go before an interdepartmental committee. The Privacy Commissioner, having chosen-even though he was offered-not to be a member of it but to be an observer on it, will be in attendance and will therefore be commenting on that draft tender document. But it does not refer--
—But only at your request.

—I have given a guarantee that I will request the Privacy Commissioner to give us advice on every single part of the process. I am now repeating that. I also point out that this process proves that I am keeping the undertaking.
—Do we get the advice?
—Order!

—I did not even hear that interjection. I gave an undertaking yesterday that I would be providing to this Parliament every piece of information provided to me by the Privacy Commissioner, except for that which will be used by the Cabinet. Once it has been used by the Cabinet, it can be made public. There is no point in suppressing information from the Privacy Commissioner.

ANSWER.PARA: To get back to the crux of that which Senator Boswell was claiming, there will be no central databank; all that the DSS will do, as a result of this process, is act as a clearing house for information. The information that will be received from other departments, the information that will be received from the Australian Taxation Office, when cross matched, will take but a few hours.

At the end of that exercise, all of that information gets destroyed unless it shows up possible overpayments. So 97 per cent of the information that we will be receiving gets destroyed within a few hours. There will be a very secure system to ensure that that happens.

If Senator Boswell took the opportunity to go out to that centre and have a look, he would see just how secure this operation is, has been, and will be for the future. I hope that all Opposition senators, instead of just chasing the headline, stick with what Mr Hewson said the day after the Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dr Hewson.

—Dr Hewson. I am sorry; I am ill-disciplined again. He said that he would have done all that we did, and more. He never specified the `more'; that, of course, is where those opposite hack into the incomes of all poor Australians. But we will not let that happen because we will be here for a long time to ensure that they are protected.

ANSWER.PARA: I hope that as this debate unfolds the fact that there will be no central database for information from other departments is understood fully. I have given up on members of the Opposition; they do not want to understand it. I hope that the Australian Democrats at least give us the opportunity of demonstrating that to be a fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. What system does the Department have for ensuring that changes of circumstances are properly taken into account in determining continuing eligibility and levels of entitlement for social security benefits?

—When the Department is notified of changes in circumstances, sometimes the change will be accepted and the change in benefit will occur automatically. If there is reason to suspect that there is something wrong with the change, sometimes there will be further inquiries. But if a client, as an example, were to inform us that as an aged pensioner his income went over that $40 limit and there was a requirement for a reduction in the pension entitlement, then that reduction would occur. If there were some reason to suspect, a further investigation would take place.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. Is the Minister aware of claims made in Tuesday's West Australian that two-thirds of proposals to develop tree plantations in Western Australia failed this year because investors are not convinced of the scheme's financial benefits? Does the Minister agree with this claim? If so, what does the Minister think of the solutions proposed in the article: firstly, to establish a reafforestation board to promote and regulate the industry and, secondly, to make tax concessions available to attract superannuation funds and small private investors?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did briefly see the article referred to by Senator Beahan. While I have no objection at all-in fact, it may well play a positive role-to establishing a board to encourage investment in Australian hardwood plantations, when I first read the article I took it on its face to be some sort of plea for a taxation break rather than something designed in the interests of promoting plantations directly.

ANSWER.PARA: I cannot comment on the validity of the claims that have been made; that is, that there is not sufficient investment in plantations as such. I do not know which plantations were referred to in the article as the ones that had not succeeded. I do not know whether they did not succeed because people did not want to invest in them, they were not properly promoted or marketed, or their management was not regarded by would-be investors as being sound. Not knowing any of those things, it is inappropriate for me to comment on the conclusions drawn by the article: that a lack of taxation benefits is in itself a reason why people do not invest, or that their fear of not getting a significant return on their investment is a reason why they do not invest.

I say that because I know that in Western Australia there are commercially successful Australian hardwood plantations. I know of one scheme run by Bunnings, a major timber company in Western Australia, called a trees on farmland proposal by which that company agrees with farmers to utilise marginal farmland for plantation forestry and promises to buy back matured trees after a given number of years at a guaranteed rate. I understand that scheme operates reasonably successfully.

I know of a scheme, too, that the Western Australian Government was involved in promoting called the tree trust proposal, which was aimed at afforestating areas of the Darling Escarpment to help with soil and salinity problems-land degradation problems-and, as well, supply the timber industry with a forestry resource.

The National Plantations Advisory Committee, which is a committee set up within the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, is investigating all factors associated with the promotion of plantations, and will soon be offering the Government advice on a national plantation strategy to encourage their development. The question of taxation concessions has been raised in its consideration and doubtless the Committee will report on it.

I think there is a real interest these days in timber industries and companies exploiting the possibilities for the development of Australian hardwood plantations in order to obtain a secure resource for their future needs, and to overcome doubts or concerns about the availability of natural forestry resources. I will do whatever I can to encourage, on a commercial basis, the development of those plantations to meet the timber industry's future needs. I think that if they are properly managed they can be very good investments.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to comments made by the Minister and reported in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald in which the Minister asserted that people in need had not yet been harmed by the cuts totalling some $8 billion to the Government's social security budget. Does the Minister really believe that no Australian in need has been adversely affected by the Government's cuts so far to social security? Secondly, is the Minister not aware of the enormous burden being placed on the non-government agencies throughout Australia as they try desperately to deal with the increasing number of people living on the streets, in need of food, clothing, financial advice, marriage counselling, et cetera? Finally, is the Minister not aware that his so-called tightening of the rules and targeting of benefits puts so many hurdles in the way of those in our society least able to cope with the complexities that he has now built into the system; that there are criteria other than virtual destitution for success in negotiating the maze, and that these criteria include a high level of literacy skills, numeracy skills, a very good measure of self-confidence, a high level of negotiating skills and, particularly in the case of the young homeless, a personal advocate to assist them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I totally reject the last part of Senator Lees' question. She calls it `negotiating the maze'. I really do not believe that Australians will accept the continued payment of unemployment benefits to people if they are not making some efforts to get a job, or if they are not undergoing some training. The Government undertakes special programs for people to make sure they get some training. The heart of the Government's philosophy of targeting is to make sure that unemployment benefits do not become permanent payments; to try to give people some opportunity to gain employment. I think that is a laudable objective. The Government's introduction of those targeting measures-including the measures to help with training, and activity tests to ensure that people are actually out there in the marketplace having a go-is the kind of measure that Australians would expect from the Government as a minimum.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not think we have adopted a policy that says: `If you are not literate and you are not numerate, and you cannot get a job, we will not pay you the benefit'. The policies are designed to make sure that if people have weaknesses in terms of skills, the Government helps them to improve the skills and, as a result of that, at least attempts some form of monitoring of people's efforts to use those skills to get jobs. But the payments do not cease if people cannot get a job. Provided people are honouring the obligation to try, the payments continue; so I reject the last part of the question.

As to the first part-that no Australian in need has been affected-I guess it will always come down to a definition of need, to what it is. I suppose we could all have an argument and say that we would like to see all those on incomes of less than $30,000 given more because they will have some needs. I guess that everyone, even those on higher incomes, considers that he or she has needs. The Government's responsibility, however, cannot be directed to all of them but must be directed to those at the very bottom end of the scale.

What we have tried to do is eliminate some forms of middle-class welfare where people are on what we would consider to be reasonable incomes and do not actually need it, and make sure that we have maintained, and in many cases increased, with measures such as the family allowance supplement being paid to low income families, welfare to those who are most in need. To have been able to do that at a time when it has been necessary to cut Government expenditure has been one of the great achievements of the Hawke Government. Had we not done that, had we adopted the cut $3 billion approach, the only way to do that would have been to hack into those at the bottom end of the scale, and the Government just will not be in that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I reject the idea that we are talking only about unemployment beneficiaries. There is a wide variety of people in need on the streets in Australia, not just the many people who are unable to get a job as the market for jobs gets worse and worse. The Minister neglected the second part of my question, which was regarding the non-government agencies. To give just one example of how bad it is, the Hutt Street Centre in Adelaide in the last full year dealt with--
—Order! Senator Lees, you have to ask a question.
—Fine. I just ask the Minister, therefore, again to address the second part of my question, regarding non-government agencies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will do that, but I point out to all honourable senators that one of the problems for Ministers in answering questions is that these days they are customarily multifaceted. If one is asked a whole series of questions it is very hard to contain oneself to a short period in seeking to answer them all. When one is asked a question with four or five parts, as is normal, it is very difficult to contain the length of the answer. I hope that we can get from honourable senators some shortening of their questions. Then they might get answers to what they have asked.

ANSWER.PARA: I am asked about the non-government agencies. Of course, there is a big burden on non-government agencies. That has never been denied. Unfortunately, particularly with family break-up and some of the worst reasons for it, we have seen very heavy burdens placed upon non-government agencies. I do not believe that, in a society where that kind of break-up has been increasing, any government can promise that there will not be burdens placed on non-government agencies. We are attempting to make sure that the longer term needs of these people are worked out and, in so far as it is possible, to help them with their short term needs. There are provisions for those in desperate need, but there will be some who slip through the Government net and they, of course, will have to rely upon non-government agencies. I do not think any government has ever been able to stop that; I do not know of any government in the world that has stopped it. I just believe that this Government throughout its 7 1/2 years has maintained as its highest priority getting help to those in need, and being able to do it in times of cuts to government expenditure has been, I think, an extraordinary achievement.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I ask the Minister: What is being done to inform and educate migrants with non-English-speaking backgrounds about their rights as consumers and the problems that they may face?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Aulich and other senators will be interested to know that the Government is implementing an education program for ethnic communities which is aimed at those people with poor or no English skills. It seeks to provide them with information to which the rest of the community has access, because its aim is to ensure equity in consumer protection for all Australians.

ANSWER.PARA: Recently a survey was done in relation to three communities: the Greek-speaking, Arabic-speaking-mainly Lebanese- and the Vietnamese communities. It showed that many of these communities were experiencing difficulties in asserting and ensuring their rights in relation to their role in our society as consumers. This was particularly the case, for example, in relation to the purchase of a car, which is a fundamental necessity when the move is made to employment or just to take part in the ordinary social life of our community. House repairs was also another area of great concern. In fact, in the review of the Vietnamese community some were said to be so despondent, and even suicidal, because of their inability to assert their rights that they were feeling extremely isolated in not being able to insist on those matters to do with warranties and their entitlements as consumers which we all take for granted, if we have the capacity in English to make our protest and vindicate our rights.

As a result, only last week in both Sydney and Melbourne I was able to launch campaigns for those three communities as a precursor to a wider campaign among other language groups in our community to enable people to be informed of their rights as consumers and to point them in the direction of those agencies where they might get assistance to help vindicate those rights. Indeed, I believe that the attendance of community representatives at those launches indicated their very real concern and appreciation for this campaign, which will largely be undertaken through the media-the electronic media, the radio in particular, the Special Broadcasting Service and other ethnic affairs and public affairs radio services.

I believe that together with the use of the ethnic print media we will be able to get the message across and enable these fellow Australians to talk about their rights, to become aware of their rights and to assert those rights in the same way as do other Australians in our community.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is it a fact that some women who previously received regular maintenance payments are now having to wait up to three months while the Government sits on their money? Can the Minister please explain why the delays under the child support scheme have apparently gone from bad to worse under his stewardship?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The average delay is now, I think, down to eight weeks. By the end of Question Time I shall inform honourable senators of the exact position, but that is my memory of it. As I think all honourable senators will recall, in answer to questions in the Senate on this initiative some time ago, I think in the first session of this year, I explained that the setting up of the child support agency was within the Australian Taxation Office. It must be remembered that I am not responsible there. It is within the Taxation Office and not my Department, but I am answering the question because it is important. In setting up that agency, the Government certainly underestimated the extraordinary response that we would have to it. That being the case, it simply did not have enough people. So the Government announced that it would be examining the needs of that agency.

ANSWER.PARA: The examination was conducted and we made an announcement of a very substantial increase in its resources. Therefore, the delays have come down to eight weeks from very much higher figures, and by the end of the year they will come down much further still as all those new people are hired, trained and come on stream. The Government was aware of this problem some time ago and it has taken a series of steps which are proving to be very successful in eliminating those delays. It should be noted that the introduction of that scheme has meant that many more sole parents are now receiving some support from non-custodial parents that simply was not there before.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. What I asked the Minister was why it had gone up. He is telling me that it is coming down. For people who were getting regular payments it has now gone up to three months; they were getting regular payments. Can the Minister please make that inquiry as to why people who had been getting regular payments are now not getting the regular ones but the time has increased?

—I think the assertion that Senator Walters is making is certainly not generally applicable. It is wrong to suggest that it could be. It may be the case that in some particular circumstances it is happening, and I will inquire from the Department as to what those circumstances might be.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery on my right of the Joint Secretaries of the Anzac Parliamentary Group at Westminster, Mr Neil Hamilton, MP, and Mr Robin Corbett, MP. On behalf of all honourable senators I welcome you to the Senate and trust that your visit to Australia will be both informative and enjoyable.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —At the same time I would also draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery on my left of a parliamentary delegation from the Parliament of Vanuatu led by the Speaker, the Hon. O.M. Tahi, MP. On behalf of honourable senators I welcome you to the Senate and trust also that your visit to Australia will be both informative and enjoyable. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I propose to invite Mr Speaker Tahi to take a seat on the floor of the Senate.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Speaker Tahi thereupon entered the chamber, and was seated accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address a question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Does the Government consider that the settlements reached in metals, in building, in transport and yesterday in oil are consistent with accord mark 6? If so, when are the results of those negotiations likely to flow to others? Would the Minister agree that, prior to the election, expectation was built up amongst worker voters that the accord would deliver benefits to all, including those who rely on the decisions of the Industrial Relations Commission and the various State industrial tribunals? Finally, could the Minister confirm that accord mark 6 said that the focal point of the wage system must continue to be the national wage case and that, in addition, it was considered that the national wage case would be in September of this year? That has not occurred. When does he expect that the national wage case will take place?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that settlements have occurred in the building, transport and oil industries. My advice is that there is no settlement in the metals industry and that negotiations are proceeding. In fact, this week there was scheduled to be a national 24-hour strike by metal workers. That strike was called off because of discussions between the Metal Trades Industry Association and the Metal Trades Federation of Unions, which met with the MTIA on Monday. While I have no progress report as to how those negotiations are proceeding, I have an optimistic expectation that they might be concluded without further disputation.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Harradine also asked me whether these settlements conform with the provisions of the accord mark VI. The provisions of accord mark VI are, of course, for the percentage increase in the September quarter consumer price index to be reflected in a percentage increase in all wages; for, six months later, a $12 per week wage increase to be paid; for a 3 per cent increase in superannuation to be allocated, commencing in annual instalments of one per cent from May next year; and, in the case of the public sector, for there to be a recognition of market rates adjustments in public sector wages.

Also within the framework of accord mark VI, we have recognised a need to decentralise wage fixing from a highly centralised system to some extent to the enterprise levels and approved that there be framework negotiations within industries to set up frameworks for enterprise negotiations on achieved productivity and profitability in those enterprises and on the understanding that there be no double-counting of increases awarded at that level with increases that are awarded at the national level.

I cannot comment on the detail of the negotiations in the sectors in which there have been settlements. I think it is more appropriate that the national wage case bench do that, because the accord contemplates that the national wage case bench would set down the guidelines for that enterprise level bargaining. Until the bench meets, hears submissions and makes a determination, it is inappropriate for me to say whether those settlements conform with guidelines it is yet to proclaim.

Senator Harradine also asked when the national wage case hearing will commence. I agree that normally it would have proceeded in September. The Australian Council of Trade Unions, the normal applicant, decided not to apply for a hearing then but to support negotiations, as the ACTU terms it, in the field. While it is not unusual for there to be direct negotiations, if I am asked to speculate-it is only an opinion, and an opinion only as an observer of industrial relations-I would say that if there was a settlement in the metals area, it is probably likely then that there would be an application for a national wage case hearing based on settlements in other sectors. I would then anticipate that the national wage case bench would consider accord mark VI and decide whether to endorse it and whether to name an operative date for the increases that have been agreed in all of the other sectors Senator Harradine has referred to, bearing in mind always that there have been agreements to increases but no operative date set for those increases. The operative date has been reserved for the national wage case bench to decide. I think that just about covers this matter, because once the national wage case bench makes the decision, clearly it will be a decision which varies all awards elsewhere in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. Is it a fact that where the Social Security Appeals Tribunal (SSAT) finds against the Minister's Department, it is the Department's policy not to comply with such decision pending an appeal or a stay of proceedings? Has the Minister been consulted in relation to this approach and does he agree with it?

—It is certainly normal across a range of legal institutions that where appeals are on, nothing changes. We do not, as a matter of policy in the Department, however, appeal too many. There are not all that many findings against the Department at the SSAT and when they come, the Department, naturally enough, will be reluctant to seek to overturn the jury's verdict, so to speak. If the Department were to believe that the decision had very significant implications, especially those decisions which set precedents, the Department will seek to appeal. On those occasions I would have to say that, while I do not make that decision and it is made by the Department, I have not yet had brought to my attention any allegation that that has been done capriciously. It has only been done when the Department has regarded a dangerous precedent possibly being set.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware that a war veteran who loses his or her entitlement for free veterans medical treatment due to a change in income may be disadvantaged by failing to qualify for private health insurance for pre-existing medical conditions? Will the Government give consideration to waiving the pre-existing condition rule or extending free medical benefits to cover those veterans for the 12-month qualifying period required by private health insurers for pre-existing medical conditions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been able to get some information from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, which I will relay to the Senate. With the introduction of Medicare, the previous special provisions that applied to veterans joining health funds were no longer required. Under those provisions veterans joining health funds shortly after losing repatriation benefits were exempt from the pre-existing rules for basic hospital and medical care.

ANSWER.PARA: Under Medicare all Australians are entitled to receive medical and hospital care, irrespective of income. Therefore, any veteran who loses repatriation treatment benefits because of an increase in income is still entitled to be treated under Medicare arrangements. I emphasise that the repatriation arrangements provide comprehensive health care for the treatment of all war caused conditions regardless of the veteran's income.

Rules governing health insurance come within the community services and health portfolio. I understand that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs has referred this matter to the Minister responsible for that portfolio.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. In Estimates Committee C on 18 September, Senator Richardson agreed or advised that he was awaiting a report from the receiver-manager of Associated Plywoods Sales (APS) at Ravenshoe. I ask the Minister: Did the Government receive the report from the receiver manager on 15 September, as alleged in the 7.30 Report on 25 September 1990? Will the Minister table the report in the Senate? Thirdly, does the report identify whether the $7.6m, made available to APS by the Commonwealth, was used in accordance with the agreement the Commonwealth had with the company, or whether fraud was involved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not certain of what was reported on the 7.30 Report, so I cannot comment. I do have some information supplied to me from the Minister, and I am happy to share that with the Senate. The Minister did write to the receiver manager on 19 June and on 14 September seeking details of how the Commonwealth assistance had been used. I am not aware that any response has been supplied to the Minister since then. I will certainly check that out for the honourable senator and if we have a report then I will let him know. But monitoring of the sawmill's operation prior to that company going into receivership found that all the conditions which the Commonwealth had put on it had been met. That makes it pretty difficult for the Commonwealth to do anything about it. It is only since the company went into receivership that we have had the problem.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister has made several attempts to find details of what happened to the Commonwealth's assistance money. After Question Time I will ask the Minister whether he has had a reply and I will try to provide the honourable senator with that reply tomorrow.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is it in accordance with the Government's vision for the amalgamation of organisations that professional bodies such as the Association of Professional Engineers Australia, the Association of Professional Scientists Australia and the Association of Architects of Australia amalgamate according to professional disciplines and not according to industries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's vision in industrial relations is quite far-reaching. Senator Cooney is quite right to describe it thus.
—It is over the horizon.

—And over the horizon indeed, as Senator Watson says. The question relates to the potential amalgamation of three organisations representing employees who are professional people; that is engineers, scientists and architects. The Government's vision in terms of union amalgamation is to encourage union amalgamation along industry lines rather than along professional or, if one wishes to term it from a tradesman's point of view, a craft line, as this type of amalgamation would seem to contemplate.

ANSWER.PARA: But the primary focus of our vision is to encourage there to be one bargaining unit or one organisation in the workplace to bargain on behalf of all employees in the workplace. I can only trust that if these organisations were to amalgamate, that would be a stepping stone which would be a more coherent industry focus to occur. However, I think it is inappropriate for me to make any further remarks about the potential amalgamation of these organisations. The Association of Professional Engineers Australia and the Association of Professional Scientists Australia are two organisations registered in the Federal Industrial Relations Commission. They have jointly filed an application for their amalgamation to be approved by the Commission. Since that matter is proceeding, it is inappropriate for me to enlarge further on the merits of their particular claim.

The Association of Architects of Australia, the third organisation mentioned by Senator Cooney, is not a registered industrial organisation within the meaning of the Act and, therefore, could not be embraced in an amalgamation of registered organisations unless it sought to be registered in its own right or unless, with its consent, the two aforementioned organisations decided to enlarge their constitutions and had that recognised by the Commission to incorporate them in an amalgamation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. With respect to the three Royal Australian Navy ships operating in the Gulf region, have there been any delays or deficiencies in replenishment of the quantities requested by the ships of food, fuel and other essential supplies?

—There is nothing in the brief supplied to me by Defence to suggest that there are any deficiencies, but I will make some inquiries with the Department and attempt to give the honourable senator an answer, which I suspect will not be until tomorrow.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CAPE YORK: DEVELOPMENT OF SPACE BASE

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, who is having a quiet time today, to a statement by the Queensland Premier, Mr Wayne Goss, in the Brisbane Courier-Mail of Tuesday last, that the joint FederalState land use study of the Cape York area would not stand in the way of any potential development of a space base. I ask the Minister: Firstly, what is the Federal Government's view of the present status of the land use study; secondly, does the Minister support the action of the Queensland Premier in breaking yet another promise-that is, the Queensland Australian Labor Party's promise of a moratorium on development in the Cape York area while the study was under way; and, thirdly, what is the point of a jointly funded study whose outcome is pre-empted by the Queensland Premier?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the jointly funded study proposal was for the whole of Cape York. The proposed spaceport is in a site which represents a very small proportion of Cape York and has to be subject to a full environmental impact statement and study. I was not familiar with the Premier's utterance on this matter, but presumably in due course I will hear from some source other than the Brisbane Courier-Mail.

ANSWER.PARA: However, let me say that there are other inhibitors to the development of the spaceport which are far larger than the environmental problem and the possible concerns about the land use study. I will check, as far as I can, with the Queensland Government to find out precisely what was envisaged by the Premier when he made the statement. But I remind honourable senators that the spaceport has to go through a whole list of environmental procedures before it can proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to an article in the Canadian newspaper the Toronto Star, quoted in today's Daily Telegraph Mirror, by Professor Hermann Buhl, head of medical research at the Leipzig Institute of Sport, alleging that East Germany's official sports training program included use of anabolic steroids for 20 years and that a monitoring system ensured athletes were not caught by drug tests. I ask the Minister for an unequivocal assurance that no East German sports coaches who participated in this organised program of cheating through performance enhancing drugs have been, or will be, used by the Australian Institute of Sport or any other government-funded body in the sports arena. What assurances do we have that East German sports coaches already here did not participate in this program of authorised poisoning of young athletes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not regularly read Toronto's newspapers.
—Why not?
—I have a few other things to do. This morning, I have to concede, I have not read any newspapers; I was a little busy.
—It would fool you.

—Anything would fool Senator Alston. I will look at what he says Professor Buhl has said. Nonetheless, I make the general point that because there is a very broad statement from someone that anabolic steroids were used widely in East Germany for 20 years, that does not mean that every single athlete in East Germany used them for 20 years; nor does it mean that every single coach used them for 20 years.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator has an unequivocal assurance that if the Australian Government were to receive information that a coach had been participating in the use of those drugs for any length of time, or at all, we would not want to use that coach. I do not think I would need to consult with the Minister for Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to give that undertaking.

The Government has taken a very hard line against the poisoning of young athletes, as the honourable senator so correctly put it, but I am not aware of any evidence to suggest that any coach we have ever used or might use from East Germany has been involved. I will ask Mrs Kelly to check with the Australian Institute of Sport and the Australian Sports Commission to see whether there is any evidence available. As I said, without consulting I can give an undertaking that we will certainly not be using a coach who has been involved in anabolic steroids.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What action has the Government taken to follow up the disturbing allegations about human rights abuses in Tibet? What has been the response of the Chinese Government to any such representations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McMullan gave me some notice of this question. It is not a matter on which I am an instant expert, but I was able to obtain some information relating to the point of his question. There have been media reports, of course, that the Chinese authorities contrived a riot in Lhasa in March this year which led to the killing of some 450 Tibetans and the disappearance of a further 354 people. There were reports quoted in the Sydney Morning Herald on 10 October, sourced from something called the Tibet Information Network, that the Chinese authorities quashed demonstrations in Lhasa on three dates in September 1990.

ANSWER.PARA: On 23 May this year the Asia Forum for Tibet, a Hong Kong based human rights information group, alleged that during the six months prior to 1 May 1990 up to 2,000 people were executed in Tibet. On 29 May 1990 a report by the United States based human rights monitoring organisation, Asia Watch, also made serious allegations concerning human rights violations in Tibet.

I am unable to verify these claims, but the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has asked the Australian Embassy in Beijing to look into this matter and, if true, human rights abuses of this scale would be a matter of the gravest concern to this Government. I must say that on 1 May 1990, when there was a lifting of martial law and reported easings on restrictions of travel by foreigners to Tibet, the Government welcomed that fact but took the view that the measures did not go far enough because there were still indications of repressive behaviour in Tibet by the Chinese authorities.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, has indicated that the Government has continued to convey to China our deep concern over human rights issues in Tibet. In July 1988, Mr Hayden raised the issue of human rights in Tibet with senior Chinese leaders. On 21 November 1989 the Embassy made representations on behalf of a Tibetan prisoner of conscience and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has raised Australia's concerns three times: with the Foreign Minister, Mr Chee-en Chee Chen in July 1988 at the Paris Conference; in October 1989 at meetings in New York; and with the Minister for Metallurgical Industry, Mr Qi Yuanjing, in Canberra on 9 May 1990. Concerns were also raised with the Chinese Vice-Foreign Minister.

Human rights issues were again raised during Dr Blewett's visits to China in early September when he sought responses from the Chinese Government on numerous cases of alleged human rights abuses. We have not had a response to those requests by Dr Blewett.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was that?

—Dr Blewett. I know that this is a matter of great interest to Opposition senators. We shall continue to pursue these cases in the hope that China eventually may be more open in responding to questions about its human rights records, particularly now that it is a member of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights.

—Senator Short recently asked me a question on the Melbourne Olympic bid. I do not propose to answer that question in detail, except to say that the matter has been dealt with in the House of Representatives. The Government, in accordance with long accepted practice on Cabinet documents and correspondence with Premiers, will not table those documents. On 9 October in the House of Representatives the Prime Minister declined to do this. I repeat that statement made by the Prime Minister.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 October, Senator Spindler asked me a question, as Minister representing the Treasurer, relating to the Prices Surveillance Authority Act. I have been provided with an answer by the Treasurer. I seek leave to have that answer incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The reply read as follows-

(1) Under the Administration Arrangement Orders the Prices Surveillance Act falls under the responsibility of the Treasurer. Accordingly, in respect of that Act, the `Minister' is the Treasurer or a Minister delegated by the Treasurer.

The Treasurer has delegated the Honourable Simon Crean, MP, Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer, to act on his behalf in respect of matters relating to the Prices Surveillance Act.
(2) Under section 18 (1) of the Prices Surveillance Act 1983 the Minister may:
(a) require the Authority to hold an inquiry into a specified matter or specified matters; or
(b) approve the holding by the Authority of an inquiry into a specified matter or matters.

(3) Parliamentarians or members of the public can make suggestions to the Treasurer, Minister Assisting the Treasurer or the Prices Surveillance Authority on possible matters for public inquiry. However, the decision as to whether to hold a particular inquiry or not is one for the Treasurer or his delegate to make.

(4) The Government has no intention of amending the legislation covering the Prices Surveillance Authority so that a particular matter can be referred direct to the Prices Surveillance Authority by either House of Parliament.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL AUSTRALIA BANK LTD: REMARKS BY TREASURER

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 September, Senator Short asked me a question, as Minister representing the Treasurer, concerning the National Australia Bank Ltd. It related to the issue of whether, at any time, that bank was technically insolvent. The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question.

ANSWER.PARA: As indicated in the House of Representatives on 20 September 1990, the Treasurer is prepared to accept Mr Clark's assurance that the National Australia Savings Bank was not technically insolvent in 1986. However, he said that its home lending was unprofitable and that its loan book was becoming unviable.
There is some other supplementary material in that answer, but I will not provide it unless Senator Short wants to seek further information at a later stage.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Powell asked me a question about Palestinian demonstrators. I seek leave to have a somewhat lengthy, up-to-date answer to that question incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The reply read as follows-

Yesterday Senator Powell asked several questions in relation to the deaths of more than 20 Palestinian demonstrators in East Jerusalem on 8 October. I took some aspects of these questions on notice and now provide detailed responses.

Senator Powell asked why is it consistent to suspend ministerial contact with the Palestine Liberation Organisation over its position on Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, while maintaining ministerial contact with the Israeli Government, in view of these killings and the systematic denial of basic rights to Palestinians in the occupied territories.

The Prime Minister made clear in a parliamentary answer on 22 August that Australia has been prepared to maintain a high level dialogue with the PLO when in our judgment that would contribute directly and constructively to the achievement of peace in the Middle East. The Prime Minister also made clear that were the PLO to undertake specific action, and in particular terrorist action, in support of Iraq this would obviously lead to an immediate reconsideration of our attitude to it. We do not rule out ministerial level dialogue with PLO officials if that might contribute to peace, but we have no plans for such meetings for the foreseeable future.

Senator Powell asked does the Government accept that a failure by the United Nations Security Council to act decisively on the situation on the occupied territories will greatly undermine the credibility built up by the Council in its concerted response to Iraq's invasion.

The Government has made clear that there can be no linkage between the resolution of the Gulf crisis and the resolution of the Palestinian issue. The requirements for a resolution of the Gulf crisis are clearly stated in the United Nations Security Council resolutions:
The unconditional withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait;
The restoration of the legitimate Government of Kuwait;
The departure of all foreign nationals who wish to leave Iraq and Kuwait.

However, as United States Secretary of State Baker has said, and as Senator Evans noted on 17 September, an appropriate resolution of the Gulf conflict could be used as a 'spring board' for the achievement of more satisfactory security arrangements in the region, and indeed for the negotiation and resolution of such deep and bitter conflicts as the Arab-Israeli dispute. The Security Council is still considering its response to the tragic incident in East Jerusalem on 8 October.

Senator Powell asked whether the Government will convey to the Bush Administration the need for such action-that is, decisive action following the deaths of Palestinian demonstrators in East Jerusalem on 8 October-including the sending of a UN mission to the occupied territories.

The United States itself is obviously seized of the importance of international action in response to this week's incident. The United States has, in fact, sponsored a resolution which envisages a UN mission to investigate the incident.
Senator Powell asked whether the Government will resume ministerial contact with the PLO. This question is covered by my response to Senator Powell's first question.

In conclusion, Australia's policy towards the Middle East is based on two main premises: we are committed to Israel's right to exist within secure and recognised boundaries; we recognise the right of self-determination for the Palestinian people, including their right, if they so choose, to independence and the possibility of their own independent state.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in Question Time Senator Crane asked me a question in which he alleged, inter alia, that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy had selectively released the business plan for the Australian Wool Corporation. I can now add to my answer.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Wool Corporation's business plan was prepared at the request of the Government. It represents the strategies which the Corporation proposes to implement as its response to the events in the wool market for the first three months of 1990-91. The business plan is a commercial in-confidence document and was considered by Cabinet on Monday of this week. As a result of Cabinet's consideration of the plan, certain aspects relating to the legislative changes have been announced by Mr Kerin. However, in relation to other elements of the plan, it is the prerogative of the Australian Wool Corporation to decide whether to release this information. As it contains detailed market analysis information, it is questionable whether the Australian Wool Corporation would consider releasing the plan to the public.
I conclude by saying that, in my view, it is also questionable whether it is in the public interest for it so to do.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston asked me a question during Question Time on the sending out of a form. I have a response. Family allowances are payable under the Social Security Act on a calendar year basis. To be in a position to pay eligible families from the beginning of the 1991 entitlement year all reviews need to be completed by the middle of December 1990. To meet this deadline it is necessary to send out family allowance review forms by the end of September to enable sufficient time for return of forms and for processing by the Department of almost two million family allowance payments.

ANSWER.PARA: In the Budget it was announced that the Government proposed to legislate for an assets test to be effective for family allowance from 1 January 1991. The options for the Department were: firstly, to send out forms with no reference to an assets test so that when the assets test legislation was passed a further form would have to be sent to family allowance recipients at a cost of $400,000 in postage alone; or, secondly, to send out forms with a question on the proposed assets test at no additional cost to taxpayers and with considerable administrative savings.

In the latter case, if legislation was not passed those who indicated that they have affecting assets are easily identified and can be contacted to ensure family allowance is paid if they meet the income test. The mailing cost of this step, if it were necessary, would be about $33,000.

The Department has attempted to save the Commonwealth several hundred thousands of dollars. Given the question in the Senate this week about the expenditure of $800, I think that is not unreasonable. I do, however, believe that there should have been a reference to the fact that legislation was not passed. I will certainly be informing the Department that I will insist on that reference at any future time when it seeks, for the right reasons, to have government money saved but fails to notify people that the legislation has not yet been passed.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON ENVIRONMENT, RECREATION AND THE ARTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On 19 May 1988, the Senate resolved that the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts: the use by Australian sportsmen and sportswomen of performance enhancing drugs and the role played by Commonwealth agencies.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has since tabled an interim report on 14 June 1989 and a second report on 24 May 1990 concerning drugs in sport. The Committee now wishes to advise the Senate that at a private meeting on 18 September 1990 it was resolved that the Committee regards its second report on drugs in sport as the final report on that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-To the extent that Senator Crowley has made reference to the resolution of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, I put on the record that that resolution was not unanimous and did not have the support of slightly less than half the members of that particular Standing Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view, the Committee, under the chairmanship of then Senator John Black, did quite invaluable work with the terms of reference it undertook. Other than the Dubin Canadian inquiry that was set up by the Canadian Government following the Ben Johnson incident at the Seoul Games, there has been no report of the nature of the interim report and the second report that were tabled in the Senate as a result of the endeavours of that Committee. As a modest member of that Committee, it is my view that the contribution that that Committee has made has been quite invaluable in terms of probing some of the areas in sport in Australia, particularly relating to drug use.

It has not always been a popular committee, least of all amongst those who have most to lose as a result of its revelations. It has been required to confront the degree of use and abuse of drugs in sport in Australia, not only at elite level but even down to those who indulge themselves in sport at a social level at the weekends. The revelations have not been particularly attractive. They show that Australia is in main stream in terms of the level of abuse, and they demonstrate that a very significant number of elite sportsmen and sportswomen who have represented this country have, at one time or another, sought to enhance their performances by the use of performance enhancing drugs.

We have looked to see what level of collusion and encouragement has been given to those athletes by their coaches, and what level of ignorance has been demonstrated by the administrators and sporting officials-the blazer brigade, as they are commonly known. It has not been a particularly attractive revelation. It seems to me that the vast majority of senior administrators have been more concerned to ensure that there is no embarrassment to sport in Australia by the detection of the use of drugs by athletes, rather than to exhibit a real, deep concern about the matter and a commitment to root out the evils of cheating in sport and the disgrace which that brings to the sport and, perhaps, consequentially, to the country that is represented.

We have had to look at the diligence of successive governments in pursuit of this problem. We have focused to a degree on the Australia Institute of Sport as a result of evidence that has been given to us. It is no modest disappointment to me to see the number of athletes that came before us who, under oath, admitted to the use of drugs while being scholarship-holders at the Institute of Sport. Of course, that caused us to look at the efficacy of the drug testing regime at the institute. We were sad to discover that perhaps 90 per cent of the tests were found to be, by any measure, invalid.

I believe that we have, at least, put the issue on the agenda and forced those who are responsible to deal with it. For my part, I have been particularly encouraged by the enthusiasm and commitment of officials in professional sport to deal with the problem. We have seen it with rugby league in Sydney, where officials have been quite unrelenting in their pursuit of a clean sport, to the extent that they have even tested for recreational drugs. I believe they have done it because they want a good, clean, even playing field for their sport. I have not detected the same degree of enthusiasm about this matter among officials associated with what used to be described as amateur sport. They seem to me to be more concerned that things look right. We discovered that the Australian Olympic Federation gave our athletes six months notice before the Seoul Olympics that they were going to be tested, and that is hardly a way to ensure that the cheats get caught. What it does is give them fair notice that if they do not get off the gear-as it is called-they will get caught. For anabolic steroids, a fortnight is enough notice. When the pentathlete Alex Watson was detected as having used a drug- the one person who has been unfairly and harshly treated-they were so embarrassed with him that they were determined to bury him. Their attitude towards him was not one of seeking to clean up the problem; it was one of seeking to bury it.

There are a number of other areas that the Committee ought to be probing. It is a question of educating the community. There is an abysmal lack of knowledge and understanding of the diabolical effect that anabolic steroids and other performance enhancing drugs can have on the human body.

In many cases where it is understood, elite sports men and women are saying that they would still risk death with that knowledge if it meant the prospect of winning a gold medal. That is a very real challenge for any government to overcome. We have taken evidence about children as young as 12 years of age being taken to doctors by their parents for the purpose of getting a prescription for anabolic steroids. One of the evils of anabolic steroids is that they stunt growth. They close the bone ends the moment they are taken. For these children who have not even gone through puberty, it was a grave effect upon their growth.

The other important area that the Committee has not addressed is the whole philosophic question of the use of drugs in sport. Whether we are concerned about health, about an even playing field or just about cheating, there seems to be confusion. When I asked the Australian Olympic Federation what its attitude would be towards the manufacture of a synthetic drug that showed no side effects, caused no ill- health and was freely available and therefore would create an even playing field, it was confused about the question. It had not addressed it.

They are the sorts of areas that we ought to be probing. They are the sorts of areas we have to learn to understand and for which we will have to develop a philosophic framework which at least gives us a proper sense of direction so that we understand the reasons why we do not believe that we should have drugs in sport.

There are many other problems that have not been addressed. For instance, as I said yesterday, beta blockers are on the list of proscribed drugs compiled by the International Olympic Federation, yet diazepam, for instance, commonly known as valium, is not. Yet it has exactly the same effect-in a different way, as Senator Crowley would tell me but essentially the same.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very doubtful claim.

—I should be grateful for new information from Senator Crowley if I am wrong. It is a very useful drug for rifle shooters, pistol shooters or the participants in any sport that requires a steady hand and a steady mind. These drugs are intended to slow down the heart rate. Pistol shooters can actually get their heart to beat so slowly that they can discharge shots between heartbeats, which gives them a very significant advantage over the next competitor, whose heart is beating with great enthusiasm as a result of his anxiety. Yet the question has not been addressed as to why there is one on the banned list--
—There are no hearts beating with enthusiasm here at the moment.

—I do not know what contribution Senator Faulkner seeks to make to this debate but, whatever it is, under Standing Orders he should not be making it from where he is sitting at the moment. However, I am sure that anything he has to add would be invaluable to the wider community in Australia. This is a reference that we should keep under review. We ought to be able to run it parallel to any other references before the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: We all know that historically sport has been a sexy subject for governments. There are votes in it. I suppose that is legitimate. It might be offensive for some of us to have our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his obsequious way gravitating towards friendship with athletes in the hope that public adulation might rub off on him--

TALK.START.PARA: —Picture opportunities.
—Yes, picture opportunities, as he basks in the potential reflected glory of the Greg Normans of this world or the Alan Bonds of this world when they are winning the Americas Cup--
—When it suits him.

— When it suits him-invited to the Lodge for lunch as he was. I suppose that is a legitimate form of campaigning, but the currency is somewhat devalued when elite sports men and women are found to be cheating. The gloss goes off the votes. It is the sort of item one really does not like to know about. It takes some of the glory away from the Prime Minister being at the Olympic Games or the Commonwealth Games if it is found that there is a problem with drugs in sport in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sad to draw the conclusion, without reflecting on any individual vote, that the Government is very happy to have this subject off the agenda for all the wrong reasons. But I hope that this Government will continue to pursue the recommendations that we have made. I understand that at some time in the dim distant future-and Senator Richardson might be able to enlighten me-legislation will be introduced to pick up a number of the Committee's recommendations. The sooner that that is done, the sooner the integrity of the various agencies which will be caught up in it will be enhanced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a brief statement.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that, at 8.30 a.m. today, Senators Alston and Coulter submitted letters in accordance with standing order 75, one proposing a matter of public importance and the other a matter of urgency. In accordance with the standing order to decide which letter should be submitted to the Senate, the President determined the matter by ballot, in the presence of representatives of Senator Alston and Senator Coulter and the Clerk of the Senate. As a result of that procedure, I now read Senator Alston's letter:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to standing order 75, I propose that the following matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, `The continuing failure of the Minister for Social Security to address the multitude of administrative problems currently besetting his Department'.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places-
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that even the Government now admits that, as a result of its failed economic policies, we have a rapidly deteriorating economy, rapidly rising rates of unemployment and increasing signs of financial hardship and social distress being inflicted on the hundreds of thousands of ordinary Australians for whom this Government professes concern. It is a matter of great regret that in that climate this country has been saddled with a Minister for Social Security who takes no interest in his portfolio, shows contempt for the economic consequences of decisions made in that area and is interested only in the politics of politics.

SPEECH.PARA: It is now just on six months since this responsibility for Social Security was foisted upon a very reluctant Minister. We all know that he drew the short straw and that Senator Robert Ray managed to pick up the plum job. Senator Richardson's line since that time has been that he has been surprised but not disappointed to have picked up Social Security. Those who follow his actions and attitudes know that it goes a bit deeper than that. We have had everything from petulant threats to resign through to yesterday's pre-emptive strike-a threat of no more cuts. He is clearly not interested in seeing the proper budgetary processes operate or indeed to participate sensibly in the economic expenditure committee with an open mind.

That is clearly indicative of the fact that Senator Richardson wants out, that he is putting the weights on the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to let him move on from this job as soon as possible. We will be coming to a deal of detail about the administrative deficiencies for which Senator Richardson ought to have been responsible, but let me point to some of the other things that he has been much more interested in doing since the Federal election.

Senator Richardson has expressed an interest in Senator Button's portfolio, if it becomes available; he has pontificated about why the Government managed to hold the green vote and why that was responsible for the election win; he has confirmed that the leadership of the Australian Labor Party is a live issue; he has said that Ministers should exercise restraint and not speak outside their portfolios, which I would have thought is the height of double standards. He attacks Senator Walsh for criticising Government decisions after leaving Cabinet. He shafted Mr Dawkins for bagging him to the media. He criticised Senator Button for speaking out against the Government. He claimed that if he had spoken out like other Ministers he would have been fired. I do not know what yesterday's effort deserved but we have not heard much from the Prime Minister on that.

He denied being involved in any attempt to oust Mr Willis from the ministry of Finance or indeed from the Cabinet, but I think Mr Willis's words on that were much more eloquent than Senator Richardson's denials. Of course, in recent times we have had these amazing little mickey mouse schemes of establishing some sort of trust arrangement to enable the proceeds of asset sales to be used for infrastructure projects. He supported, of course, the Beazley proposal on telecommunications, but unfortunately got rolled there.

TALK.START.PARA: —What?

—He supported the wrong one, of course. He supported the Beazley proposal for all the right factional reasons but for all the wrong national interest reasons. His having spent all his time in those areas, I think we can properly describe him-with thanks to Senator Peter Baume and apologies to the Mikado-as the Minister who dabbles in enthusiastic tone in every conceivable subject area and every portfolio but his own.

SPEECH.PARA: What I want to do is to actually look at some of the administrative efforts that Senator Richardson has presided over in the last six months. We heard him say today that maintenance payments under the child support scheme are now down to eight weeks. I have had recent information conveyed to my office of people who have been waiting not three months but six months. In one instance, a constituent applied to the Child Support Agency in March of 1990 and received no money or information until the day before she contacted the office of a member of parliament in sheer frustration. Then she received a letter telling her that she would not receive any maintenance for the month of July. In other words, from March to July she received not only no money but also no correspondence; and, of course, six months later she had still received no money.

In the other episode, someone who applied at the end of July, with the help of the Department of Social Security, simply received a notification that she had been put on the register on 4 September and that the first payment would come through on 7 October. I hope that Senator Richardson can explain why it takes a month between being put on the register and receiving one's first payment.

The next episode, which I am sure the Minister finds equally amusing, was the $848 worth of contracting out, and again I would have thought that that was a very serious matter. Mr Murphy said, as reported in Estimates Committee C Hansard on page 269:

I make the point that the letters which have been written in the Department, and there have been numerous drafts over the years, have been the subject of complaints by people who are representing clients. It was in order to get away from the departmental approach to writing letters of this sort that the decision was taken to go outside.

In other words, there are 16,000 employees in the Department of Social Security and none of them are capable of writing a letter, despite presumably having every opportunity to get advice from outside and to attend seminars, briefings, conferences and the like. So, rather than employing experts we have this absurd charade of contracting out. If it can be contracted out in that area, I would have thought there must be an enormous amount of other activities that could also be contracted out.

The third episode that I think is equally of concern to Senator Richardson, or ought to be, involves a decision relating to the payment of invalid pensions. My colleague Senator Herron will deal with this area in much more detail because he has a great degree of expert knowledge.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope he knows a bit more than you.

—I do not profess to be an expert in this area, and it is quite clear from Senator Richardson's actions that he would not even have the hide to claim that either. Let me just give one example that was recently relayed to me. A person who applied for an invalid pension in 1987 happened to have come to the country on a temporary visa. Three days after the visa expired, she claimed to have injured her back whilst lifting her adult son. She was then granted an invalid pension and remained on that pension for three years before the Department realised that she had never been entitled to it in the first place because she was an illegal immigrant.

SPEECH.PARA: The Department decided it would change this recipient over to special benefits. It sent a doctor to her premises on the basis that she claimed to have been bedridden.
