When she was not home, the Department decided to take some action. At that stage her son went to the office of a member of parliament and complained bitterly that she was getting a rough deal. Of course, the son complained to the wrong member of parliament. A staff member of that office rang the Department and was told:

She'll still get paid the $360 Invalid Pension benefit for the next fortnight as the computer records haven't been changed in time. Next fortnight she goes on to Special Benefits, and she will also get a $50 p.w. rent subsidy. She lives with her son in a Housing Commission low rent flat, but he claims she pays him this money.
The woman visits her country of origin regularly and her last absence from the country was for 19 months, during which time she received her invalid pension.

There are other examples that have come to my attention from officers within the Department from sheer frustration. In one instance we had information from an officer in a metropolitan regional area that at least nine transactions in three days had been processed for payment when they should have been further investigated, that there were no checks on personal data update, that many unemployment benefit forms are partially filled in and some questions referring to income are ignored, that payment is made with no follow-up interview, and even declared income is happily ignored and the computer records are often not amended for a considerable time. Again, this is a matter of great concern.
Another matter referred to me is that oft-repeated claim that people cannot get unemployment benefits unless they personally attend the Department's office and hand in the form. The form says:
You MUST return the form ON the date shown.

My information is that one suburban office has a box in which the forms can be placed. So anyone can drop a form in and there is no attempt to verify that the claimant is returning a form. The form also says:
You must get the CES to stamp the form first unless you have been told otherwise.

Again, there are some classic outs in this area. Another matter of great concern, in view of the fact that Senator Richardson conceded the other day that the amnesty had come in well below estimates, is a letter from a national amnesty coordinator writing to regional officers advising that a person suspected of having received overpayments, irrespective of whether they might be ineligible due to deliberate fraud, had been receiving forms. The letter says:

It has come to our attention that Regional Offices have been sending Amnesty Applications to clients that appear on Suspected Overpayment Facilities (SOF) listings without checking whether it is appropriate to do so in each case.
Despite that, of the estimated $55m we have only $40m. I seek leave to table the letter.
Leave granted.

The next matter of particular concern relates to Senator Richardson's answer to the Senate today about the practice of the Department in paying moneys that have been ordered to be paid by the Social Security Administrative Tribunal. The guidelines in existence make it patently clear that the Department reserves to itself the right not to pay even when it has been ordered to pay. The best that Senator Richardson could do when making a meal of the answer was to suggest that the Department does not appeal as of course; it does so only when the Department considers a dangerous precedent might be set.

The fact is that according to the guidelines which have been made available to me, the Department takes the view that it does not have to pay even if it has not appealed and even where it has not sought a stay. Even if the Department seeks a stay, it nevertheless withholds payment. In one instance brought to my attention this week payments were cut off in June this year on the basis that the recipient was not serious about looking for work. He appealed and won and it is now two months since that decision was made. Yet, he has received no money because the Department says that it is appealing. Now, the Department will seek a stay. In other words, the Department has taken it upon itself not to pay, to ignore the ruling of the Tribunal. The guidelines say:
The position appears to be that where a decision awarding payments is made by the SSAT, that decision, unless otherwise specified, comes into force on the day the decision is made-
in other words, the Department admits liability-
It creates a liability on the Secretary ... to make those payments to the claimant. If they are not made the claimant may take action in the courts to enforce that payment.

In other words, the Department can choose not to pay and then it is up to the poor unfortunate recipient to take legal action in the courts to enforce payment. That is a preposterous proposal. I hope the Minister will acknowledge the absurdity and unfairness of that arrangement.

It is clear that if that is the prevailing wisdom, the Department has lost the place. This bureaucratic zealousness sits extraordinarily against the level of over-payments that we have heard about recently, something of the order of $90m last year. The Department has waived payment of $5.8m where it says that moneys have been paid out in good faith and yet, against that background of something like $90m to $100m being paid out when it should not have been paid out, we have this penny-pinching attempt to somehow save a few extra dollars from people who have been found to be entitled to payment.

I would have thought that that would be the height of absurdity, and it is yet another example of what Senator Richardson has been missing in the last six months, and a good example of why he ought to take a lot more interest in proceedings than he has in recent times, apart from wandering around the world on unnecessary trips, talking about treaties that are entirely premature and, even in Australia, spending a lot more time doing other things.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greek and Turkish communities would be fascinated to hear about that.

—Can I tell Senator Richardson about a meeting that I attended recently with over 1,000 Greeks, a meeting chaired by Dr Xtenas of the Greek Orthodox community of Victoria. In the presence of Mr Hand, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, and Senator Bolkus, the Minister for Administrative Services- honourable senators well know that that community has been quite supportive of Labor on occasions-Dr Xtenas said that the consultation process that Senator Richardson claims has been in place, is a sham, and that Mr Hand could go back and tell him that. He said that it is just not good enough and that they were not going to put up with it any more. I am sure Senator Bolkus has told Senator Richardson about that. It is interesting to know what they think of his consultation processes.
—You ought to hear what they say about you.

—He had a lot of nice things to say that night. Members of the community were not at all impressed and did not see any need for Senator Richardson to wander off to Greece prior to these consultations having been properly concluded. I now turn to the form, and I note that at the very end of the supplementary answer that the Minister gave he acknowledged that it was improper for the Department not to have adverted to the fact that legislation has not been put in place. I ask him to advise the Senate on how many other occasions this has happened in the past, and to guarantee that it will not happen again under his tenure, because the form quite clearly says, `If the net market value of you or your partner's assets is less than $300,000, you will continue to get the family allowance'. It makes no mention at all of being contingent upon any legislation being passed.

SPEECH.PARA: The next matter I advert to is again an extraordinary episode. Senator Richardson has been pretending for months and months that there have been no administrative problems; there are no high levels of overpayment. He described $20m last year as a phenomenal track record, and generally suggested that somehow there was nothing much that could be saved. All of a sudden we now find him sticking to this figure of $400m. I would like to know where he gets it from because his Budget initiatives providing measures to improve compliance and reviews, computer matching, amnesty, accelerated claimant matching, local review teams, review of files of pensioners overseas; that seems to be it. In my calculations that totals $863m over a three-year period, which is less than $300m a year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you taking the first year as $60m or something?
—The first year is $152m. The second year is $350m. The third is $361m--
—$361, and what is the fourth?
—The fourth is $371. How does that add up to $400 a year?
— $371 is not close to $400 and neither is $360?

—This is extraordinary. Senator Richardson has never said for a moment that we will be losing $400m from year four. He has said that we are currently losing $400m a year. I would be delighted if he would clear that up for us. Another matter I want to refer to, and perhaps I will leave the details of this for a later time, is a classic example of the low morale and the administrative problems that persist in the Department. I refer to some minutes of a meeting of Department of Social Security (DSS) officers this year. One of the officers reported that the area manager had said that staff should get used to providing a lower standard of service to clients, but the other officer said in his opinion a 2 1/2 hour counter wait was of a low enough standard and there was no need to cut back further.

SPEECH.PARA: I now move on to the extraordinary behaviour of the Minister's Department in circularising all senior officers of the Department about any attempts I might make to visit regional offices. I think the matter has already been publicly ventilated, but it was forwarded to me by a bemused DSS employee who said, `Presumably area managers are considered in Canberra to be as tactless and untrustworthy as regional office managers'. I find it extraordinary that when we are supposed to be saving money all these officers are being told that there have to be at least three people present at all times and all matters have to be relayed to the Minister and the Secretary as soon as I go anywhere near a departmental office.

That is based on extraordinary sensitivity arising from an article in the Sydney Morning Herald a few months back when a regional officer of the Darlinghurst office, writing in that newspaper, said that his regional office had been paying out something of the order of $40m a year. He said that at the end of the year a balance sheet would show that it had conceived of no plan for relief of local poverty, had developed no strategy on drug or alcohol abuse, had seen a rapid decline in the available accommodation for the poor in the area, had lost 75 per cent of its staff and had ended up with a highly unskilled work force. He said it was quite clear that the Department of Social Security was unable to meet the needs of those clients and yet $1.2m was being spent on paying the officials to run that office. I would be fascinated to hear the Minister explain what steps have been taken to cure the problem at the Darlinghurst office. I hope we will not hear that it is simply a disgruntled employee because it seems to me that it is a very poignant account by an obviously concerned and dedicated insider who has proposed a number of constructive ways in which the Department might be able to better spend its resources.

I suggest that what we have here is a litany of examples of maladministration about which Senator Richardson has shown absolutely no insight and certainly no concern. We will hear a few bits of political rhetoric, but I doubt very much whether we will see any effective action. If Senator Richardson cannot stomach social security, he ought to have the courage to go and tell the Prime Minister and move on to greener pastures. But if he is to stay in this area much longer, I can assure him that we will be expecting him to lift his game.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I stand before you underwhelmed. In listening to this latest burst of rhetoric, I am disappointed on only one factor, and that is this is not a broadcast day. I only wish that we had the opportunity to let a wide audience hear what is happening today. I would like to expose Senator Alston's performance to the nation. As that opportunity today is denied to me, I will restrict myself to an exposure to only those present. I note the remark that I have engaged in petulant threats to resign. These petulant threats to resign amounted to my saying that in the course of the next five years I might get out and that is on the basis that one has been a senator for 10 years and in full time politics for more than half one's life.
—That would make it 20.

—I am 41, if one wants to be exact. I know that I look a lot older but that is because I have to put up with the likes of Senator Alston. I have said I do believe that if one wants to have a life after politics-and I certainly do-the older one gets before one leaves here, the less likely one wants it when one attempts to get a job in the real world. I can repeat to the Senate, and I hope not petulantly--
—Never petulantly.

—Petulance is not in my nature, Senator. I repeat to the Senate that at some stage in the next five years I will certainly tap the mat, and do so happily. I will stagger a few honourable senators by quoting Senator Alston's comment that Senator Ray picked up the plum job. I have not heard defence referred to before as the plum job in the Government. I will ask Senator Ray whether he would regard it as such. It is certainly not a portfolio for which I ever expressed the slightest, tiniest, teeniest desire. I doubt very much whether I will do so in the future. But of course one serves one's country in whatever way one can, and should some other greatness be thrust upon me, as always I will jump to the fore.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning to Senator Alston's attack-if that is what it can be laughingly called-the concentration of Senator Alston and the Opposition has always been, and will always be, upon the odd case that comes to light of some outrageous behaviour on the part of a social security client or social security officer. There are so many social security clients-we are looking at millions upon millions-that there will always be a fascinating case that we can point to of an overpayment or a fraud. We will never totally eliminate that from all those millions and millions of cases. However, the responsibility of administration is to make sure that those amounts are minimised. In a couple of ways that has been done and I will come to those during this contribution.

I have to say, however, on behalf of the 17,000 people who work in the Department of Social Security (DSS), that they are people who run a magnificent administration. They put in an enormous number of hours, often under great stress, and I resent any attack on them. I do not mind being fair game myself, but the only conclusion one could draw from Senator Alston's contribution was his attack upon employees as well. Those employees, I believe, do a magnificent job.

First off, let us go through what has happened in social security in recent years. We have seen phenomenal change. There has been an incredible amount of change during the last few years as during the life of the Hawke Government we have sought, for the first time in this country's history, to target welfare payments. Those advances in policy administration, in automatic data processing systems and in improving the integrity of the social security system have put us in advance of literally any other country. Judging from the number of people from other administrations around the world who are coming here to see how it is done-we are now seeing practices that we have adopted in the last few years adopted in other countries-it is obvious that informed people see Australia as a model for social security policy and administration.

Let us look at some facts. DSS makes payments to nearly 4 1/2 million people, with expenditure in 1990-91 of $23.7 billion. That is an extraordinary amount of money. It represents more than a quarter of Commonwealth outlays. Of course, funds are also spent on behalf of other agencies and countries. The DSS client-based computing systems produce over 140 million payments a year and 35 million client advices each year. In spite of those 140 million payments and more than 35 million client advices, its administrative costs amount to 3 per cent of total outlays. One wonders how many companies in private industry in Australia can boast that kind of record. It is amazing. It is a tribute, I believe, not to myself-I certainly will not claim any credit for it-but to Don Grimes and Brian Howe who, in the periods of their administration, did so much to tighten up the administration of this Department.

Not only can the Department boast that 3 per cent record in administrative costs compared with outlays, but also it has managed to deliver that service in a highly decentralised form-over 300 offices around Australia delivering a service yet keeping costs down to what they are today. That I believe is an achievement that is unmatched by any other department in this Government. I do not know of any private companies which can do as well.

One must also look at our computing network. It is virtually the largest in the country. It is an integrated network of eight large Amdahl mainframe computers; 300 Wang mini-computers; and over 15,000 work stations. In excess of 99.9 per cent of DSS pensions, benefits and allowances are paid on time. In a situation when there are millions of decisions which are appealable, there are only about 6,000 appeals to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal a year-around half the number of two years ago. Apparently, that is supposed to point to administrative problems-6,000 appeals out of millions upon millions of decisions. By the way, two-thirds of those appeals result in decisions in favour of the Department.

The reality is that the enormous majority of our client population, people who do not appeal, see this as an efficient system. Of all those millions of payments, under 100 complaints are lodged with the Ombudsman each year about the social security administration, and yet I am supposed to address massive problems. Where the hell are they? As a proportion of gross domestic product, social security outlays have declined in recent years from 7.2 per cent in 1983 to 6 per cent now while, at the same time, virtually every payment has increased in real value.

We then have to look at the management of change, and this Government has been about change. There have been over 300 major policy and administrative changes in social security since 1986 alone. There is not the slightest doubt that the integrity of the system has been enhanced substantially because of the tightening of proof of identity, the requirement for personal lodgment of forms, the introduction of mobile review teams, automatic data processing systems, the introduction of matching of Department of Social Security data using new technology, and the tighter targeting of payments. What more can any administration be expected to do?

At the same time there has been a dramatic initiative in changing the Department of Social Security from being just a passive payment agency to being a key component in an active strategy to help people to overcome their disadvantages, become rehabilitated where necessary, or to obtain employment and be less reliant on social security in the future. This can be seen in programs such as jobs, education and training, new start, the job search allowance, child support and financial information services for pensioners.

The retirement incomes policy announced in the 1989 Budget set a new direction for Australian society, and that is what the Department has been about doing all of these years. A great tribute must be paid to my two predecessors in this portfolio. In the area of family payments, we have seen massive increases in family allowances and the introduction of the family allowance supplement. For the first time they have been targeted because we have had real tests on income and we are about to have real tests on assets. It is worth noting, especially for Senator Lees, who has a legitimate and correct concern for all of these Australians at the bottom end of the scale, that we are looking now at just on 200,000 Australian families receiving the family allowance supplement.

Obviously all of these changes-and there are just so many of them-added to the ones announced in the Budget, must impose strains on any administration. For the staff of the Department of Social Security, there is, of course, the added problem of dealing very often with people coming into the offices under stress, and that stress must transfer to those behind the counter. If one had walked into a DSS office after someone had brandished a knife one would know the kind of feelings that so many people on the staff must experience. Yet for all of that, the number of complaints against staff has dropped off dramatically because the staff is now well trained and well able to cope with all of these new strains.

I have already mentioned that I believe our staff has coped quite magnificently with all of those changes and the improvements in services to clients. At the same time as we have been coping with that, we have managed to spread the net of offices that supply those services to Australia. We now have offices right around the country. We now have a massive staff training scheme, with large increases in it announced in the course of the last few years. We have managed to improve administration and management every single year. As a result of the measures taken in this Budget, we are taking some further steps to do that once again.

With all of that splendid, marvellous record of improvements in administration, we have a matter of public importance raised by the Opposition to focus on a few minor blemishes which, as I said, can never and will never be eliminated. I cannot promise that out of millions of payments there will not be a mistake-of course there will- but what this Government is determined to do is to make sure that, where there is fraud, we find it; to make sure that, where there are overpayments, we find them and have them recovered. In the case of fraud, the Government will pursue those who have perpetrated the frauds.

When one looks at the Senate Estimates committee process, one gets a fair idea of the kind of preoccupations of members of this Opposition. They spent more time in pursuing an $848 consultancy payment than on major programs involving the expenditure of more than $20 billion. The Opposition has a fixation with the minutiae of administration. It is more concerned with its own middle-class preoccupations, about bashing sole parents, about bashing unemployment beneficiaries, and about bashing invalid pensioners, than it is in ensuring that Australia provides an adequate payment to those who are in real need, than it is with the provision of sound administration, than it is with measures to ensure that the real cheats are caught by using modern technology for matching information about recipients.

For all of that, for this accusation of my failure to deal with administrative problems, I only wish I had the time today to go through all of the interviews and press releases that have been released by Senator Alston over time. I do not have the time, but I will just go through a couple. There was an interview between Senator Alston and Sonya Voumard of the Age on 1 August. There is a great quote out of this interview showing the depth of knowledge of the shadow Minister, who gets up and criticises me today. It states:

At least 51 per cent of those clients granted the invalid pension in 1988-89 did not fulfil the requirement of 42.5 per cent impairment, as laid out in the Act. Further 16.6 per cent did not fulfil DSS' own internal directives that invalid pension beneficiaries have 30 per cent impairment. There is profound bunching around the 30 to 39 per cent category.

I assume, of course, that Senator Alston stands by all of that. Stunned silence we get from Senator Alston, not even so much as a nod. `Will I or won't I?', he thinks to himself. `Should I own up or should I not?'. The answer is, of course, that he should not. I really worry about the honourable senator First of all, there is not a mandatory requirement of 42.5 per cent impairment in the legislation. That is just plain wrong. What we do about it, I do not really know.

TALK.START.PARA: —A re-education program.

—Re-education can be pretty hard. This is a herculean task. For the most knowledgable of professors, for the very best of teachers, re-education here is just not possible. Not even being sent back to the collective would deliver anything here. I would have to say that that figure of 42.5 per cent is not used anywhere in the invalid pension provisions of the Social Security Act and there is no line of interpretation from the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or the Federal Court which supports Senator Alston's assertion that there is such a mandatory impairment threshold.
—Have you not read the Auditor-General's report?
—I will get to that later, if I have time. Senator Alston got that one wrong as well. I might hand it to one of my colleagues, just to make sure he reminds Senator Alston of where he went.
—You have not told the Auditor-General he has got it wrong.

—That is good. Senator Alston is now admitting that he believes there is a 42.5 per cent impairment threshold in the Act. Is that what he is saying? `Will I or won't I?'. Here we go again. What paragraph 27b does contain is a requirement that a person's incapacity for work must derive primarily from medical impairment. That, of course, is a qualitative judgment; it is not an impairment threshold. Senator Alston is confusing impairment and incapacity and has always seen them as synonymous. I did indicate in the Senate in the last few days where that can be different.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing to point out about that silly interview is that the DSS policy manual does not require that all claims be rejected where the claimant has less than 30 per cent impairment. Thirty per cent impairment is used as a useful rule of thumb in the interests of good administration; it has never been and certainly is not any inflexible threshold. When one looks at the huffing and puffing from Senator Alston, one is startled sometimes at the level of ignorance. I have to say, by the way, to Senator Alston that this is still a democracy and he does have a right to be ignorant. What I really wish is that he would not demonstrate that ignorance so often. Senator Alston is militantly ignorant. If I were him I would be passively ignorant. I would try to keep this a bit of a secret; I would not try to let everybody know. But occasionally he does give us the opportunity of exposing just a little bit of it-never enough, just the odd bit. Senator Alston's extraordinary efforts in trying to look at overpayments have always worried me. He never quite understood the amount of money to be recovered that went back over 20 years.

I also wonder about his understanding of the difference between what we can recover now through sending out review teams to knock on doors and discover anomalies and what we can do when new technology is available. There is obviously a difference. When new technology becomes available-as it is now-whereby we can find out what goes wrong in payments, where people are double dipping and where they are claiming are too much, we have got a duty to the Australian taxpayer to use that technology and we will live up to every inch of that duty. We are not going to walk away from it-not now and not ever.

In this whole argument I hope it is remembered that those who seek to cheat the system have these extraordinary savings, hundreds of millions of dollars, in their pockets. Senator Alston claims that he wants to knock $3 billion off government expenditure. How will he do that? He will have his hand in the wallets and pockets of every poor person in this nation. We are here to stop him ever doing that. This Government has presided over the most comprehensive evaluation of social security policies and programs ever undertaken. It has supervised vast improvements in social security programs. It has boosted the integrity of the social security system, and it has done all of this while making savings of $8 billion in total in social security since 1986-87.

One wonders what more could be expected of any of the Ministers or of anyone else involved in the administration of social security. Those 17,000 people have done a magnificent job. They deserve the praise of everyone in the Senate-not the criticism. Ministers Grimes and Howe deserve the thanks and praise of the Australian people for finally targeting welfare to those most in need, for leading the world in the targeting of that welfare and for ensuring that all over the world governments find out how to do it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented.
—Are you seeking to make a personal explanation?

—Yes, I am. The first point on which the Minister has quite deliberately misrepresented my position is that he claims I have been attacking employees of the Department. I know that ignorance can go so far, but there cannot be any question of ignorance here. If he had listened or had cared to listen, he would have understood that I was saying that there is a whole series of structures and rules that the Minister is responsible for enforcing and that he has shown absolutely no inclination to do that. It is profoundly inaccurate, to say the least, to suggest that somehow I have been in the business of attacking employees of the Department. I want to make it perfectly clear that we have no quarrel at all with the way in which those employees carry out their tasks.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter that I want to correct is the suggestion that we are about bashing sole parents, invalid pensioners and unemployment beneficiaries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Comments about the Opposition's attitude to people in Australia have nought to do with an attempt by Senator Alston to suggest that he has been misrepresented. I ask you to rule him out of order.
—Until now Senator Alston has been in order, but I remind him that his remarks have to relate to matters on which he has been misrepresented.
—I am greatly indebted to the Minister because he has now made it clear that he is not in any way suggesting that I am in the business of bashing any of those three categories of people.
—Ha, ha!
—Does the laugh mean that he is not conceding that? If he is conceding that I am not in any way to be accused of bashing those three categories, I have nothing further to add.
—Sit down.

—Can I just suggest, for example, that in relation to that silly little story about 100 complaints to the Ombudsman, if one looks in the explanatory notes for Estimates, one will find that the true figure is something in excess of 2000. The third area in which I claim to have been misrepresented-and this is a very personal and not generic complaint-is in relation to that interview that, extraordinarily, Senator Richardson still refuses to comprehend. The Act clearly says that one must be totally and permanently incapacitated to the extent of 85 per cent and of that one must be primarily physically incapacitated.
—You said 42.5 per cent impairment.

—Exactly. Just a moment; I am making what I said clear once again. Senator Richardson asked me whether I claimed that the Act said that, and I am explaining the position. The Act says that one must be permanently incapacitated to the extent of at least 85 per cent.

—I raise a point of order. I do think that the honourable senator, once again, has strayed well away from a personal explanation and is now just redebating this issue. I ask you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to ask him to cease.
—Senator Alston is still in order, but I invite him to bring his remarks to a close in a moment.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. The simple point is this: Senator Richardson suggested that I had said that the Act has a mandatory requirement of 42.5 per cent impairment. I have never said any such thing. Putting it in a nutshell, it says that that is effectively the result of an 85 per cent incapacity having to be primarily the result of a physical, mental or intellectual impairment. As Senator Richardson would well know, that is a rule of thumb that has been applied and, therefore, equates to what I have consistently said-that is, it is effectively a 42.5 per cent test. But I have never at any stage suggested that the Act has that as a mandatory or other requirement, and he well knows it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to comment on this matter of public importance raised by Senator Alston today. The administrative shortcomings of the Department of Social Security (DSS) and, indeed, the failure of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) to adequately address them have been of great concern to the Australian Democrats for quite some time. After all, it is the group of people most in need who are among the most disadvantaged by this Government's economic policies. I would add to this group only the farming sector and the small business communities, which have been as adversely affected. It is indicative of the Government's attitude towards them that their distress is further compounded by the continuing administrative difficulties and the indifference displayed by the Department of Social Security.

SPEECH.PARA: Before continuing to specifically address the matter of public importance, I would like to make a comment on something Senator Richardson raised. He said that we were in advance of other countries because we spend so little on those in need. I argue that less is not better and that, in fact, we are well behind the majority of Western democracies, almost at the bottom, as far as our spending as a percentage of our gross domestic product is concerned. I hope that Senator Richardson is not suggesting that we should follow the track of America, which is, I think, the only country spending significantly less than we are. It has major problems of people living on the streets, drug abuse, crime, et cetera.

However, I return specifically to the debate in hand. The Department has had an image problem for quite some time. Its procedures and practices have been subjected to a number of inquiries, none of which was mentioned by Senator Richardson. Honourable senators should be aware of the recent report by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which looked at debt recovery under the Social Security Act. Last year the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs conducted an extensive examination of the practices of the Department relating to its fairness, courtesy and efficiency. These investigations pointed out the great inadequacies in the Department's administrative procedures, and yet a serious, demonstrable commitment to improvement on the part of the Minister still has not been forthcoming.

In particular, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs pointed out a range of problems in the Department's dealings with its clients. These included poor employment practices within the Department which led to queues and very long waiting times for assistance-in fact, in many cases people had to return over and over again-lack of consistency and accuracy in the information they were provided with when they were eventually seen and an unwillingness to volunteer information to clients: they needed to know exactly what they were in need of and how to ask for it. The Committee also mentioned major criticisms in relation to a reluctance on the part of field officers and mobile review teams to fully apprise clients of their rights and a generally unhelpful nature of many of the Department's routine letters.

The Government has taken only limited action on the recommendations of this very thorough report, and, indeed, it seems that very little, if anything, has changed since this report was tabled in May last year. Since taking over the responsibilities for the Democrats in this portfolio, I have spent quite a long time talking to a wide range of community groups across Australia. They all speak of ongoing problems with the Department's administrative procedures. They tell me of inadequate information being provided, of inaccurate and confusing advice being given and of a system so complex that not only the clients but also, in fact, the departmental staff find it increasingly difficult to fully and accurately access entitlements and people's rights.

The Welfare Rights Unit in Melbourne, which is part of a national network of independent advice services for pensioners and beneficiaries, recently conducted a phone-in about problems within the Department. Over the day of the phone-in some 160 clients of the Department called the Unit. Their complaints reflected much of what the other investigations I have mentioned also found. Clients complained about not receiving adequate or accurate information; about the inadequacy of information about eligibility for pensions and benefits; about having their benefits cut off only to have them reinstated after very little investigation, as it was simply an error; about being unable to get information on incidental benefits from the Department because the officers themselves did not know the answers; about regional offices of the Department not having up-to-date information on the latest changes to the Act; about not taking up payments to which they were entitled because of misleading information being supplied by the Department; and about long delays, as has been mentioned previously, in receiving benefits and pensions.

Other welfare rights groups have told me of the ongoing communication problem between the Department and the Commonwealth Employment Service, which has resulted in people being wrongly denied unemployment benefits, and of the continuing insensitivity and lack of respect for privacy shown by the Department in its investigation of sole parents. It seems to be quite the norm in some areas of Australia to simply go and check with the neighbours, to start by asking them questions before approaching the sole parent.

These are not new problems. Time and time again they are raised by clients and their advocates. Time and time again we hear about the hardship and suffering these problems are causing. The unwillingness or inability of the Department and the Minister to reform administrative procedures has seriously disadvantaged many clients of the Department. The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs pointed out that the Department's clients included `the most disadvantaged, the most vulnerable in the community'. These people have great difficulty in understanding the provisions of this very complex Act and are often at risk of failing to comply with sections of the Act due to its complexity.

The results are that the already vulnerable are further disadvantaged because they lose their rights and entitlements, they lose their only source of income, and they are not among the group in the community which has a small nest egg put away somewhere for such emergencies. These people are turning more and more to the private sector, to the voluntary agencies in this country, for support and assistance. Not only the Department's immediate clients are affected, but also their families-their wives and their children or, in many cases, husbands and children.

In addition to its continuing administrative problems, the Department appears to be increasingly reflecting the attitude of a government obsessed with reducing the number of pensioners and beneficiaries, regardless of the consequences to individuals and families and the community as a whole. I was recently advised by the Adelaide Central Mission that 10 per cent of the people coming to it off the streets are not accessing any government benefit at all. Some of these people living on the streets simply do not know what benefits are available-they have been unable to obtain the information- and it is therefore up to the Mission to provide the advocacy service necessary to help them through the maze that has been put in their way. It is quite clearly the poor and low income earners in this country who are now bearing the brunt of this Government's economic policies, and it is scandalous that the Department that should be providing them with adequate income support cannot get its act together sufficiently to do this job.

As the Minister commented earlier, I am quite prepared to acknowledge the inherent problems in operating such a complex system. There have been some 25 amending Bills to the Social Security Act in the past three years and it is a particularly complex and cumbersome piece of legislation. It seems fairly clear from all the available evidence that the departmental staff simply cannot keep up with the changes to their own legislation. However, it is up to the Minister to ensure that these problems do not adversely affect the Department's clients.

Alongside this rapid change there has been a decrease in overall departmental staff; as Senator Alston mentioned earlier, there is a very high turnover of staff, particularly of junior staff; and there have been cutbacks in the number of social workers available. In many offices the clients are not informed that a social worker is available if they have problems; they are also not always informed that a welfare rights centre is available if they have problems. All these difficulties clearly demonstrate the great value of a welfare rights service-an independent advice and advocacy service.

If the Department cannot conduct its affairs properly, it should at least be supportive of outside organisations which can offer accurate advice. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs in its report acknowledged that `agencies often act as a substitute for the Department where problems arise' and that `a substantial proportion of the workload of the agencies consists of assistance to DSS clients who are concerned to maintain or obtain their entitlements'.

But, once again, the attitude of the Government towards the Department's clients is all too obvious: no money was allocated in this year's Budget towards supporting the national welfare rights advocacy network, and many of the welfare rights centres have already had to cut back on the service they provide; indeed, some of these centres are threatened with closure before the end of the year unless support is given. If this occurs, even more clients of the Department will be disadvantaged and a significant crucial voice and advocate on behalf of pensioners and beneficiaries will be silenced.

I do not think the Government wants to address this problem, because its primary motivation is to reduce expenditure and to reduce the numbers of pensioners and beneficiaries and it does not particularly care how it gets there. In order to provide a proper service for clients of the Department of Social Security, the Government obviously cannot continue to hack at the social security budget, as indeed the Minister himself has very recently recognised.

It disturbs me that it is already too late for the many social security recipients who have been adversely affected by both the Government's economic policies and the increasing lack of concern it shows towards pensioners and beneficiaries-a lack of concern that is reflected in the continuing failure of the Department of Social Security to provide adequate services.

I will cite two examples of how much pressure is now being placed on private agencies and the services provided by a variety of non-government groups. The first group that contacted me today is the Hutt Street Centre in Adelaide, which provides meals and shelter. Last year it dealt with an increased number of 1,349 clients. This year, to date, it has already had 1,541 clients to its door. At least 25 per cent are young people under the age of 25. The centre is beginning to see families and people who already have shelter in their own homes but who do not have sufficient money left over to feed the children.

The second group that contacted me today is the Adelaide Central Mission, which runs Wright Court in the city. It has an ever increasing number of people seeking assistance. In just one day last month 171 people asked for its help. It is now averaging 131 people per day. Its clients are also getting younger. It recently estimated that there are now 350 homeless in Adelaide, of which 10 per cent receive no benefits, as I mentioned. These people have to rely on rubbish bins, on collecting cans and on charitable handouts. Unfortunately more and more are being forced into desperate situations where they are stealing. The Mission also finds that the mentally ill-it estimates nearly 40 per cent of those on the streets have some problem in that general direction-and the illiterate cannot get through the maze of paperwork that is now necessary to claim a benefit.

The ultimate picture that will emerge from this indifference is not one that the Australian Democrats believe the community can tolerate or afford. I recently talked at length with the superintendent of the Brisbane City Mission, the Reverend O'Connor. He made an observation about the inadequacies of our social security system which demonstrates the seriousness of the problem. He said, and I will conclude with this quote:

The Brisbane City Mission having served in the Valley for the past one hundred and thirty-one years has now turned full cycle. Whereas in those early days we worked with convicts deported for stealing as little as a loaf of bread, we are today involved with children stealing food in order to survive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —To be frank, I believe that the wording of today's matter of public importance treats the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) rather too kindly. Certainly, he has failed to address the multitude of administrative problems currently besetting his Department, and his performance today gives me no comfort at all that he is going to change. Of even greater concern is the fact that in many cases the Minister has either brought the problems on the Department himself or is blissfully unaware that any problems even exist.

SPEECH.PARA: Within three months we will witness in Australia the commencement of the most extensive computer data matching procedures ever to have occurred in our history. Social Security will be responsible for linking and comparing income, identity and tax file number information relating to the clients of every benefit-providing Federal government agency except the Health Insurance Commission. Given the document that was tabled by Senator Bishop, I even suspect that the Health Insurance Commission data might one day see its way to the Deakin centre. God forbid that it does.The responsible Minister has repeatedly stated that he will personally ensure that his Department will protect the privacy of all Australians. What are such assurances worth when he quite obviously had not even bothered-and it was evident yesterday in his answers to questions asked here by me-to find out how these new data matching procedures will work?

There has been a disturbing breakdown in communication between the Minister and his Department with regard to this matter, and the example I gave of not being able to answer my questions is the latest example of administrative and ministerial blundering that has beset this portfolio. The recent Social Security amnesty is a perfect example of what I am trying to describe. On 21 August the Minister had the gall to claim that the amnesty is not for people who have deliberately defrauded the system. He said, `The people the Government is trying to help with this amnesty are its basically honest clients'. To whom does this amnesty apply? It applies to anyone as long as the original claim for the benefit was honest. It does not matter that, after that, claimants have been ripping off the system ever since. As long as they were honest applicants when they applied, they can do whatever they like after that as far as the amnesty is concerned.

The Secretary of the Department of Social Security admitted in the Estimates committee that most people in the amnesty would be aware-because they had been told by letters from the Department-that they were giving the Department false information. These are our honest citizens that Senator Richardson was telling us we were abusing when we raised this issue. Another official admitted that people covered by the amnesty would have committed offences under the Social Security Act. I presume the real purpose of the amnesty was to clean out the Department's grossly inefficient benefits control branches before the onset of the new data matching processes. The Minister's claim that the amnesty would apply only to honest citizens who have not deliberately defrauded the system is not only untrue but also an affront to Australian taxpayers who finance Social Security's inability to control welfare fraud.

I was fascinated as, I have no doubt, many Australian people were, that the Social Security Department jumped on the politicising of the Public Service bandwagon, which has reached epidemic proportions under this Labor Government. Early in 1990 the Social Security Department was instructed by the Labor Government to conduct a $1.5m superannuation promotion. I do not need to remind honourable senators here that it was just weeks before a Federal election. When one goes back through the Budget Papers for last year one sees there is no mention of this item being budgeted for. The Department did not know it was going to happen. There is no indication it was coming, and that was admitted in Estimates. But it is not surprising that it was urgent-because the election was coming up. Now the urgency is over and the Department tells us in Estimates that there are no plans to follow up on this initiative. We have a blatant example of misuse and abuse of taxpayers' money.

This one-off superannuation campaign pales into insignificance compared with the onslaught of political propaganda that arrives in pensioners' mailboxes every three months. It arrives in more than pensioners' mailboxes. My father, who is an endangered species-the last of the small manufacturers and exporters left in this country-was infuriated when he received a copy of Aged Pension News in his letterbox, as he most probably provides the pension for 30 to 40 citizens in this country. He is of the age to receive a pension but he still employs himself and 35 or so other people; yet he received it. Despite the fact that I am not one of his senators, he proceeded to lobby me and abuse me for this happening, so I decided to find out why he had received it. He received it because he happened to be eligible-he has never taken it-for Veterans' Affairs benefits; so he gets on the Social Security list. This wonderfully organised Department sends to a taxpayer the Pension News. He found it very interesting to find out how his money that he was supplying through his tax was being used, so I suppose there was some point in sending it to him.

What appears in this Pension News? There are massive headlines applauding Government initiatives, and a letters page devoted to self-congratulations-letter after letter from Mr P. of somewhere, Mr C. of somewhere else and Miss C. of somewhere else-congratulating the Government on what it has had done for them. It was quite interesting to note that one of my staff said to me, quite innocently, 'These don't look as if they have been written by old people'. I have asked the Department to supply me with copies of some of these letters just to show me that they are written by people out in the community. There are biased articles about Ministers who are, supposedly, concerned for the plight of pensioners but whose actions belie these claims.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is pretty mean, Senator. What did the Department say?

—Senator Crowley will have her chance. The Department runs the jobs, education and training (JET) program. Only 4 per cent of eligible sole parents are taking advantage of that program. It is obvious that this will join the score or more of Labor employment initiatives that are heralded with great publicity and glossy brochures, and then thrown on the scrap heap. One of the reasons this one could end up on the scrap heap is that only 4 per cent of the sole parents that are the target for this program queue up for it. At least the Minister has recognised that there are poverty traps discouraging many sole parents from returning to the work force, but his continued reliance on a financial blunderbuss such as JET does not suggest he is sufficiently committed to eliminating these traps.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not given to applauding the Government but I suppose one should give credit where credit is due. It has belatedly recognised the need to have more stringent eligibility tests for the invalid pension-soon to be called the disability support pension. There are very real reasons to doubt the efficacy of the research upon which these Budget announcements are based. During 1989-90 the Department conducted two research projects relating to methods of assessing invalid pension eligibility. The first was the Australian functional ability measure-known as AFAM. That cost the Department $200,000. It was an abject failure and produced no useable results. That was $200,000 down the drain. The second was the modified invalid pension project-referred to as MIPP-which produced some interim results that were passed on to the Government, but the final report has, as yet, not even been written up or assessed. I call on the Minister to allay my suspicions that the Government has announced these changes to invalid pension eligibility checking systems without first obtaining and assessing the necessary research results. It has tried but it has not been very successful.

To be gracious, the Department of Social Security has a very mediocre record as far as identifying and recouping overpayments is concerned. The current overpayment bill is $214m; it rises every year. Included in this figure are 19 examples of internal fraud. We are not talking about the single examples that Senator Alston gave-and they are very important, despite what the Minister says. We are now talking about internal fraud netting $671,000 of taxpayers' money.

The Auditor-General recently criticised the Department for its tardiness in raising overpayments. There is also overwhelming evidence that officers have not been paying proper attention to exception reports and the suspected overpayments facility. Departmental officials claim that considerable effort is being made to overcome these problems. But when it takes 18 months-and despite the Minister saying that the amount of $848 spent on a general overpayments letter written by someone outside the Department is minutiae-one begins to doubt whether the Department has either the desire or the ability to lift its game as the Auditor-General has demanded.

The overpayments have not been made only to the recipients of social security benefits. We discovered in the Estimates hearings and through the Auditor-General's report that the Department-the excuse was that it was changing to computers-had overpaid a supplier by $1.7m. Imagine a business overpaying a supplier by $1.7m! What a joke.

All of these examples of administrative problems currently facing the Department of Social Security may well be pushed into the background come 1 January 1991. On that date, Social Security will become the central benefits control hub for the departments of Employment, Education and Training; Community Services and Health; and Veterans' Affairs. Each of these departments-I want this on the public record just so we know what is happening, because Senator Richardson does not seem to want to put it on the record very clearly --

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, you tell us.

—I gave Senator Richardson a chance. Each of these departments will provide Social Security with family identifiers, tax file numbers and income information. The tax file numbers of these clients, who, I remind the Senate, are not necessarily Social Security clients, will then be given to the Australian Taxation Office, which will return them to Social Security with their accompanying Tax Office income information. The income information from the Tax Office and the income information supplied by the other departments will then be cross-matched, and if a possible incorrect payment is identified Social Security will notify the relevant department.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister calls us scaremongers and claims that we do not know what we are talking about. He is the last one who should start throwing stones. It is the Minister who on 19 September claimed in this place-I may be stretching it to say that he misled the Parliament, so I will not say that-that Social Security would be giving to the Tax Office in this data matching procedure the tax files numbers of only its own clients. That is what he said.

It was the Minister who on AM this morning told us that the information from other departments would be immediately destroyed if no discrepancy was found. This may be the case with the mainframe-it may eliminate the information if there is no mismatch-but it must be remembered that the information will also be stored on a tape or cartridge which has been received from the relevant department. That will be there for 90 days, then destroyed by the Department. The tapes will then be cleared and sent back to the relevant department.

It is the Minister who informs us that the Privacy Commissioner has been continually consulted about this matter, but when I asked about this I was told-I would be pleased if this were not true, and I am quite prepared to be told that it is not true-that the Privacy Commissioner has not even visited the computer centre where all this matching will take place. I do not know whether that is true and I hope the Minister will be able to clarify it at some point, but that is what I was told.

It is the Minister who tells us that every privacy requirement will be followed, when in fact these new initiatives have already rendered the latest tax file guidelines obsolete and Social Security is now tendering without even waiting for the Privacy Commissioner's data-matching guidelines to be finalised. The Minister says that consultations are taking place and that we have guidelines that are not even there.

I refer to another thing that concerned me. When we went to the computer centre we saw the large computer tapes that are now being used and the small cartridges that the Department of Social Security is moving to. When I asked what security arrangements were in place with regard to these small cartridges-they are about the size of two cigarette packs together and doubled; they are not very big-I said, `What is to stop somebody in the Department from walking out with one of these in his or her pocket?'.

These cartridges-containing all this data about people-can be used on any IBM-compatible machine. The person to whom I was speaking said to me, `Oh, Senator Patterson, we've never thought of that. What a good idea. We'll have to take it up'. I do not know whether that was a reference to helping people put the cartridges in their pockets-I do not think so-but the Department had not thought of how it would have control over internal fraud or tapes going out of the Department. That is appalling, and I rest my case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As always, Senator Alston has introduced a matter of some moment; that is, the question of the administrative problems in the Department of Social Security. It is proper that, as shadow Minister for Social Security, he should look at those issues. He has opened up what he considers to be the problems. His view seems to be that, amongst other things, Senator Richardson has ambitions to be a Minister of some other portfolio. Senator Alston put forward that ambition as a reason for saying that there are administrative problems currently besetting the Minister's Department. I am not too sure whether there is a connection between his ambition and any problems in the Department at present, but no doubt Senator Herron will explain that to us.
—He has his mind on other things.

—Senator Alston says that the Minister has his mind on other things and therefore cannot properly administer the Department. Senator Patterson has indicated the sorts of things that the Opposition is talking about. She has told us that some overpayments have not been collected to the value of $214m, that there has been some internal fraud costing $671,000, that a bill for $1,814 has been run up which should not have been, and that an amount of $1.7m has been overpaid to suppliers. Senator Patterson, together with Senator Alston, says that these things have come about because of the ambition of Senator Richardson. That seems to be what we have to infer from all that.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Patterson said that a bill for $1,814 is an important matter, and of course it is. An overpayment that amounts to $214m is important too. But what concerns me about all of this is that, while the Department of Social Security, directed by governments of all colours-it was directed magnificently by former Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle-is meant to help people who are sick or lame, people who are desperate to stay alive, the shadow Minister should target out of all this some instances of problems in the administration. One might have hoped-indeed, might even have expected-that we would be debating whether or not the people that this Department is meant to help were being helped properly. Since that has not been introduced, the only conclusion we can draw from that is that the Opposition, in spite of its criticisms of Senator Richardson, concedes by the very terms of this matter of public importance that the recipients of social security benefits have been well treated.

No matter what else we might say about Senator Richardson, we have to concede that the job he is in there to do-to provide the people with proper benefits; to provide the lame, the sick, the halt and the poorly-off and deprived in this community-he is doing magnificently. There has been not one criticism in this regard. I have listened to Senator Alston, an outstanding barrister, and to Senator Patterson, who has a great analytical mind, and neither of them has been able to give us any examples of how this Department has ill treated or treated other than in the best of ways the recipients of social security benefits-the very purpose of this system.

It is all very well to get up and say that there were some significant overpayments, a bill of $1,814 paid that should not have been paid, and $671,000 in internal fraud and so on. But what about the essential thrust of our policy and what this Department is all about? I refer to giving some sort of relief to the most vulnerable people in the community. On that prime test and judging by the way this case has been conducted by the Opposition, I believe that Senator Richardson comes out trumps, following the magnificent work done by Senator Grimes and by Mr Brian Howe in the past.

Let us look at the `maladministration' which Opposition senators talk about. They have come up with overpayments and internal fraud amounting to $671,000-that seems to be the figure. One would have thought that if a million dollars was all that was in the budget, a sum of $671,000 would be a significant figure. Opposition senators must have been talking about fairly limited figures. Therefore, one looks to a document referring to the Budget Papers to find out what the expenditure in 1989-90 was. It is estimated at $21 billion. While I am on this point, let me give some other figures. Some 16,500 staff are employed at more than 300 locations across Australia. So in respect of a department that has an outlay of $21 billion and a staff of some l6,500 employed at 300 locations, Senator Alston, who is an outstanding adornment to this chamber, and Senator Patterson, on whom we have to rely completely, come up with about four examples, as I understand it-it may be more, even up to 10- in support of their arguments. Senator Patterson rages, and properly so, that there is an internal fraud of $671,000 in a budget of $21 billion.

I say to Senator Patterson-and we accept her figures because she is so outstanding-that that is the significant thing about the running of the Department of Social Security (DSS) in this country. The great and significant thing that Opposition members have got on to about the DSS and about the payments to people who are the most deprived and the most vulnerable in our community is that there have been overpayments of $214m and costs by way of fraudulent employees of $671,000.

I would have thought that the figures here today, rather than showing a lack of proper administration, show that it has been a pretty tight administration all round. One would have thought that more examples would have been dragged forward if the administration is as bad as the Opposition says it is, a lot more examples of maladministration and fraud than Opposition members have been able to gather and glean today. I understand that this is after days and days searching through this Department in the Estimates committee hearings by powerful figures on the other side of the chamber. They have had before them all the people from the Department that they wanted to see. Opposition senators had freedom to cross- examine those officials and to call before them whomever they wanted and to ask them whatever they wanted. In a budget of $21 billion with 16,500 staff employed at more than 300 locations around Australia, the best they can do is to come up with the miserable number of examples that they have quoted here today.

Those examples have to be seen in the context of Australia in hard economic times, where people are suffering because of the economic downturn. There are people who, through no fault of their own, rely on the invalid pension, unemployment benefits, age pensions, special benefits, and child allowances of various sorts. The needs of all those people and the sorts of things they must have in order to live a decent life are absolutely ignored by Opposition senators because they want to talk about half a dozen examples of bad administration in such a large department with such a large budget-if one accepts the examples they have given as bad administration. The case presented by the Opposition today is conclusive proof, given the examples that it has been able to quote, that this Minister has administered magnificently.

In this context I wish to say something about the overpayments of $214m, which was the figure quoted by the Opposition and which I accept. Let us look at what overpayments are about. They occur when people are paid a particular pension or level of pension without entitlement to it. The Social Security Act provides means by which those sums can be recovered.

I would point out that the provisions set out in the Act by which money can be recovered are fairly draconian. If honourable senators look at section 164 of the Act, they will understand what I mean. However, that sort of thing does not concern the Opposition. I can understand anybody with a heart saying, `Perhaps the way you are trying to collect these overpayments is a little stringent', but Opposition members do not say that. They say that the process should be even more stringent and oppressive in terms of the collection of overpayments.

The attitude of this Government has been quite different from that. It has said that it understands the distress, the denigration of people's dignity which poverty and sickness bring. It will set up a scheme-and the Minister has gone into this-not to fling some dollars at people who are in distress, not to set up soup kitchens and dole out some gruel to people who are desperate for dignity, but to create a whole new philosophy which is based on the proposition that people in distress should be helped, not simply in money terms but in being restored to the community as people who are able to walk where they could not walk before, able to earn where they could not earn before, able to cope with advancing age where they could not cope before. These schemes such as Jobs, Education and Training and Newstart, which have been denigrated in a most miserable fashion, are part of that program. They are part of a philosophy which cannot be worked out successfully overnight, but which has been begun successfully, brought forward, with modification, successfully and ultimately will lead to a new way of thinking in the community that will be beneficial to the most distressed people in it and, because of that, to the community as a whole. That is what this Government has done, and that is what this Minister represents.

It is quite mean of the Opposition to come in here and ignore that magnificent effort and the philosophy which was begun by Senator Grimes, continued by Mr Howe and is now being carried on by Senator Richardson. One hopes that the Opposition will continue that philosophy if ever it gets into power.

In the couple of minutes I have remaining to me in this debate let me say something about the appeal system that this Government has set up. It has set up on a statutory basis the Social Security Appeals Tribunal, which previously existed at an administrative level. That has given scope for people who are dissatisfied with the way in which the Department has treated them to go to an independent body. That has been a success and indicates the way in which this Government has gone about things. I think that ought to be mentioned because it deserves great praise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two days ago I asked the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) whether it was a fact that persons with as little as 15 per cent medical impairment had been held to have 85 per cent incapacity for work for the purposes of obtaining an invalid pension. In his reply the Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is possible that, in the past, 15 per cent levels of medical impairment have led to calculations of 85 per cent incapacity-that has occurred.

I would like to make the point that it is occurring today; that is the criterion that is used. The criteria on which eligibility for invalid pension is based are quite imprecise. The Social Security Act requires that two tests need to be met:
(a) the degree of the person's permanent incapacity for work is not less than 85 per cent; and
(b) that permanent incapacity, or at least 50 per cent of that permanent incapacity, is directly caused by a permanent physical or mental impairment of the person.

In practice, a medical practitioners's assessment is regarded only as a broad indicator. The Department has decided that, in practice, if an impairment rating of 30 per cent or more is achieved, it should usually be accepted that persons meet the requirement of the Act. I repeat: the Department has decided that if the impairment rating is 30 per cent-

TALK.START.PARA: —Without authority.

—Without authority and without medical direction, the Department makes the decision. As I have mentioned previously, some pensions have been granted on the basis of impairment levels down to 15 per cent. As a result of this, two quite dramatic and remarkable events have occurred in relation to this matter. The first is that surveys have shown that the peak impairment level is between 30 and 39 per cent. In fact, one-third of all recipients fall into this category and 16 per cent below it. I seek leave, Mr Deputy President, to table the document showing these facts.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Only 10 per cent have levels of 80 per cent impairment or above. The second fact is that there has been a dramatic increase in the growth rate of entitlements to invalid pensions. Since 1983, there has been a 40 per cent increase in the growth rate of invalid pensions. There are now 412,552 invalid pension beneficiaries in our population of 17 million, and taxpayers' money amounting to $2,679,752,000 is involved.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to show a graph demonstrating that fact. That is what has happened in relation to the number of invalid pensions that have occurred in this country since 1983. The lower graph shows the growth of population in this country since 1983. The lower graph is population; the upper graph is the number of invalid pensioners. Something dramatic has happened. I know that Senator Richardson was known as the Kneecapper, but even the Kneecapper could not have produced that increase in the last seven years.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a lot of knees.

—It is a lot of knees and it is a lot of invalid pensioners. Suddenly something has happened in our society whereby we have got this dramatic increase: up to half a million of our population are now on invalid pensions. How has this occurred? The answer is fairly simple. The Department has decided that anybody who has got a 30 per cent incapacity to work now gets an invalid pension, on the Department's decision. What is the Minister going to do about it? These figures have been brought to his attention.

SPEECH.PARA: There was a review done a couple of years ago demonstrating that this sort of thing was going to occur. The Minister is going to review it. But what does the review show? It shows that the estimates are that about 2 per cent of the beneficiaries can be reviewed because of the people taking part in the review. All the present beneficiaries will continue as before. I might mention that we have already passed the point where there are more people receiving benefits in Australia than there are taxpayers, and that is going to increase because of the ageing population. Inevitably, that proportion will increase. We passed the halfway point a couple of years ago.

The Minister mentions with pride that there are four million beneficiaries now and over $16 billion is administered by the Department of Social Security. He mentions that the Department of Social Security has got the largest computing network in the country. That is where we have reached in this country: the Department of Social Security has the largest computing network-not the Department of Defence, not the Department of Health, and not any other department, but the Department of Social Security.

We have reached the stage in this country where there are more beneficiaries than taxpayers, and that is what the Labor Party has led us to: no creation of wealth; just spend it; keep doling it out; do not control it; bring it down. And even Senator Crowley might reach the 15 per cent level if she keeps waving her hand at me. The Department has lost control of procedures, and the Minister has lost control of the granting of pensions. So he has lost control of his Department and his portfolio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not expected the bonus early call. Today, we are actually dealing with a remarkable matter of public importance (MPI) that reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The continuing failure of the Minister for Social Security to address the multitude of administrative problems currently besetting his Department.

That, I would think, is a monument to puerile and pathetic opposition. It is quite surprising that into this place comes a debate not about policy, not about the direction of the money, and not about the intention of the Opposition in social security. The best those opposite can say is that here and there-I think they gave collectively some 10 examples; maybe we are up to 20 examples by now-a little bit of administration is going wrong. They do not want to tell us what they will do under social security and the aims of their policy because it is clear they have not got anything to say.

This is the most puerile and pathetic MPI I think have ever heard brought in to this place since I have been here. At least in times past, the Opposition wanted to argue an alternative emphasis under social security. Today those opposite are down to whether or not administration is up to scratch. How absolutely pathetic are Opposition senators when that is the best that they can deliver as an MPI-no claims; no justification of where they would take cuts under social security to meet their $3 billion extra that they rushed around with during the last election; and no evidence at all of what they would do instead of what is currently in place.

We know that they said not too many months ago that they would want to take people off the dole-`Get rid of dole bludgers' was their claim-but they are not talking about that today. They have not the courage to tell us their social security policy; they have not got one. They want to come in here and carp about some administrative problems. One way they did this was to give us examples of people who had found it very difficult when they got to the Department. Do not go, Senator Alston. I have a case that should gratify the honourable senator: a man appeared in my office complaining bitterly at the Social Security Department's criteria for him to identify himself in order to be eligible for payments. I presumed him to be a bona fide constituent and took up his case with the Department. He was particularly upset when a payment was given to him that time but not the subsequent two weeks later.

He came back to my office saying, `It is outrageous; they are demanding further identification'. I discovered that he was out of gaol from a case of fraud. That man makes me very angry because he is the reason that the Department has to have very precise and tight requirements on all the just and honest citizens in this country who have to go to great pains to identify themselves because there are crooks and frauds such as this man around the place. Why did Senator Alston not tell us about similar examples to that? Or is it that those examples only come to my office?

There are people who are in trouble. From time to time, as the Minister acknowledged, things go a little less than perfectly. As far as I know, any time that I have ever contacted anybody in the Department or any of the Ministers in charge, they have immediately addressed the problem as quickly and as efficiently as they could. Senator Alston's matter of public importance does not give any balance at all to the amount of money outlaid on behalf of citizens of this country; as Senator Cooney said, on behalf of those people who are behind the eight ball, who are deserving of age pensions, who are single mothers looking for support, who are unemployed, who are invalided, et cetera.
