Before Senator Herron leaves the chamber, it is important to remind him about the definitions of impairment and invalidity. Senator Herron did not say when he claimed the definitions were vague that they were properly vague. I ask him: How would he measure schizophrenia, for example, as a case of impairment? Is it 15 per cent, 20 per cent, 39 per cent or 50 per cent? Are we up to 85 per cent? What figure could he possibly put on anybody with a mental illness in this country? He knows that the definition properly has to be vague. A person may have a very limited impairment but be enormously disadvantaged in terms of his or her capacity to work. If there is a problem-and the Minister said that he is reviewing it-I take that as bona fide that he will do so.

Senator Herron knows-particularly as he is a doctor-that we cannot possibly define impairment too precisely. He would be the first to scream if people took away the medical profession's right to make its own medical assessment. Senator Herron also knows that the medical profession in times past has not exactly covered itself with glory on this matter. So, let us contribute to review, not come in here carping about invalid pensions and vague definitions. I think that Senator Herron has scored a cheap point and it does him no credit.

As to Senator Herron's suggestion that we should have a bigger computer in the Department of Defence than in the Department of Social Security, I will have to make him remember that line for a long time to come: `The biggest computer is for the Department of Social Security. Why is it not in the Department of Defence?' Indeed, why is it not? It is because this Government has a priority that would rather pay dollars to people than put bullets and bombs around the country. That is a crazy claim, Senator. The Department of Social Security has a very big computer because those of us who have been around here for a long time know the effort which the Government has taken, under Ministers Grimes, Howe and now Richardson, to get that STRATPLAN computer in place. If Senator Herron knew his history, he would know how much more efficiently the Department is now administering all those payments. That is why it has administrative costs of 3 per cent. Senator Herron would also know how much more reliably pensions and payments are delivered to the community.

It is crazy to claim the Department of Social Security has the biggest computer as though that is some liability. The Department has a computer sufficient to the task, at last. We no longer have the failure and breakdown of the payments system that we had in the past. The Government should be commended for getting that computer in place, because it is delivering the service to the people when they expect to get it and payments are not held up as they were-certainly as I recollect it-in the early 1980s before that STRATPLAN computer was in place. I have to say to Senator Herron that his argument is totally ridiculous.

The Opposition has assessed the `disaster' here and it will go in to bat on some millions of dollars and ignore the benefits of over $20 billion paid to deserving people who meet the criteria of eligibility to receive payments. The Opposition has its size and proportions wrong. It is a little similar to the way it argues about hospital waiting lists. Any minute now we will be able to prove the Opposition wrong on that, too. I have it from New South Wales that we can look at that State's waiting lists and say that 20,000 people per month are on the public hospital waiting list. We can also say that across the whole of New South Wales 98-plus per cent of public patients out of the one million people who seek attention are treated within a week and, if they are emergencies, within 24 hours. It just depends which way the emphasis is put.

The Opposition wants to argue about minimal costs for administrative problems that it brings into this chamber and totally to ignore the benefit of the $20 billion-worth of payments properly going to the people who deserve them. By all means Senator Alston should raise his points, but he should not come in here saying that they have the substance for a serious matter of public importance; it is not such. It is a puerile, pathetic little example of the meanness of the Opposition's mind and nothing to boast about at all.

Before my time runs out I would like, for the record, to refute Senator Alston's claim that he has never mentioned in an interview the figure of 42.5 per cent. I quote from an interview from Richard Alston and Sonya Voumard of the Age-

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you listen to what I said?
—Yes, you said you never said it. Senator Alston is quoted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: At least 51 per cent of those clients granted the invalid pension in 1989 did not fulfil the requirement of 42.5 per cent impairment as laid out in the Act.

Those are the lines that he said he has never said, in a quote. That is what it says in the script of the interview. That is what Senator Alston claims he did not say when he was claiming to be misrepresented by the Minister. I simply put on the record again that that quote refutes Senator Alston's claim. I do not believe that he can possibly go on insisting that he was misrepresented. He was not. He got it wrong. The Minister has pointed that out. He has to live with that wrongness.

TALK.START.PARA: —That wrongness?
—If honourable senators opposite do not like the word `wrongness', we will have to think of something else-such as gross inefficiencies, major errors, disasters; we can add to the litany.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that Senator Lees was complaining that the Department of Social Security was not providing assistance to welfare rights groups. I would like to make it clear that the Department of Social Security is not in the business of funding organisations such as welfare rights groups. Many of those groups enjoy funding but they enjoy it under the auspices of the Department of Community Services and Health. In fact, the split between health and social security in the early 1980s, the early years of this Government, made it quite clear that the Department of Social Security was about the payment to people for income security, for pensions, benefits, and so on, and to invalids, and that those people would be entitled to income security. That is what the Department of Social Security is about. It is not a fair criticism of the Department to say that it is not funding welfare rights groups. That is not the Department's aim or the function. Indeed, just to put one point to rest, I know that some welfare rights groups-I cannot be sure of the ones Senator Lees mentioned-enjoy assistance but they enjoy it through a different department.

To my surprise Senator Herron is shocked that we should have such figures as have already been mentioned in this matter of public importance. Yes, indeed, four million people are being paid assistance by this Department and that amounts to more than $20 billion. The figures I have are over $23 billion. I think that figure, within $1 billion, is right. That represents about 25 per cent of Commonwealth outlays. I would also like to reinforce the point made by the Minister that since we came to office in 1983, the social security outlays have declined in recent years: from 7.2 per cent in 1983-84 to an estimated 6 per cent in 1990-91. At the same time, while the outlays have been reduced, the payments have all increased. I do not believe anybody looking at social security could possibly fail to acknowledge the great contribution that this Government has made through the increased payments under the family allowance and the family allowance supplement. Very importantly, they are now established as benchmark criteria so that they will never reduce. Those benchmark figures for payments on behalf of children have been set by the Department and they are now indexed. They will never fall below those benchmark figures as set.

Next, I would like to suggest that the role of the Department of Social Security in the child support legislation cannot be overlooked either, though for the record, Senator Alston may criticise the Child Support Agency, but strictly it is not the responsibility of the Department of Social Security. So if Senator Alston wants to complain about the Department of Social Security, he should stick to the parts that it is entirely responsible for, and if the honourable senator wants to tackle the Child Support Agency, he can bring in another scintillating matter of public importance.

Very importantly, too, this matter of public importance is complaining about poor administration. But, in closing, I would like to stress a point mentioned also by the Minister in his remarks that the Department has changed dramatically, not only in reducing its outlays, but also in increasing the payments to everybody eligible. Also, in terms of not being merely a post-box or a banking facility for these payments, its staff have become very actively involved in the care and concern for all those people eligible to receive payments.

Those of us who have seriously noticed the changes under Newstart, under jobs, employment and training, under the requirements for long term unemployed, and so on, will know the charge against the departmental people is now much more demanding and requires much more skill and training than it did in times past. Indeed, if honourable senators read this review, `Reform of Social Security Policies and Administration 1983-1990', over the name of Brian Howe, Minister for Social Security, listing the achievements, they will see very early on specific mention of the need to introduce administrative reforms for greater effectiveness, efficiency and integrity. It is one of the five broad strategies of the Department, and it, of course, is looking always to improve the administration and delivery of its payments. As well as doing all that, it also has made sure that it has provided the money to train the staff members so that they are better able to do this very different requirement asked of them under this Government.

People receiving benefits are not just getting money, they are getting evidence of the care and concern of government, which is, one, that they are probably eligible and, two, that they are properly assisted if they wish to use their payments as an interim before they move into full employment and other benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time allowed for the debate has expired.

DEBATE.TITLE: ADVANCE TO THE MINISTER FOR FINANCE 1990

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

There are a couple of matters in relation to the Advance to the Minister for Finance for September 1990 that I wish to raise. I do so in the context of the discussion that has taken place. I have raised this here on previous occasions, and also we have had some very lengthy discussions on this matter during the Senate Estimates Committee A hearings in recent weeks. I draw the attention of the Senate to the importance of these Advances to the Minister for Finance that are tabled on a regular basis in this chamber. They are very important indeed.

It seems to me that the Senate does not give as much attention to these as it should do, because we have seen examples in recent times, particularly in relation to the Advances to the Minister for Finance used in June of this year when there were three illegal payments made through the Advances to the Minister for Finance. They are supposed to be paid only when the payment is both unforeseen and urgent. Quite patently, the Government has been using it for purposes other than that to disguise the ability for proper scrutiny of some of these expenditures.

There are two points about the expenditures that I wish to refer to here. The first one is to note that in the Advance to the Minister for Finance for September, there is an amount of $319,700 which is said to be `required to cover an overspend' by the Australian Manufacturing Council. This relates to payments for consultancies used by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. According to the supporting applications to this Advance, this overspend of almost $320,000:

. . . was caused by the unplanned for necessity for AMCS to make the final payment to the firm of Pappas, Carter and Coop, who were employed as consultants to produce a comprehensive report on the international competitiveness of Australian manufacturing.

That report has received a very mixed reaction and reception in the wider community since its publication and, indeed, a considerable degree of criticism. The point I want to make is this: what does this explanation of the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance mean? How can a final payment that had earlier been contracted for possibly be regarded as `unplanned'? I express very considerable concern about this because in the past year no less than $8.14m has been spent by Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce alone on external consultancies. That $8.14m includes a figure of about $1.2m on the multifunction polis, $500,000 on the Australian Manufacturing Council, $500,000 or thereabouts on the National Industry Extension Service and a host of others.

In particular, the consultancy company, Pappas Carter Evans and Koop Pty Ltd, has received in the 1989-1990 financial year, and to date in 1990-1991, $2.5m-the one consultancy alone-and that does not include a possible additional $81,650 for payments on which I need to seek clarification in Senate Estimates hearings tomorrow.

The other matter that I wish to raise in this context of the Advance to the Minister for Finance is to note with concern that the supporting applications for both the August and September Advances to the Minister for Finance do not include details of the date on which payments from the Advance were approved from the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis). I do not know why that is the case. I would hope for an explanation from the Minister for Finance for that because that stamp of approval indicates to the Senate and to the Parliament that the payment has in fact been made.

The fact that those details are not there is contrary to the practice which has occurred with previous supporting applications for the Advance tabled in the Parliament and it is a matter of great concern that it is not there.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to take up a point by way of personal explanation against the comments made by Senator Crichton-Browne earlier in speaking to the drugs in sport reference. He did seem to suggest that I and our Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts had withdrawn the drugs in sport reference because the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) did not wish to be associated with heroes who had lost their sheen because they had been associated with the use of drugs. That is drawing a very long bow, and I find it particularly offensive to suggest that our Committee, in a majority vote, would be making decisions influenced by any such pressure at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, a most important point that I wish to put on the record, is that seven of the members of the Committee are new members and only Senator Crichton-Browne is there from a prior Parliament with any understanding of the content of the drugs in sport inquiry. As a very full inquiry report has already been tabled-indeed, two reports have been tabled-and as all but one senator is new to that Committee, they are the principal reasons why it was decided to conclude the reference.

It is important to acknowledge the virtue of the drugs in sport inquiry and, I think, the very considerable contribution made in those two reports. I do not believe that anybody is in disagreement with that. I would accept Senator CrichtonBrowne's comments that the report from the Australian Senate is one of the very few volumes in the world canvassing as comprehensively as it has the issues involved in that very important area. If Senator Crichton-Browne wants to criticise the Committee on the ground that there is still more work to be done, that criticism should more properly pertain to the previous Committee or himself rather than the new incoming Committee. One would appreciate the difficulty that committee of inquiry had because there is no illegality to use-

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am sure the honourable senator has a great deal that she wants to say on this matter. The adjournment debate would be an appropriate place to do it. I believe she has gone beyond making a personal explanation. I have listened carefully to what she has said and feel that is the case.
—Senator Crowley could draw her remarks to a close. It has been a fairly long explanation.

—I will take your advice on this, Mr Acting Deputy President, but I would suggest, through you, that Senator Reid might like to measure the column inches I am making against those that Senator Crichton-Browne made. If in the course of his comments he wanted to impute a fairly grave claim against me as Chairman of the Committee and indeed the Committee, implying that we had been under some pressure to conclude that reference, I would put it on the record that is not the case. No such pressure was applied. I also object to what is a very offensive implication. As I say, it has been done because there are very new members on the Committee and the report is nearly concluded.

—Order! Senator Crowley, you have indicated before the situation regarding other members of the Committee and I believe that at this stage you seem to have encompassed most of the issues relating to your personal explanation.
—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRY COMMISSION-INTERIM REPORT ON PAPER RECYCLING

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 August, on motion by Senator Watson:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few remarks on the Industry Commission's report on paper recycling. Previously Senator Watson has suggested that manufacturers should be left to use recycled fibres in the manner most suitable to them, their products and their clients' needs. While that sounds very plausible and actually relates to some of the thoughts in the report, in many ways what he said and what I have read in the report proves to me that manufacturers are committed to serving their own needs. Because of the investment that is only too evident in Australia-the investment in large mill infrastructures, large forestry concessions and large capital equipment-it is difficult for the paper industry to deviate from the status quo which applies to manufacturing processes and manufacturing style.

SPEECH.PARA: To suggest that such an industry could quickly respond to consumer demand for a different style of product, I think, reveals an ignorance of how this industry works. Taking it a little further, I think that to suggest that manufacturers would be falling over themselves to meet the demands of which recycled products, or indeed any products, consumers deemed suitable to demand, if manufacturers' interests were better served by maintaining the status quo, is quite ridiculous.

The problems which were considered in the report have received a fair bit of public airing and should not be ignored or written off with the sort of implication made by Senator Watson, which was, `Leave the industry to its own devices; it knows what is best for the industry'. Of course it knows what is best for the industry but it is not necessarily best for the community, which has expressed considerable concern at what is happening. That is best illustrated at page 5 of the report which states:
Makers and users of paper do not have to consider the full costs of waste disposal. Hence the present prices of paper products do not reflect the true societal and environmental costs of paper use.

In fact, it is quite true, and we know it, that this encourages overuse of paper and discourages recycling. I have before me a report from the Local Government Bulletin of March 1990 which presents this most perceptive observation:

Paper recycling is a hot issue. The most prominent material by weight in the waste stream is newsprint (including magazines). Over a million trees are cut down each year to supply Sydney with papers . . .

That is indicative of the concerns that are being expressed throughout the community. It is wise to note these concerns and not dismiss them. Although the report does note the concerns well, it does not go far enough in considering what we ought to be doing. It is an interim report. I hope that in the final analysis the final report will give us a little more guidance on how we might bring about matters which will satisfy the community concerns about how recycling can best be conducted. I support the motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 August, on motion by Senator Watson:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is fortuitous that the two Industry Commission reports come in close succession and support the contention that I wish to raise briefly. The Industry Commission report on pulp and paper contains a great amount of information and the information is presented clearly enough. But, as I understand the reference, the Commission was required only to present information. I am concerned that the information is simply presented. I am concerned that reports such as these are often presented in isolation from each other. With that in mind, we in this Parliament should ensure that we consider the reports and other information about pulp mills and paper manufacturing in totality.

SPEECH.PARA: The processes involved in paper making are complicated, they are inter-related, and we should ensure that that information is in fact inter-related and cross-referenced. This particular report should, I believe, be read in conjunction with the Industry Commission report I just spoke on, the report on paper recycling. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation report to Ministers, Pulp Mills: Modern Technology and Environmental Protection is also relevant on this subject.

There are other reports and research papers which, before we can make enlightened expressions of opinion on these matters, we should take into account. The report which was prepared for the Tasmanian Government which is often referred to as the Simons report, Pulp and Paper Options for Northern Tasmania: Focus on fibre, markets and technology related to non-chlorine bleaching, makes sense of the report we are considering now.

The trouble is that the temptation is there for decision makers to accept the information one package at a time and not to see the inter-relationships which are so important. Sometimes inquiries are established in such a manner that cross-referencing is in fact difficult. I bring to the attention of the Senate a letter from the Industry Commission to the Treasurer of 10 July 1990 which is in the front of this very report. It says in part:
the Commission was not asked to report on the BEK -
that is, bleached eucalypt kraft-
pulp mill guidelines and has not done so.

Although I could speak for some time on the content of this actual report, my main concern today and the one I wish to bring to the notice of the Senate is that these reports can, if not carefully read, be seen in isolation and conclusions can be reached which are not relevant to the industry. They do not stand up to further cross-examination and consideration. The Senate was told, for example, even in the very introductory phases of this report on page 2:

The effects of organochlorine discharges on people and on natural ecological systems are not fully understood or quantified. Indeed, the effects of the effluents from bleached eucalypt kraft mills are largely unknown.

I would have thought it was the very duty of an inquiry, in a report of this nature, Pulp and Paper: Bleaching and the Environment, not just to admit that we do not know very much about these things, but to express concern about the fact that we do not know and to do something about it. If that is out of the scope of reference of this report, I would draw the attention of honourable senators to the existence of many other reports and, rather than just accept our ignorance, urge them to take measures and to conduct research which would alleviate that ignorance. I am pleased to see that on page 4 of this report we are told:
Producers and governments are responding to community concern and consumer demand for unbleached and non-chlorine bleached products is strengthening.

The sense of that is that the response to demand is strengthening. I am pleased to see that because in the previous report I referred to we were told that that demand was insignificant. When these reports are seen in conjunction, although they may seem to contradict each other in some ways, if we read them carefully we can at least gain some sense from them. I hope that the report is widely read and I support the motion to take note of it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL DROUGHT POLICY REVIEW TASK FORCE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 August, on motion by Senator Bjelke-Petersen:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some reference to this report and highlight a few factors within it. If this report is adopted by Government, it effectively means that there will not be a comprehensive national drought policy but an individual farm drought policy. The main emphasis is on the farm. While I agree that it is important that there should be emphasis on the individual farm situation, and that has been the situation in the past, it is also important that there be a national approach to this and that drought relief measures in terms of sustained drought should not be taken from the natural disaster arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: That is very important and it was highlighted in the early 1980s when there was an extensive three or four year drought. It is important because there is a necessity in those times to maintain the national herd or flock and also to protect the environment and, in particular, to facilitate the current land care program. Therefore, there needs to be provisions under the natural disaster arrangements.

Unfortunately, the report confuses the rural adjustment process with what should be specific drought measures. The rural adjustment process is something that should continue, and will continue, year in and year out, whereas drought measures are of a totally different nature. The report is notable for its motherhood statements, which stand for little. The recommendations on taxation measures are welcome and essential, and I hope the Government will at least move quickly in this area.

In relation to section 7.4 of the national drought policy, there should be a coordination of the various resources involved into research into the El Nino southern oscillation, water resources and other matters so that there is much greater knowledge in terms of the ability to understand those climatic changes which lead to drought and create a situation whereby we are able to predict, or have a much better idea of, what is coming along.

I would like to deal with a number of specific points in the report. I turn first to page 7. I find the diagram that is there to be very offensive, particularly the comment with regard to `apathy'. I do not think that a national inquiry of this sort and the types of people on it should resort to that sort of language, particularly when they are dealing with an industry which, when we get to practical conservation measures through the land care program, which is an industry driven initiative, is a leader in this particular aspect. I want to bring that part of the report to the attention of the Senate.

I mentioned in my opening comments the rural adjustment guidelines. I would like to bring to the attention of the Senate once again chapter 5, Future Policy Directions, and emphasise the need for drought relief, even if it is administered through the rural adjustment system, which is, in fact, a separate and different operation.

There is a reference on page 10 of the report to incentives for effective soil and water management. It states that they are appropriately delivered through soil conservation and not through drought relief measures. I am not aware that has ever been done and I think that is a misrepresentation of the situation. There is much work to be done in terms of this report. There is a need to keep the natural disaster arrangements in place, I believe. There is a need to identify the importance of maintaining the flock or the herd in the national interest, and it is worth noting that the measures that were taken by the Fraser Government in the early 1980s, which the Hawke Government was the beneficiary of, were able to maintain our export figures in terms of wool and cattle because on a national basis the flock and the herd were able to be moved around the States and from State to State. We saw a consistent growth factor in the value of those exports over the period from 1979-80 to 1988-89. Had that not been in place, I believe those figures would have been significantly lower and the effect would have been that our current account would have been significantly worse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite a while, in fact, quite a few weeks, since I read the final report of the National Drought Policy Review Task Force. From what I can remember of it, the report seems to be out to prove that we do not need any more drought relief and that farmers should be relying on their own resources. I thoroughly agree that on a one-to-one farm basis all farms should conserve fodder and build up their water supplies-whether by reticulation or, preferably, by collecting one's own water in reserves if one can; but even under this Government, a certain amount of cash should be kept aside for harder times. It is a bit hard to say that that can be done for ever and a day, because in certain parts of Australia, namely, Queensland, there had been continual droughts for about 10 years in the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s.

SPEECH.PARA: One could adopt Senator Walsh's idea that those areas were not viable in the first place and that the land should be left to become bush again. However, at this time the land in those marginal areas around Australia is developed, and there is too much infrastructure to let those areas go backwards. If there is a drought for only one year, most established farmers can cope with it, but if there is a long term drought-a drought that goes beyond one year-for example, in a grazing and wheat growing area, I believe that there should be some sort of national drought policy to overcome the problem.

From what I read in this report, it seems that the Government's idea, whether it be on the back burner or somewhere else, is to vindicate itself, to absolve itself of all responsibility in drought situations. It is unfortunate if the Government has that idea. Hopefully, that is not its idea and would not totally implement it. I believe that most people in the Australian agricultural sector are educated to be self-reliant, and that is the way to go, but it would be a disaster if the Government did away completely with a national drought policy. As one from the agricultural field, I am prepared to cop the consequences of this or any future government's introducing a measure to do away with a national drought policy, but everyone else should be treated in the same way and so should other industries be treated in the same way. In a downturn, for example, manufacturing industries should not be helped out. That idea could be extended to a lot of other industries down the line. Whatever our field is in life, if we are in for a hard time because of a downturn, we would be on our own if this idea were to be adopted. People will have had the chance to build up resources, such as cash reserves, and they should cop the consequences of a downturn.

Unfortunately, things do not work that way, as we have seen in the case of some of the bail-outs around Australia in the last few years, such as the bail-out of W.A. Inc. and Victoria Inc. If we are going to make the agricultural and pastoral industries self-reliant, we have to see that this is done right across the board. I hope that the Government will take notice of the very short remarks I have made on the drought report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: PHILOSOPHY BEHIND THE PROVISION OF AGED CARE SERVICES IN AUSTRALIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I rise to speak on the Government's response to the philosophy behind the provision of aged care services in Australia. This is a response to two documents which have been tabled recently in the Senate and in the House of Representatives. The documents refer to an agreement and a contract that has been designed to protect residents' rights in nursing homes and hostels.

This side of the House is concerned about the rights of older Australians and the rights of those in nursing homes. There is no doubt that in some institutions in this country the rights of older people have been abused and that there was a need for this issue to be raised and addressed. However, I am surprised to see in the Government's response the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) state:
Today, I am pleased to introduce to the House the documents designed to underpin the reforms.

I am surprised that he said that he was pleased to introduce them because when we look at those two documents we see that they are a shambles and are poorly drafted. In fact, almost without exception the people who have come to my office in goodwill to talk to me about these two documents in an attempt to protect and extend the rights of older Australians, especially those in residential care, have mentioned the appalling draftsmanship. I do not believe that the parliamentary draftsmen drafted these documents, so I am not casting aspersions on them. However, it seems that somebody who is not a draftsman attempted to draft these documents, and there are all sorts of problems.

One problem brought to my attention is that it would be very difficult for someone who is running a nursing home to actually close the nursing home. Once a contract has been signed with an individual or a group of individuals in the nursing home, it may be very difficult to get out of it. So we might find some people are out of nursing homes because proprietors are not prepared to go into that.

It is always a problem when protecting the rights of one group that we deny the rights of another. There are implications with agreements and contracts. In essence, a contract says that a resident of a nursing home will not discriminate against another resident, a staff member or the proprietor on any basis and that residents within those nursing homes ought to have rights to engage in behaviour which, for some, may not be acceptable.

For example, the Catholic bishops have spoken to me. They said that two individuals of the opposite sex who are not married cohabiting in the same room would not be acceptable in a Catholic nursing home because it offends the belief of the people who fund and run that nursing home and it is contrary to their religious beliefs and their practice. The bishops said to me that the only alternative they would have would be to close down those nursing homes because they ought to raise money and not accept government funding.

In essence, if a proprietor does not sign a contract, he loses his funding. The nursing homes would not be kept open because the only people who would be able to afford to pay for them, if they cannot raise the money by charity, are rich people. That is not what the Little Sisters of the Poor or some Catholic groups and church groups are about. I also believe that I would be approached by the Rechabites, although I have not been approached yet. They have signed the pledge. They might feel that any restrictions placed on their nursing home may be so onerous that it would challenge their philosophy and their value and belief system.

It is strange that we cannot have rules up front before a person goes into a nursing home so that he knows what is there. I can understand if someone is in the nursing home and suddenly these rules are placed on him. I believe that the rights of individuals who want to share the remaining years of their life in a nursing home with people who share the same value system and culture are being denied and, therefore, everyone is brought down to the same common denominator. Of course, these issues will be debated when we raise them when affirmative resolution has to be taken and I will continue my remarks then.
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australian farmers generally are held in high regard throughout the world and South Australian farmers in particular are regarded as outstanding.
—Order! Senator Chapman, would you formally move the motion?
—Wasn't that written on your piece of paper?
—I do not need it written on a piece of paper. On behalf of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill), I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes with concern the State Bank of South Australia's Rural Report for August 1990, which shows that gross farm income from 1989-90 to 1990-91 in South Australia is expected to plummet 49 per cent in relation to wheat, and 31 per cent in relation to both barley and wool;

(b) notes that the above calculations assume that the rate of exchange of $A/$US is $0.70, and that the current rate of exchange is in fact around $0.81, which means that gross farm incomes from wheat will drop 56 per cent, barley 40 per cent and wool 41 per cent;
(c) further notes that the United Farmers and Stockowners of S.A. Incorporated attributes the disastrous state of the South Australian rural economy to the Federal Government's monetary policy; and
(d) calls on the Federal Government to adopt a monetary policy which will give Australian exporters a reasonable chance to compete internationally.

Australian farmers-as I was saying before that interjection from Senator Bolkus, who would know nothing about Australian farmers-are generally held in high regard throughout the world and South Australian farmers in particular are regarded as outstanding: outstanding for their economic efficiency and outstanding for their expertise in dry land farming, which has maximised the productive capacity of the driest State in the driest continent.

In view of this well deserved reputation, one would expect them to be reaping favourable economic rewards. Instead, we see our farmers plunged into the worst financial crisis since the Depression of the 1930s, a crisis which could well match that Depression as it continues to develop under this Government's inaction in its detrimental impact on farmers and rural communities but ultimately, and also importantly, in its detrimental impact on the whole Australian community. The whole Australian community will suffer if our farmers do, because farm production and farm income remain significant sources of wealth creation in this country.

Unlike so many sectors of the Australian economy, of which the car industry and the textile, clothing and footwear industries are the most notable, Australian farmers are efficient and, when on a level playing field, internationally competitive. Being first and foremost exporters, they are price takers, not price setters as are industries which supply Australian domestic consumers.

Farmers have to meet the world market price for their commodities. By and large, they can do this and remain viable-even against the subsidised farm produce of Europe and America. By and large, they can remain viable despite having to carry around their necks the ravaging effects of periodic drought. By and large, they can remain viable, despite having to carry the cost of the excessive protection given to some sectors of Australian secondary industry around their necks, to the tune of about $8,000 per farm, as well as having to bear the cost of matching, under our centralised wages system, the wage levels which these protected industries are able to pay.

Our farmers can cope with all of these disadvantages, but they cannot remain viable in the face of the long term economic mismanagement of this Hawke Labor Government. This economic mismanagement is most in evidence in its reliance on the single instrument of high interest rates.

Farmers, not high interest rates, are Australia's best hope of overcoming our massive foreign debt, which grows monthly because we import more than we export. Certainly, over time, high interest rates have dampened demand for goods and services, including imports; but they have also destroyed Australia's productive capacity, especially that of our rural producers. Even with falling demand, accompanying falling production causes our trade deficit to remain, and so our foreign debt keeps escalating. We have all the pain and no gain.

The pain for South Australian farmers has been clearly spelt out in a recent letter from Don Pfitzner, the President of the United Farmers and Stockowners of South Australia, which is, of course, South Australia's peak rural group. He sent that letter to South Australian senators. The letter and the figures that other bodies have produced recently spell out the enormity of this crisis on the South Australian rural scene. The figures are disturbing and damning. The State Bank of South Australia, in its rural report of August 1990, has produced figures some of which are contained in the wording of the motion I read a few moments ago. These figures paint a shocking picture. The figures show that gross farm income this financial year is forecast to fall by 49 per cent from last year.

As the motion indicates, wheat, barley and wool incomes will be particularly hard hit, not to mention the loss of the live sheep trade to the Middle East. These massive falls in income will hit South Australian farmers-and, indeed, all South Australians-relatively harder than the rest of Australia, because although South Australia has only 9 per cent of Australia's population, we produce 19 per cent of Australia's wheat, 40 per cent of its barley, and 50 per cent of its live sheep exports, which are incorporated in South Australia producing 15 per cent of Australia's overall sheepmeat products. Because of that relatively higher proportion of Australia's production compared with our relatively lower proportion of Australia's population, this dramatic fall in income will have a much more severely detrimental effect on South Australia than on the rest of Australia.

Let us remember that these forecasts are based on an assumption that the rate of exchange between the Australian dollar and the United States dollar will be 70c. Today's rate is about 83c-with a rise of 2c even since this motion was drafted just a few weeks ago. That means gross income will drop even more. The State Bank now says that South Australia could lose $534m in earnings from wheat, barley and wool alone in this financial year. What is more important is that each of these gross figures is the sum of, and reflects, a decline in incomes for individual farms and farming families. The State Bank's Rural Banking Division predicts South Australian farmers will make no profit this financial year and will be forced to use savings or increase debt to maintain their operations. In other words, at best, South Australian farmers will have no income. That is what no profit means: no income; no wages for the farmer; having to live on past savings. It is not surprising, after reading this report, to also hear that farmers are angry and are taking action. How many trade unionists would work for a year for no wage?

TALK.START.PARA: —Not many.

—None at all, of course. They even want to be paid when they go out on strike. No wonder South Australian farmers have warned that they may join New South Wales to move to bring down the Hawke Government because of its gross mishandling of this economy. No wonder the United Farmers and Stockowners has said that the rural crisis in South Australia is the beginning of the 1990s depression. No wonder Don Pfitzner, in his letter to us, says:

SPEECH.PARA: The situation is deteriorating extremely fast, and I have very real fears for the future of many farmers and their families as well as the South Australian economy.
I quote further from Mr Pfitzner's letter as follows:
Even the `blue chip' farming areas of the State are suffering from the full impact of the collapse in commodity prices.

I understand that a bank branch in one of the major regional centres of South Australia's south-eastern district-which is one of the State's most productive areas-has determined that 52 of its 76 rural clients are not viable under current commodity prices. It is estimated that each 1c rise in the value of the Australian dollar costs farm exporters $150m in total. Quite simply, the present excessively high value of the Australian dollar-a value which is unjustified by this country's wealth and productivity under this Hawke Labor Government's mismanagement-makes our produce uncompetitive in world markets and, therefore, the domestic market, in turn, is awash with primary produce and growers are receiving less than the cost of production for many commodities. Again, I quote from Mr Pfitzner's letter as follows:
Across the whole range of commodities which we produce in our State-from grain to grapes, from citrus to wool-we are seeing our export markets deteriorate and our farm gate prices fall dramatically.
In the concluding paragraphs of Mr Pfitzner's letter are included damning indictments of this Hawke Labor Government as follows:
We are convinced that the desperate state of South Australian agriculture has been brought about by the Federal Government's monetary policy.
Later, it says:
In addition, the Federal Government's monetary policy has meant that farmers' debts have increased as they struggle to meet the repayments resulting from high interest rates.

I request that you exercise all the influence you can upon the Federal Government and in particular the Treasurer, to introduce a monetary policy which will substantially improve the terms of trade for South Australian Farmers.

The motion which I have moved on behalf of the coalition today is, in part, our way of fulfilling that request. We can only hope that it will not fall on deaf ears, but recent Government decisions give us little cause for hope.

In the August Budget this Government actually reduced the value of assets under which farmers or their children are eligible for Austudy, the family allowance supplement or the family allowance from the previous $600,000 to $400,000, $200,000 and $300,000 respectively. For those on salaries, $57,000 income is the cut-off point for family allowance, and it varies upwards if there are more children. There is no way that a $300,000 farm would generate $57,000 in income per year even in good times, let alone in the present parlous situation. Also, there is no concession allowed in terms of the assets test related to the number of children in a family.

This Government maintains a disadvantage of 10 to 15 per cent for Australian farmers compared with their American counterparts with regard to fuel prices. This Government continues its failure to reduce farm production costs by dragging the chain-as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) so aptly put it-on reducing protection, by failing to deregulate the labour market and failing to get rid of inefficiencies in rail transport, the wharves and coastal shipping. Most important of all, this Government refuses to budge from its reliance on high interest rates, despite their proven failure shown through theoretical analysis by experts such as Professor Ron Bewley and, most importantly, by their clearly demonstrated failure in practice.

This Government should urgently introduce several measures to help alleviate the ills its policies have caused. These include immediate interest rate relief, the revision of taxation laws which disadvantage farmers, a drastic reassessment of welfare spending priorities, and a coordinated approach to reducing wage pressures. It should ease access to family benefits, especially Austudy benefits, for rural producers and their families who may be asset rich but are income poor.

The South Australian State Labor Government must also take positive initiatives. With a whole range of options open to it to provide producers with some relief, the Bannon Government failed dismally in its announcements yesterday after promising a package to deal with the crisis. All it has done is to increase to $150,000 from $100,000 the limit on loans available at 12 per cent interest under the rural adjustment scheme. But after three years these concessional rates revert to commercial rates.

Let us remember that the Bannon Labor Government in South Australia has increased State taxation more than any other State this year-by a massive 18.2 per cent. These are taxes which, in the main, unlike income tax, farmers will have to pay irrespective of their financial situation and irrespective of their income. So, although national and overseas factors are largely to blame for the crisis, the State Government's response to the situation is quite inadequate. Furthermore, Mr Bannon, as Federal President of the Australian Labor Party, has failed to bring his influence to bear on his Federal colleagues in any effective way.

In contrast, the Liberal Party both nationally and in South Australia has the policies which will improve the lot of farmers. At the Federal level, a tighter fiscal policy, privatisation, tariff reform, tax changes and so-called micro-economic reform will markedly improve the economic climate for producers, in particular exporters. Our State colleagues in the Liberal Party have produced a five-point plan to alleviate the present rural crisis and are convening a crisis meeting of South Australian rural leaders.

But rural South Australia and, indeed, rural Australia, cannot wait for the next Federal and State elections, which will undoubtedly give us the opportunity to implement these initiatives. Urgent action is needed now. It is time for this Government to swallow its pride, admit that it is wrong and take up our proposals. Unless it does, rural Australia will simply not survive until we get the opportunity to do something for it after the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the motion before the Senate, which has been moved by Senator Chapman and which quotes the United Farmers and Stockowners of SA Inc. and claims a disastrous situation in the South Australian rural economy. That is the gist of the motion. It goes on to claim that Federal Government monetary policy is somehow responsible for the decline in rural production values.

SPEECH.PARA: There is absolutely nothing in this motion about the prices of rural commodities. That is the first thing that has to be said. Of course, the prices of a number of rural products are down on world markets. There has been a worldwide reduction in commodity prices. The motion says absolutely nothing about world production levels for a number of commodities. Of course, at the moment agricultural production levels are very high.

The motion that is before us has more to do with the current state of conservative politics in South Australia than with the rural situation facing Australia. In fact, it is really about the rivalry and the battles going on on the conservative side of politics between the wets and the dries and between the city Liberals and the country Liberals. That is what this motion is all about. One does not have to be a Rhodes scholar to work that out.

I get around South Australia very regularly. I am a regular visitor to many rural centres in South Australia, and I know that Senator Chapman is in great trouble in the Liberal Party over his stand on wheat deregulation. One does not have to go to too many towns in South Australia to find out that Senator Chapman's very vocal and strident position last year proposing deregulation of the wheat industry went down very badly in a host of country branches of the Liberal Party in South Australia. Senator Bolkus, the Minister in the chamber at present, knows very well that that is true-that the reason behind Senator Chapman's moving this motion tonight is that he is in deep trouble in his own branches in South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you sorry for him?

—I am not sorry for him at all. This motion also has a lot to do with the current rivalry in South Australia on the conservative side of politics between the Liberal Party and the National Party. There is no doubt about that. Senator Chapman was very pointed in talking about the `Liberal Party's' five point plan on the so-called rural crisis. There is no reference to the National Party's involvement in this document; he was talking purely about the position of the Liberal Party in South Australia on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I travel very regularly to the rural areas of South Australia. I know that, for example, the Liberal Party on the Eyre Peninsula is still licking its wounds after the drubbing it got in the Flinders electorate last year when Mr Peter Blacker, the National Party member for Flinders, whom the Liberals had great hopes of removing from office, triumphed yet again on the Eyre Peninsula. One of the Liberal Party's top drawer glamour candidates hit the fence in that election.

The moving of this motion in this Senate is really part of a drama that is being played out in South Australia between the big city Liberals and the country Liberals and between the Liberal Party and the National Party in the rural constituencies. That is what is going on and that is why this motion has been moved tonight. It does not talk about world commodity prices or world production levels; it has just been moved in here in an attempt to wave a flag saying, `We are the Liberals. We oppose the Federal Government and we are trying to stand up for the farmers in the Australian community'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Not only is Senator Maguire showing utter contempt for the farmers who are suffering from the current economic situation, but also his speech is totally irrelevant to the motion before the Senate. I respectfully ask you to direct him to address his comments to the motion.
—There is no point of order. I call Senator Maguire.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. The Government is well aware of the falls in rural prices. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) made a major speech in Parliament on Tuesday talking about the price falls in the wheat and wool components of the rural sector. We are well aware of and concerned about the falling values of production in those industries. But I will not on behalf of the Government support a motion of this type which has been moved as part of the continuing drama on the conservative side of politics in South Australia. We on the Government side are well aware that rural proceeds are down, particularly in the wheat and wool sectors.

SPEECH.PARA: I might say that I am not in trouble in the wheat belt over my stand on wheat deregulation, but I know that Senator Chapman is in real trouble in the country branches of the South Australian Liberal Party. I get around. My sources in the Liberal Party keep me informed on what is going on in South Australia.

The key problem facing farmers in Australia is that world production levels, particularly for cereals, are very high. There have been record harvests in the Northern Hemisphere and a very big harvest in the United States of America, one of the major producers of wheat.

I cite an article in this week's edition of the London Economist magazine, which is not a magazine from which I normally quote or read greatly. However, I did see in an article on United States farming a reference to `bumper harvests of corn and wheat'. There has been a major crop in the United States and big crops in the major producing countries, so prices are not very high. Australia, of course, is a price-taker; we cannot set world cereals prices, and consequently that has been a major reason for the fall in Australian prices.

In regard to wool-and the wool component of the rural sector is the one that is causing the most concern at the moment-we all know the history of the wool industry in recent times. The fall in wool income colours the whole farm picture. It is estimated, according to information available to the Government, that some 58 per cent of the total loss of production in Australia's rural sector is due to the one industry's decline, and that is the wool industry. The current position in that industry does not reflect Government monetary policy or exchange rates specifically, as has been referred to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on!

—Not overwhelmingly. It reflects decisions made by the industry itself three years ago, and the setting of prices that could not be sustained. That is the reality of what is happening in the wool industry, and now we have had an enormous decline in prices.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me talk about some of the things that the Hawke Government has done for the rural sector, because they are very important. The conservative forces in Australia tend very conveniently to forget some of the major reforms that have occurred. For example, I can well remember a time in the early 1980s when double digit inflation faced Australia's farmers. There were double digit farm cost rises under the Fraser-Howard Government, and I well remember them. Under the Liberal Government in the early 1980s farmers were facing costs that were rising at 11, 12 and 13 per cent a year. We had inflationary costs at that level, which hit the farm sector. At the same time, as Senator Chapman pointed out, our farmers are price-takers for their products; their output prices are set by somebody else. But under the Liberal Government in the early 1980s, they were facing double digit cost rises, and that is a matter of record. We do not have double digit price rises in Australia now.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are coming up.

—We do not, and it is a fact. The Liberals would pretend that inflation is still at the levels they left the Australian farmers facing. We do not have 11, 12 and 13 per cent cost rises facing farmers now. In fact, when one looks at overall indexes of inflation, one sees that they are more like 7 to 8 per cent in terms of cost rises.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the other things that the Liberals very conveniently forget is Labor's enormous achievement in reducing disruptions to the shipping of farmers' products to markets. We had enormous problems in this country before the Hawke Government was elected in regard to industrial disputation. This afternoon I went and refreshed my memory as to the numbers of days lost due to industrial disputes under the Liberal-National administration. I thought the figure I had in my mind was right-two million days lost to industrial disputes in 1982-83 under a Liberal administration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that when Hawke was President of the ACTU?

—No, he was in Parliament. He was the member for Wills in the Federal Parliament at the time. But I would point out that we do not have a situation now in which two million days are being lost annually owing to industrial disputes, two million days which disrupted the movement of our wheat and our wool crops to world markets. I am sure Senator Panizza was complaining about those things as a farm activist in Western Australia. The number of days lost due to industrial disputes in the last year for which figures are available was not two million, but in fact had been cut by 35 per cent to 1.3 million. There is a very tangible achievement of the Hawke Labor Government in terms of keeping down the cost of shipping our farm products to export markets. Those are very important steps.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to this motion moved by Senator Chapman, which is very critical of the exchange rate-the international parity of the Australian dollar-the Government is certainly aware of concerns in all sectors of the economy about the level of the Australian dollar. However, it is fact that the dollar is high at the moment. That in turn helps contain inflation. It is no accident, I think, that one of the reasons why it is helpful to have a relatively high dollar-and I do not want to see it continue permanently, I might say-is that it does help to contain inflationary pressures in a domestic market by helping to keep down the price of imports. That is a fact of life. Although that high dollar might not be helpful to farm incomes, it is certainly helping to contain the growth of costs. That is the other side of the coin. One cannot have it both ways and say that one is losing on both sides of the equation. I know, for example, that many of the pesticides and insecticides used in the farming sector are imported. I would like to have a look at some of the prices for them, but certainly, if one wants to push up their prices, one will have a low dollar rather than a high dollar. That is a fact of life.

The motion also blames the Federal Government's monetary policy for the position in the South Australian agricultural sector. I presume that Senator Chapman is referring to interest rates. If he is, I agree that interest rates are high at the moment; but the Government has interest rates at current levels for very good reasons: to ensure that the total level of spending in the Australian community is brought more into line with total levels of production in Australia to stop an overflow, a spill-over of buying power into imported products. That is the reason interest rates are high.

The reality is that if interest rates were not at present levels we would have a bigger balance of payments deficit. What do those opposite want? If I can just ask a rhetorical question: what does Senator Chapman want? He wants to have lower interest rates, it would seem. Does he therefore want to have a bigger balance of payments deficit? That is one of the things I would like to ask him. Certainly it is a fact that the Liberal Party does hold the record for having the biggest balance of payments deficit as a percentage of gross domestic product. That is the reality. The Liberals hold the record of having a deficit in 1981-82 of 5.9 per cent of gross domestic product. Does Senator Chapman want to repeat that? The Government has reduced interest rates on four occasions. This calendar year there have been four rounds of cuts in interest rates-major falls have occurred.

Paragraph (d) of this motion calls for the introduction of an appropriate monetary policy to help us compete internationally. I am paraphrasing paragraph (d), but that is what it is really saying-we want an appropriate monetary policy to help us compete internationally. I presume that means that Senator Chapman wants an interest rate level which would help us reduce the value of the Australian dollar compared with other currencies and would therefore be a spur to exports. I presume that is the logic. A lower Australian dollar will probably raise the cost of production. Imported products will go up in price. It is voodoo economics to say those sorts of things. But I presume that Senator Chapman means that by lowering the interest rates one will lower the value of the dollar and therefore help exports.

That type of link is rather naive. I simply refer to the facts about this calendar year. There is no clear link between levels of interest rates and the level of the Australian dollar. At the beginning of this year the Australian dollar was worth US79c, and at the time cash interest rates were 18 per cent. So 18 per cent interest was in conjunction with a 79c dollar. But now we have got cash interest rates of 14 per cent, but the Australian dollar is not 79c; it is above 80c. So at the same time as interest rates have fallen by four percentage points from 18 per cent at the beginning of the year to 14 per cent now, the Australian dollar has not gone down; it has gone higher.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the dinner break this evening I was expressing concern about falling levels of production in the rural sector, particularly in the wheat and wool sectors, due to international factors, particularly the increase in world production levels and consequent falls in world prices, which I believe will have a more profound effect on the value of rural production than will interest rates, the subject of this motion tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: I am opposing this motion that has been moved by Senator Chapman. Senator Chapman is one of the most vocal deregulators in the Senate. He has been very strong in his support for the deregulation of the wheat market, and it is fair to say that he wishes to see market forces at work in other markets of the economy, including the labour market.

I turn to the part of this motion which refers to the rate of exchange-the value of the Australian dollar compared with other currencies. Over the years, those on the conservative side of politics have called repeatedly for a floating Australian dollar. That is what they have sought time and time again. They said that it would be appropriate for supply and demand to set the level of the Australian dollar. They have said that market forces should be used to set the value of the Australian dollar on the world exchanges. In other words, they did not want a pegged or fixed exchange rate for the Australian dollar. That was basically the view of those on the conservative side of politics.

Despite all that rhetoric about deregulation and market forces, we find in this motion tonight that Senator Chapman does not want the particular level of the Australian dollar that applies at this time and place. He does not want an Australian dollar at the levels that we currently see. He is saying in moving this motion tonight on the farm sector that the current level of the Australian dollar is not suitable. But, as I have pointed out, conservative politicians for years called for the introduction of market forces, for supply and demand to set prices in markets-in other words, to set prices for a range of items, including the value of Australia's currency compared to other countries. We see in this motion moved this evening that conservative politicians do not want to see market forces being left to set the value of the Australian dollar as it currently is.

I want to refer to a number of other initiatives that the Hawke Government has taken in regard to the farm sector. We were the nation which instigated the so-called Cairns Group of traders, countries which are predominantly producers of commodities. We sponsored the formation of that Group to try to increase the bargaining power of those countries whose products hitherto had been set by international forces rather than by the countries themselves. By taking that action of convening the Cairns Group of producers, we were addressing the major problem of the rural sector, which is the levels of commodity prices and the fact that we have not been able to influence the levels of commodity prices faced by Australian producers. Also in convening the Cairns Group of countries, we were taking action to hit corrupted agricultural markets, to hit corrupted trading practices whereby particularly the European Community and the United States of America subsidised exports of commodities, especially agricultural commodities. We took action; we did not simply complain about it.

Australia has also been heavily involved in the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations. We have been fairly central in having agricultural products put on the agenda for that round of trade negotiations, and seeing trade not simply as the movement of industrial products between countries but as including agricultural products as well. I might also refer again to that article in this week's Economist magazine from London headed up the `Wrath of America's Farmers'. It refers to threats by the United States of America to walk out of the Uruguay Round of global trade talks. It is very interesting indeed to see that the United States seems to be becoming concerned at last about the effect and impact of subsidies in agricultural markets around the world. I quote that article:
America may not be bluffing when it threatens to walk out of the Uruguay Round of trade talks if there is no deal to cut farm subsidies.

That is certainly a very interesting quote. It is certainly very hopeful and maybe, at long last, after repeated efforts by the Australian Government, the United States Administration itself is getting the message about the harm done by subsidies for farming products on world markets.

Another major initiative of the Hawke Government has been the introduction of the first ever program at the Federal level for soil conservation. Many on this side of the House, I suspect, would say that the need for soil conservation because of the degrading of Australia's farmland is one of the major environmental problems facing this country. We were the first government in the history of this nation at the Federal level to provide funds for soil conservation. For decades the Liberals and the National Party did absolutely nothing about this very pressing problem. The soil blew away in our most fertile farming areas and it became a major environmental problem, but it took a Labor government to act on the question of soil conservation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish! The first soil conservation policy in this country came from a coalition government.

—I think it is past Senator O'Chee's bedtime. I repeat: the first ever soil conservation program at the national level in this country was introduced and implemented by a Labor gov- ernment, not by a conservative government; and Senator O'Chee had better check his facts on that one.
—Which Labor Government?
—The Hawke Labor Government, Senator Short.
—That is not true.

—There was no soil conservation program at the Federal level in this country until the Hawke Labor Government was elected. Those on the other side of the House pretend that they somehow have an interest in the farming sector.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I do not really like to intervene on statements by members of the Government opposite. But really, when a senator is saying something that is patently not correct--
—Order! Senator Short, which standing order are you complaining under? I call Senator Maguire.

—I repeat that the funding for the first ever soil conservation program at the national level in Australia was introduced not by a Liberal government and not by a National Party government, but in fact by a Labor government; and that is the record. That is the fact and that is the reality. Opposition senators can try to prove that I am wrong. I also point out that this Government introduced a full excise rebate on the use of diesel fuel on farms. We have provided for reductions in excise tax for those who use diesel fuel on farms-a major initiative by this Government for the farming sector.

SPEECH.PARA: As this motion is about the record of the South Australian State Government in regard to the farming sector, I note that yesterday the State Minister for Agriculture, Mr Lynn Arnold, announced some measures to help remedy the situation in the rural sector. I note, for example, that he has increased the maximum lending limits for the rural adjustment scheme up to $50,000, and funds will be available at a 12 per cent interest rate for three years under that particular scheme.

There we have it. The rural sector, which we all know is a very cyclical sector, has its troughs and its peaks. No doubt continuing striving by Australian farmers to produce efficiency will help protect them more against the cycles. It is most important that farmers continue to make efficiency gains on their properties. They have had a good track record and they will have to continue to look for efficiency gains.

I have some figures which show that returns from farmers vary enormously per hectare. That is something that ought to be looked at more closely. The figures suggest that returns per hectare are as low as $43 for some farms and as high as $245 for others. I presume that the farms are in similar climatic areas and that the samples chosen are of broadly similar areas. As a result, I think we ought to be focusing on making sure that those with the lowest returns per hectare come up closer to the average and improve beyond the average. That would seem to be one area where we can move for better returns for our farming sector.

In conclusion, efficiency gains for farmers have been a key in the past. They have been achieved by Australia's farmers in the past and they certainly will be a key to future prosperity in the rural sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Hill's motion, moved by Senator Chapman, and to remind the Senate that, as someone who lives and works in rural Australia, I can tell honourable senators that it is hurting out there-far more so than most Australians living in the city realise. I speak as the wife of a farmer, the mother of a farmer, and a person who pays the bills for the farm workers on our property, so I know what I am talking about.

SPEECH.PARA: I have listened to Senator Maguire talking about what Labor has done. He has not mentioned the exorbitant interest rates that farmers have to put up with under the Labor Government. He has not talked about the big overseas debt that we have acquired under the Labor Government. He has not talked about the high fuel prices that we have under the Labor Government, which it does nothing to try to bring down.

The motion before us notes that gross farm income in South Australia is expected to plummet in relation to wheat, wool and barley. It also condemns the Federal Government for its adherence to a policy which means that Australia's commodities are uncompetitive in export markets, with every 1c rise in the value of the Australian dollar costing Australian farm exporters an estimated $150m. It also calls on the Government to adopt a monetary policy which will give Australian exporters a reasonable chance to compete internationally. I can tell honourable senators that it is not only in South Australia that farmers will be facing massive reductions in incomes. We are facing what is becoming quite commonly referred to in the press as our rural crisis all across the country. The profound shift in Australia's export earnings from farm product to other economic sectors has left primary producers with shrinking incomes. The far-reaching changes that this shift is engendering are by no means complete, although they are being speeded up by historically high interest rates and technology's impact on areas such as the fibre market. These changes mean that we cannot afford simply to sit back and wait for the farm sector to be virtually depopulated. It is in everyone's interest to control the process, to ameliorate its worst effects, and to approach the whole issue with a balance of sympathy and energy.

There is no doubt that rural producers are suffering. They are hit by fuel pricing policies which might make a great deal of sense in bureaucratic compact Canberra but which add intolerably to the cost of living in remote parts of the country. These fuel pricing policies mean that the Federal Government Treasury coffers and the exchequers of States which impose fuel taxes are garnering rich profits from the crisis in the global oil market. This Government still believes that we need world parity pricing to demonstrate that we are fair dinkum about being part of the real world. Most people, in contrast, would argue that the national interest demands that we should seek to minimise the impact that Saddam Hussein can have on our pockets through petrol prices and their effects on other costs.

Today farmers are also being made to face financial risks associated with fluctuating commodity prices. Down the track some of them face virtual closure of their markets through changing demands and the advance of technology. Urban Australians-the great majority of this country's people-have very little grasp of the realities of making a living in the bush. To them, the country is a place to drive through on the way to a holiday. The problems of sheep farmers in the est, like those of Longreach grazier Ron Button, which were featured recently in the Courier-Mail, are gross and intractable. Mr Button runs 9,000 sheep on a 12,000 hectare property, a business his family has been in for a century. The next year will be very hard for him. Rising production and commodity prices, coupled with diving wool prices, are expected to reduce the family's income by 30 per cent. Imagine the hullabaloo if workers on award wages were to be told that their pay packets were to be slashed by nearly one third over the next 12 months. I can just imagine what honourable senators opposite would be saying about that.

Where it has not already fallen prey to agribusiness, the farm sector is very much a family affair. Yet such farms rarely make enough profit to pay each productive family member a living wage. To that extent farms are small businesses and should be seen as such by the tax man and the bureaucracy. Small wonder in these circumstances that farmers are getting restive.

According to the President of the Queensland Farmers Federation, they are also getting ready to take to the streets. Mr Lyndsay Hall, the President of the QFF, says that Queensland farmers will back a move by the National Farmers Federation (NFF) for direct action to highlight the fact that thousands of their colleagues are going broke. Yet we hear members of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) saying that there is no rural crisis. An interview with the United Graziers Association president, Mr Bill Bonthrone, reported in a recent newspaper article stated:
Mr Bonthrone told a UGA council meeting in Brisbane that the rural crisis was driving conservative, law-abiding citizens to call for militant action.
`The anger is now so deep that only the catalyst is needed for an emotional explosion from the family. It could be fuel prices and interest rates that provide it,' Mr Bonthrone said.
This Government and many of its members representing rural areas in my own State of Queensland have not recognised that there is a crisis in rural Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!
—It is a shame. Only last week the Chairman of the ALP Caucus primary industries committee, the honourable member for Hinkler, Mr Brian Courtice, told The Australian Rural Times:

SPEECH.PARA: I certainly do not believe or agree rural Australia is in crisis or about to collapse, but there is no doubt wool and wheat have difficulties to overcome.
Well, it was nice of him to make that observation.
