TALK.START.PARA: — No wonder the farmers hate him.

—I do not think that Labor politicians will be very popular in the electorate of Hinkler. Mr Courtice said that he would be telling the NFF at its forthcoming meeting with the Caucus committee that the Government's monetary policy was correct and that any easing of the policy could see demand go through the roof again.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Rob Hulls, the honourable member for Kennedy, is a man who should know better than most ALP members about the plight of those in rural Australia as his electorate covers most of north-west Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not interested; he will be there for only three years.

—I am sure he will, because I am sure that the people will realise that he is not interested in rural Queensland. He rejected suggestions that rural Australia was at crisis point and, instead, maintained that the present economic policies were working.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Lavarch, the honourable member for Fisher, the electorate that adjoins Wide Bay, the electorate in which I live, said the suggestion that the rural economy was going to collapse as a result of high interest rates was an oversimplification. Perhaps Mr Lavarch should speak to his Prime Minister, who only today finally admitted that his Government's high interest rate policy was causing undue hardship and damage. Also, there was an item in today's news where South Australian backbencher, Lloyd O'Neil, said that many farmers might be asset rich but income poor, particularly with this years rural downturn. He is certainly telling the truth.

Beyond doubt, the farm sector must live with the strictures that apply to all components of Australian society. Nationally, we are uncompetitive in world terms. We are paying for past delusions. We must, though, recognise the need to regulate the effects of fast moving change on sectors of the economy which impinge heavily on individual lives. Recently there was a letter in the Brisbane Courier-Mail and I will read some of it to honourable senators. It contains the comments of any ordinary Australian fed up with what is happening to his country, and it is a plea for the Government to finally recognise the mess we are in. The letter reads:
I have had enough of watching the Australian Treasurer, Paul Keating, telling us his economic policies are working:
We have:
* Record current account deficits.
* The highest continuous interest rates historically, which are doing irreparable damage not only to small business, but to grazing and farming industries as well as the nation.
* The greatest number of small business collapses in our history outside the great Depression.
* An Australian dollar so high it has priced the export industries off world markets and dramatically reduced our opportunities to trade.
* A national debt which has, in only a few years, escalated out of all proportion to $140 billion.

* The nation's greatest single export earner-the wool industry-with its confidence shattered by the unbelievable government decision to reduce the floor price against the advice of the Australian Wool Corporation, Wool Council of Australia, the vast majority of processors around the world and 96 per cent of Queensland wool growers.
* A wheat industry about to receive the lowest first payment for many years.

* A beef industry struggling for survival, for although it has been receiving high prices (which are now falling fairly dramatically), it is being smothered by escalating costs and government charges.
* A desperate sell off of the Commonwealth Bank to prop up the incompetent financial performance of the Victorian Labor Government.
If this rot doesn't stop, the nation will never recover. We will have lost the lucky country.

This Government cannot claim that the rural crisis has only just hit. It has been warned continuously for years, and the evidence to show just what is happening outside our major cities has been around for quite some time. As long ago as last year we read of disturbing figures which showed that farmers were losing money fast, with costs increasing at twice the rate of income. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics September quarter index last year showed an average of 1.2 per cent increase on prices received, or income, whereas this was heavily outweighed by a 2.1 per cent increase in prices paid. This is under a Labor government which then has the effrontery to claim that farmers are pleased with the Federal Government.

I do not know what criteria the Government would use for such a claim, but I can assure you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that if your income is being steadily eroded at the rate where the costs to earn it are twice the rate of the actual income, then I am sure that if you are a thinking Australian, and I know that you are, Mr Acting Deputy President, you would know that you were going backwards and you would not be too happy with that situation. Perhaps some honourable senators opposite would be happy to see their income eroding as quickly as that! There is not much point producing a product if it cannot be sold profitably.

Similarly, it is not much use to so rationalise our rural sector that we eventually see the demise of the family farmer-the person who spends unrecognised hours and efforts producing that end product. The Government has often made much of the fact that its major endeavours were to encourage the growth of an adaptable and efficient primary industries and energy sector. It is often when assessing the rural industries that we talk only in terms of how much they have contributed to Australia's growth and not the effort that has been made to achieve those exports. But it is here that I want to point out that in the goal to achieve these low cost internationally competitive industries the Government has to be aware that it could be killing the goose that lays the golden egg.

I am referring not only to some of the major decisions the Government has taken in the past few years which have had a direct impact on primary industries such as wool, wheat, sugar, and the fishing industries, but also to the policies which this Government is continuously maintaining, such as crippling high interest rates and excessive fuel costs which have had adverse effects on the man on the land. We never heard a word about those from Senator Maguire when he was speaking earlier. If in the process to achieve cost efficient industries we push the small family farmer off the land, in the long run we are serving no really good purpose for Australia.

We should be ever vigilant that we do not allow ideology on economic issues and crass politics to misplace the needs of people. This is what is happening in many industries today, and it is at the expense of one of the most important sections of our community-the economic survival of the small family farmer. I have very much pleasure in supporting the motion that was moved earlier by Senator Chapman.
Debate (on motion by Senator Richardson) adjourned.
(Quorum formed)

DEBATE.TITLE: MEETINGS OF ESTIMATES AND STANDING COMMITTEES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This morning Senator Hill asked for the Government's plans for the programming of committees tomorrow. I recognise that there are honourable senators who are members of more than one of the committees which propose to meet tomorrow, given that we have Estimates committees as well as standing committee meeting. I have therefore consulted with the relevant chairmen of those committees, and with Senator Hill, Senator Reid and Senator Coulter, to ensure that there is maximum convenience for all honourable senators involved.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government proposes that Estimates committees A and C proceed with their meetings at 9 a.m. tomorrow as arranged, as will the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for its consideration of the Privacy Amendment Bill. To accommodate Senator Walters in particular, the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs will not start its meeting on the Social Welfare Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill until 10.30 a.m. Senator Walters is a member of both Estimates Committee C and the Standing Committee on Community Affairs. She will be given priority at Estimates Committee C from 9 a.m. until 10.30 so that her questions can be dealt with there before the Community Affairs Committee meeting begins.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's a mistake.

—This is one time when such interjections are not helpful, Senator Schacht. Both Senator Walsh and Senator O'Chee belong to Estimates Committee A and the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, but they are both agreeable to those committees meeting concurrently. The Chairman of Estimates Committee A will be cooperative about Senator O'Chee's and Senator Walsh's questions if they need to return to an area of questioning because of having spent some time at the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee meeting.

SPEECH.PARA: The new system of referring Bills to committees is obviously causing some problems. As honourable senators would be aware, attempts are being made to reach agreement about some of the procedures needed to help us all adjust to the new system. I suggest that until those procedures are settled, the sensible compromise that I propose this evening should be satisfactory to all concerned and will ensure that the Estimates committee process can be finished in time for the planned reporting by Estimates committees on Thursday, 18 October and that there is a minimum delay in dealing with the Bills which have been referred to standing committees, given that the new system was proposed to expedite the consideration of legislation and assumed that committees would have to meet concurrently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I concede that the Acting Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Richardson) has consulted with me and others and I listened to what he said. In fact, he gave me the opportunity to read it during the suspension of the sitting for dinner. I regret to say that I do not regard his proposal as particularly helpful. It is a further demonstration that the Government's program is in shambles. This idea of allowing 1 1/2 hours at the beginning of the day to enable one senator to deal with his or her questions is simply an inappropriate way in which to deal with Estimates. Does that mean that the honourable senator is to range over the whole of that part of the portfolio area that remains? If that is so, clearly the Estimates will not be dealt with item by item as they arise and matters that may arise out of another senator's questions which could have been pursued-matters that may not have been known by the senator that has to leave to fit the Government's program elsewhere-may not be pursued. In my view, that is unsatisfactory.

SPEECH.PARA: Why could there not have been orderly planning that allowed the standing committees to meet at a time that was convenient? As I asked this morning, why could the Estimates Committee not have met last Wednesday night or alternatively next Wednesday night so we did not have this doubling up? Unfortunately, no satisfactory answer has been given to the Senate tonight. I do not intend to hold up debate now because an important debate is taking place on the rural crisis that is being faced in this country, but I do express my disappointment and say that, in our view, the answer that the Minister has given is not satisfactory. It has simply flowed from the Government's inability to get its program in proper order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Estimates Committee C has been given a very heavy workload. It has had to consider the estimates for the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories; the Department of Social Security; the Department of Community Services and Health; and the Department of Veterans' Affairs. We were given three days to complete that task and, of course, we were unable to do so. We were given an extra two days, but we were not given the same Minister. The Ministers that we normally have were unable to be present and we were shifted around from one Minister to another. Sometimes the Minister came in for an hour at a time. This was most unsatisfactory. It is not the fault of the Estimates Committee at all. The fault lies with the Government and the very heavy load that it gave the Estimates Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has said that it wants this new arrangement of sending Bills to standing committees to work. It seems to me that to date the Government has not given our committee even a full day to look at the Bill that is before us. There is no possibility of our task being accomplished in one day. The Government has taken away an hour and a half with its suggestion that the Estimates Committee sit prior to the sitting of the Senate standing committee. Estimates Committee C has been extremely cooperative as I am sure Senator Tate, if he were here, would acknowledge. With the Department of Veterans' Affairs we called only the Minister and four officers. I think we questioned the whole Department for only about 20 minutes. There were not a number of questions. We did not go through veterans' affairs in detail because we saw that we were unable to accomplish the task that the Government had set us in anywhere near the time allowed. We virtually scrubbed veterans' affairs from our agenda. As I say, the Committee has been particularly cooperative with the Government in that regard.

I ask the Acting Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Richardson), in all good faith at the moment: What is wrong with Estimates Committee C sitting on Wednesday night? It would at least give the Senate standing committee one full day, even though more time is required-and no doubt we will debate that some time later-and the standing committee would be able to start at 9 o'clock.

As the Minister knows, the Government has run out of legislation. Indeed, all the legislation ceased last Tuesday night at two minutes past 10. The next day, Wednesday, all sorts of odd legislation was dredged up for us to be able to open the doors of the Senate. Now we have reached the stage where the Estimates are encroaching on the Friday that the Senate determined, with its numbers, should be put aside for the standing committees to sit on. The standing committees not sitting for the full day will make a difference to those senators who wish to, and have a right to, visit those committee sittings. It will also make a big difference to any senator who wishes to attend the Estimates committees.

I believe that the arrangements stop the Senate standing committees having any real input or being considered in a serious manner by the Government, and I protest very strongly. Again I ask the Minister if he will arrange for the Estimates committee to sit on Wednesday night instead of tomorrow morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The processes by which Bills will be sent off to the standing committees admittedly is one which is in the process of development. But I remind the Senate that there have been meetings between representatives of all parties, there have been a number of documents circulated and those documents-certainly in relation to the Australian Democrats' consideration-have been considered at some length. We were under the impression that a pattern of classification of Bills was agreed to and that the processes by which Bills would be dealt with had also been agreed to and this was the pattern towards which we were moving.

SPEECH.PARA: Today the Selection of Bills Committee considered a number of pieces of legislation. The report which has just been tabled indicates that there are nine Bills which the Selection of Bills Committee, on which representatives of all parties sit, has agreed could go straight through the older type of processes in this chamber without being referred to a Standing committee.

There are two Bills which-I believe everybody in this chamber has known this for days-those of us in the Opposition and in the Democrats wanted to be dealt with under category C. If any senator in this chamber does not know what category C is, he or she has not been reading the literature that has been going around and has been substantially, I understood, agreed to. There are considerable controversial elements in both of those pieces of legislation and we certainly wish to have witnesses called and I understand that is the position of the Opposition.

Last night, in a meeting with Senator Richardson in relation to those Bills, he pointed out, quite rightly, that some clauses need start-up dates for 1 November. I pointed out to him that the clauses would need amendment because there was no way witnesses could be called this Friday, that there was simply not enough notice given. He indicated to me, and I would like him to confirm this, that with respect to those clauses amendments could be made so that the 1 November start-up date-I am not referring to the 1 January start-up date-could be put back, so that witnesses could be called.

I simply say to the Government that if it is not going to be fair in relation to the new system, if it is going to try to use its numbers in small committees to prevent the new system from working, as it was designed to work and as we understood it had been agreed it should work, I believe that we will simply come back into this chamber and we will send the Bills off to a committee. It will hold the old style committee hearings; there will be a calling for written submissions; the whole process will take months and the Government certainly will not get its legislation.

I put that on notice and I suggest that the Government start to consider this new process a little more considerately, particularly as it is not the fault of either the Democrats or the Opposition that we are running out of legislation. The Government controls legislation and it is the Government which has failed to bring legislation forward in adequate time. I ask the Minister: Is it not a fact that the 1 November start-up clauses cannot be accommodated, that these Bills cannot be dealt with under category C, and that the calling of witnesses cannot be accommodated within the next few weeks so that the Government can have its legislation within this session?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The first matter I want to address is the astonishing remark by Senator Coulter when he stated that the Government has not been fair to the new system. Senator Coulter early in his remarks said that a document had been circulated which indicated a coded procedure, A, B, C, D, for dealing with committees. That document is circulating. There is no final agreement about that document as yet. Nowhere in that document which is circulating in this chamber is there any mention of splitting a Bill and referring it to two or more committees.

SPEECH.PARA: That is where the Government has been dry gulched. In recent hours we have been dry gulched on it. That is an offensive remark, and the honourable senator ought to take that on board and examine where he and his party are going in developing and making this new system work. No new system will work if it is modified at every turn as we move through it.

I want to address some remarks to what Senator Walters had to say about the Estimates committee and the difficulty that she had, as a member of that Estimates committee, and indeed that other senators may have who may be interested in the affairs of that Estimates committee and the relevant standing committee. It is accepted that there is a problem with the number of departments that are allocated to Estimates Committee C and I understand that the Government and the respective Ministers are going to look at that and attempt to ensure that that situation does not develop again. It is a very weighty committee in terms of its portfolio responsibility. But it should not be forgotten that the Committee has been examining its reports and has been undertaking its inquiries for four long days--

TALK.START.PARA: —Five days.

—There was a fifth day allocated. I apologise; I was on the committee only for the last few days. I accept Senator Walters's interjection that it was five days. There was then a sixth day allocated. From memory, we met on 26 September and we were to meet on 27 September but, unfortunately, not all Committee members were available. That applied not only to Government senators but also to some Opposition senators. So it applied to each of us in turn. That extra sitting day had to be called off, but we did try to make some progress by sitting a little later on Tuesday night, 26 September. The Committee examined when it might meet again, remembering that 26 September was the first week of the two-week break that we had.

SPEECH.PARA: We endeavoured to utilise the remainder of that week or the following week, which was a break from the Parliament, but unfortunately, because of commitments, among other things, that senators had to standing committees of the Parliament which were undertaking inquiries throughout Australia, we were unable to do so. A week and a half of available time was lost. We then looked at the possibility of sitting on Monday of last week but unfortunately the shadow Cabinet meets on that day and the whole day was ruled out as an option as well. It was suggested that we could have met last Wednesday night, but the Committee determined that we should not meet last night.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?
—Ask the Committee members.
—No, we were never asked.
—I will answer Senator Walters's interjection. She was part of the discussion, as indeed was Senator Harradine for a short time, on these meeting times.
—When?

—On 26 September. I suggest it was about 1600 hours. I may be wrong by a few minutes here or there. That is just a rough recollection of when it happened. Estimates Committee C rejected a whole number of options and a whole number of possibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walters interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot hear Senator Walters; I am speaking. She will have to speak louder. I re-emphasise the point: Estimates Committee C did try to meet its obligations but, for a variety of reasons-and casting no stones-we were unable to do so until tomorrow, which was the agreed date by the Committee. So we are locked into that. We do have a reporting date determined by the Parliament. That reporting date is next Thursday. All of the Estimates committees have to report by that date.

SPEECH.PARA: The question was asked: Why can the Committee not meet on Wednesday night of next week? The Government would have no problems with that if it was sure that the Committee would finish its deliberations by 10 a.m. on Thursday of next week, and there is no guarantee of that. I assure honourable senators opposite that it has not been Government senators asking all the questions. I know that the Committee has some concern because a number of honourable senators have not been able to ask questions in the Committee. We have tried to accommodate them. We have leaned over backwards to do so.

When the Committee meets tomorrow and goes through its full deliberations until quarter to four tomorrow afternoon or five to four so that people can catch planes, it may be that it will still have to meet next Wednesday night and roll right through until 10 a.m. on Thursday. If there are any guarantees, we can fix it. There is a will to fix it. But can anybody give us a guarantee that this will be done? We on this side of the chamber could give some guarantees, and we could then deliver them. I am more than happy to sit down with Senator Reid and, indeed, Senator Richardson and Senator Hill to talk this through to see whether we can deliver on time. The challenge is for honourable senators opposite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I make a couple of comments in this debate on committees. The way things are going with the Standing Committee on Community Affairs, after our meeting that has just concluded, I really see no point in our meeting tomorrow. It may well be that this Estimates Committee can continue.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats and the Liberals attempted to get a set of standing orders for the Committee that would have permitted us to call witnesses. After all, the main reason we terminated the debate during its second reading, not letting it go to a vote, not letting everybody speak, was so that it could go to committee for a proper inquiry. In that Committee I moved a motion that all witnesses be called as required to provide written submissions or be asked to appear before the Committee. That was defeated. Therefore, that Committee has been set the task tomorrow of listening only to the Minister, possibly to the Department, and then only to any person whom we can ring at 9 o'clock in the morning demanding that that person attend, whether that person lives in Sydney or wherever.

The Democrats had hoped that we would be able to make the system work. We wanted only three people. At our earlier meeting today we had hoped to get out the requests to those people for a written submission. The vast majority of those submissions could simply have been recorded in Hansard as received. The information could have been taken on board as we made our decisions. However, that was not to be. We have spent today in two meetings, making effectively no real decisions on recalling anybody. We have lost an excellent opportunity to get this off the ground next Friday. I recommend that the Estimates Committee continue to meet because there is very little point in the other Committee meeting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I respond to what has just been said by Senator Lees. I have made numerous efforts to find exactly what the sticking point is on this legislation so that we could get a reasonable program. This has been done without a great deal of success in terms of what the Australian Democrats want.

SPEECH.PARA: I correct the impression that we were not going to allow witnesses; we said that we were perfectly willing to allow witnesses tomorrow. Some of those witnesses were in Canberra and could have been called on at short notice. But we were not prepared to take another week at least in order to complete this proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-We have just had our meeting. The motion put to us was that the only person to come before us be the Minister and that officers of his Department be allowed for his reference, not the Committee's-that the Minister alone come before us.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion put forward by Senator Lees asked that other witnesses be called as required and submissions sought. I do not have the exact words but the amendment put was that other witnesses be called as required; there were no numbers, no details as to where they live-just that other witnesses be called as required and that written submissions be sought. That was defeated by the Labor majority using the casting vote. It is very obvious that no outside witnesses, apart from the Minister, will be present at tomorrow's hearing.
We now have the situation of no witnesses being called. No-one knows it is on. Only the Minister, with officers at his behest, will be required. That does not suit the Democrats or the coalition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Devereux Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As a member of the Committee, I should like to set the record straight. What Senator Walters has just said does not truly reflect what occurred at the Committee tonight. Two motions were carried. Senator Walters, in a fit of pique, decided that she did not want to listen to the second motion. The first motion carried a set of procedures for tomorrow's meeting. The second motion agreed that witnesses would be called before the Committee as required tomorrow.

SPEECH.PARA: That is quite different from what has just been said by Senator Walters. She claimed that the Committee said that it would not hear any witnesses at all. Quite clearly-and a second motion was carried-the Committee agreed that witnesses would come before the Committee tomorrow. The members from our side of the Committee are quite prepared to sit on for as long as it takes to hear submissions from those witnesses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I make two points. First, the sort of procedure envisaged and foreshadowed by the Australian Democrats and the Opposition in discussion on this particular legislation has been covered in the document circulated, the spirit of which we were attempting to adhere to, both yesterday in other matters and today on this one.

SPEECH.PARA: In order to try to expedite that approach, Senator Lees developed a list of people whom she felt she would need to see to answer some of her concerns. Some of those people are not in Canberra. For whatever reason, the Committee was unable to accept that motion. It certainly was never up to the individual senator to make decisions about who would be called or whether anyone would be called. We certainly made an attempt to facilitate the work of the Committee.

Another committee has been going through the same procedure of deciding what it will do tomorrow. Last night it made those decisions, established its procedures, called its witnesses and will go through its procedures tomorrow. Whether it finishes tomorrow or not depends on how the committee's work proceeds. We were involved as a party in that process. I think we had a perfect right on this legislation, although the appropriate committees had not yet reported, to be anticipating in the spirit of the document that has been circulated. It was always clear what type of inquiry we were looking for.

It is disappointing that, although one committee can accept from our Party submissions on the witnesses it wants, can accept a different set of witnesses from the Opposition, can set up a timetable and can get it all done expeditiously and pretty efficiently, with negotiations between the parties and in the end the committee making the decision-which is exactly the process we were attempting to put in place with this piece of legislation; I have Senator Lees's list in front of me-unfortunately it has not worked in this case. As Senator Lees has said, we are of the view at this point that there really is not anything to be achieved in that committee tomorrow that would not be achieved in the chamber via the old system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I had hoped to avoid entering this debate, but I think I should just put into context some of the matters that Senator Powell has just raised. I am sorry to have to do that because I have been involved in discussions with her about the document she referred to, but I think it needs to be emphasised that there is some difference between the two Bills concerned in this case.

SPEECH.PARA: The other Bill that Senator Powell referred to is the Privacy Amendment Bill, which has passed its second reading and which will be dealt with by the relevant committee because there are large numbers of amendments-Government amendments and possible Opposition amendments-and, I gather, alternative suggestions from some of the witnesses. I suppose that is a way in which the Privacy Amendment Bill can fit more easily into the draft document that Senator Powell referred to and can be dealt with in the way that was being proposed.

The pharmaceutical benefits legislation is at a quite different stage of its proceedings. I think everyone acknowledges-Senator Powell would do so as well-that it does not really fit within the four categories that were envisaged in the draft document.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not?
—Because the categories B and C that were talked about in that document related to dealing with the clauses of the Bill instead of the committee stage, the Committee of the Whole.
—No, that is not right.

—That was clearly the intention. Of course, the Australian Democrats put to us the suggestion that that ought to be broadened to accommodate the sort of committee examination before the second reading debate in the chamber takes place, which is what is proposed with the Social Welfare Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill. I am still not sure why this particular Bill needs that, but that is what was proposed by the majority in the end; so it was referred to the committee. But it was at that different stage.

SPEECH.PARA: The suggestions that were made to alter that draft document have not got any further than that. There was general agreement that it would not be finalised until Senator Ray returned as Manager of Government Business next week and let Senator Richardson resume his normal heart rate. The suggestions about recognising the consideration of that sort of Bill have not been put properly to Government members and have not been transmitted to the Opposition, so we cannot say that it was an agreed set of proposals. We cannot really work on that basis yet.

I just wanted to put that into context because the pharmaceutical benefits Bill is in a quite different category and, in some ways, because it involves finances, a much more urgent Bill than the Privacy Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I was present at the meeting, too. It seems as if there are six different versions floating around about this meeting. I can only assume that the members of the Government who were on that Committee suffered the same affliction as Senator McKiernan in that they could not hear while they were speaking. It seems to be an Irish affliction affecting the other members who were present, because there is a different version coming across. I was the only one who did not speak at the meeting, so I did hear what occurred. I can tell honourable senators what occurred. Senator Lees moved a motion at this meeting. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Witnesses may be called as required to provide written submissions, or may be asked to appear before the committee.
A vote was taken and on the casting vote of the Chairman, Senator Zakharov, was not passed. Then everybody started to speak.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said you didn't speak.

—I am learning. I have not been here long enough to suffer from this affliction of putting my tongue in gear before my brain gets into gear, which seems to be another affliction on the other side of the House. At that stage we decided to leave. There was not much point in standing around when our original motion was not passed, so we retired to confer with our respective parties, just as Senator Walters said. With respect, that is what happened.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I would like to answer some of these questions.
—You hope so.

—I hope so; I can never be sure. There are a couple of crucial questions here. I suggest that the allegedly different versions are not what happened at the Committee earlier on tonight. Knowing the loquacious nature of some of the senators who sit on this Committee, I can understand that they would have all been talking at the same time, some of them even under wet cement. Nonetheless, I am faced with the task of explaining what the Government's attitude is on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The first crucial question comes from Senator Walters, on the operations of Estimates Committee C. The Guinness Book of Records will be rewritten by Estimates Committee C and Estimates Committee A on this occasion. They are sitting for what all of us would acknowledge to be an extraordinary length of time. It does not matter whether one is a member of the Opposition or the Government, sitting for five days on an Estimates Committee is not normal. One wonders just how long these committees will go.

Senator Walters asks why the Government is not prepared to have the committees sit next Wednesday evening. The Government is prepared to have Estimates Committee C sit next Wednesday evening. I told the chairperson, Senator Crowley, that that may well be necessary and that she ought to prepare her troops for yet another onslaught. If one realistically looks at what has happened at Estimates Committee C during those five days, one sees that there is no guarantee that it will finish tomorrow; in fact, I would have to say that the chances were less than 50:50.

The Government then has a real problem, because we have a reporting date for Estimates committees of 18 October. If we have an 18 October reporting date, we will need tomorrow and we will probably need next Wednesday night to have them complete their business. So we do not have a choice about Estimates committees sitting tomorrow: it is simply not an option if we are to abide by those reporting dates. That is the first point on Estimates Committee C.

The second point about Estimates Committee C is that conditions are being offered by the Government tonight that I have not heard offered before in my 7 1/2 years in the chamber, and that is the absolute right of priority given to a particular senator to enable that particular senator to ask whatever questions that particular senator considers to be necessary. That, in so far as the operations of Estimates Committee C are concerned, surely covers all that has been said. More fundamental, more crucial to the operations of the Government, will be what occurs tomorrow at Senator Zakharov's committee on the Social Welfare Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill. There is some confusion in Senator Coulter's mind. We do not have a record of the proceedings of the meeting last night and I cannot be certain of exactly what words I used. I cannot guarantee, therefore, that I have finished the words exactly, but I will be very exact about it now.

It is certainly the case that some start-up dates will have to be changed, but they are not start-up dates for the pharmaceutical benefits Bill. The start-up dates that I acknowledge have to be changed are in the social security legislation. They are concerned, in fact, with February Economic Statement start-up dates. We had start-up dates, I think, for sole parents and family allowances for tax file numbers of 1 November, and I indicated to Senator Coulter that already it was obvious that those particular start-up dates would have to be changed, and they will. Clearly, now, the Government envisages changing those 1 November start-up dates to 1 January. Obviously, that means some loss of revenue to the Government. That part of the loss of revenue to the Government is comparatively minor. So that the Senate can conduct what is an appropriate investigation, the Government will readily agree that those start-up dates can be put back. If I have misled Senator Coulter on this I apologise, although I certainly did not mean to and I thought he understood it referred to that Bill.

As far as the pharmaceutical benefits Bill itself is concerned, the Government has not even considered the possibility of its start-up date being put back. That has massive implications for revenue. While I must concede that it has been a movable feast for all of us as to what would happen with these committees in the last couple of days, I was not made aware until today that there was any possibility that we were not likely to have that Bill coming back into the Senate for report next week, and then back to the House of Representatives. We regard that 1 November start-up date as very important to the integrity of the Budget, and I have never suggested that the Government would be happy or easy with delaying it.

Further to that, we face the problem now of Senator Cooney's committee tomorrow dealing with the privacy legislation on consumer credit and not with tax file numbers in the social security legislation, and the suggestion-I must admit, not made to me until today but probably it has been around for somewhat longer, maybe a couple of days-that some senators want a full-blown inquiry into that tax file number system. That would take us into next year and mean that start-up dates would be put back until April.

That, again, would be very serious indeed for the Government. The Government had operated-I think quite reasonably-in the expectation that that tax file number legislation, if it was to be passed, would be dealt with by the Senate in December at the latest-we were certainly hoping for November but, given that that looks impossible, at least by December-so that the 1 January start-up dates could be met. If those start-up dates were all to be put back until April-and that would be the earliest if we were going to have a full-blown inquiry and then report back when the Senate resumes next year; a 1 April start-up date would probably be optimistic-we are getting to somewhere between $70m and $100m lost to revenue from the Budget. The Government cannot just wipe away those sorts of massive sums easily. It was never suggested to me that that was likely to happen and the Government must resist that occurring.

In resisting it, I put it to honourable senators that it is not a matter of resisting the spirit or the letter of anything. I am as anxious as any senator here to make this committee system work. The Government will cooperate totally with it. We will be there, we will sit there and we will answer questions day in and day out. But what we are concerned about-and I think, especially in the light of events of the last 24 hours, quite reasonably so-is that, in particular, these Government Bills to do with the Budget, which involve considerable sums of money and the integrity of the Budget itself, get dealt with within a reasonable period. We are happy, as I said, to put some start-up dates back, but we cannot be expected to delay the whole of these Budget Bills until April or May next year. That would place far too great an impost on the Government and we cannot agree to that.

I must assert, especially to Senator Coulter, that we never did agree to that. In none of the negotiations conducted by Senator Ray or Senator Coates was that ever suggested. We do not want to break the spirit of that agreement. I am sure that when Senator Ray returns on Monday-and that cannot happen soon enough-we will complete the negotiations of the wording of that agreement and we can set it in concrete. I have to assert again that we have not set it in concrete yet. There are some changes which have not been put to Government senators. I do not know whether they have been put to Opposition senators, but there has certainly not been a meeting of the Government to address this question. So it requires a few more days.

In the meantime, we will have to try to work our way through a new committee system that is causing some difficulties. The Government can put some start-up dates back for money Bills, on the assumption that they will be completed within a reasonable amount of time, but on the pharmaceutical benefits Bill we have never considered the possibility of doing away with its start-up date. When one then goes through the whole range of start-up dates in the social security legislation for tax file numbers, again, we are talking about very big losses to revenue, and that is not something the Government would be able to contemplate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was indeed startled by the attitude of the Government in this debate as exemplified earlier this evening by Senator Maguire in comments which I and many other senators on this side of the chamber found utterly contemptible and offensive. But that would not be inconsistent with the attitude of many senior members of the Government. In fact, it would not be inconsistent with the attitude of Mr Courtice, who happens to be the Chairman of the Prime Minister's country task force. Mr Courtice is on record as saying, `I certainly do not believe or agree that rural Australia is in crisis or about to collapse'.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Courtice, the man whose job is supposed to be representing the electorate of Hinkler in the House of Representatives, the man whose job is supposed to be to represent all the farmers and other people dependent on primary industry in his electorate, has the audacity to come to Canberra and say that he does not believe that rural Australia is in a crisis. Maybe Mr Courtice has been in Canberra for too long. Maybe Senator Maguire has been in Canberra for too long. I can say, as, I am sure, can all of senators on this side of the chamber, that even the shortest trip into provincial Australia will reveal the depth of the crisis that is facing this country and all of our primary producers.

I am yet further astounded by other claims by members of the Prime Minister's country task force, such as Mr Hulls, who does not seem to believe that there is a cause for concern because, according to him, the Government's economic policies are working, `albeit slower than a lot of people would like'. When things are going backwards they cannot go much more slowly. Mr Hulls is a very good representative-unfortunately not a good representative for the people of Kennedy in Canberra, but a damn good representative for the people of Canberra in Kennedy. Unfortunately, what we need here in Canberra is people who will tell the story as it is.
Amongst all the gloom and doom, I have pleasure in complimenting a backbencher from the Government, Mr O'Neil, who said today:
. . . in many cases, people in rural areas will not be earning any income at all . . . I think this is a complete indictment of this Government.

The reason why it is an indictment of this Government is that this Government fails to understand the predicament of primary producers across this country-not just in South Australia but all over this country. One of the reasons why it fails to understand was pointed out very adroitly also by Mr O'Neil today when he said:
One of the terrible tragedies in this House-
that is, the House of Representatives-
is that we do not have somebody in the Ministry who lives in a country area.
Is that not a shameful indictment? Not one member of the Ministry lives in a country area. Is it any wonder that when these matters go to Cabinet there is not adequate representation?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I am not quite sure which standing order this relates to, but I maintain that the honourable senator should at least be accurate. There are a number of Ministers who live outside the metropolitan area. I would instance the honourable member for Calare. If the honourable senator does not think that the electorate of Calare is rural, I suggest that he visit it.
—As you pointed out, Senator West, there is no such standing order, but you have made your point.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. Yet again we have another example of the failure of the Government to understand exactly what is being said, except that this time, instead of failing to understand what we on this side of the chamber have been saying-and, goodness knows, we have been saying it for so long that even the most sleepy-headed member of the Government should have been able to listen to it and understand it by now-it has failed to understand what its own backbenchers are saying.

SPEECH.PARA: The groundswell has come. The people of provincial Australia are sick and tired of what this Government is doing to them. It is very obvious from Mr O'Neil's statements that even the Government's own backbenchers in rural areas-those of them who have a conscience-are not only sick and tired of what the Government is doing but also desperately afraid of what the electorate will do to them at the next election.

This Government still pays no attention to the plight facing rural Australia. Today we heard Senator Maguire come before the chamber and say, amongst other things, that the Australian Labor Party had done great things for people in country areas. He had the audacity to say that none of the problems that were afflicting the primary producers of this nation could be blamed upon the Government because it was all the result of market forces and, if it was not the result of market forces, it is because we had a free floating dollar and nothing could be done about the matter.

In that last comment we find the ultimate deception of this Government when it comes to talking about economic matters. Quite clearly, we do not have a free floating dollar. The value of the Australian dollar is totally unrealistic. What Senator Maguire neglected to say-and if I were Senator Maguire I would not want to talk about it either-is that the level of the Australian dollar has been maintained at its current high value not because of market forces but because of manipulation of the dollar by Mr Keating, the Mr Depression of the Australian economy, who has through high interest rates manipulated the Australian dollar upwards for his own ends but not for the advantage of primary producers in this country.

It is a fact that, for every one cent rise in the value of the Australian dollar against the greenback, primary producers in this country lose $150m in annual earnings. That is the indictment of the Government, and that is the indictment of the economic policies of Treasurer Keating. Yet the Government believes that somehow it can hold up its hands and say, `Sorry; we are not responsible for the crisis that faces rural Australia'. That is just not on.

The Government fails to answer the criticisms that we on this side of the Senate have made of the high interest rate policy to which this Government has subjected the people of this country for the last two years. It has failed to address the fact that many farmers in this country will be forced off the land not because they are bad farmers, not even because of the bad seasons alone: the straw that will break the camel's back is the high interest policy of this Government.

The reason why many farmers will be forced to lose farms that have been in their families for 50, 60, 70 and in some cases 100 years is that they cannot pay the interest bill on their overdraft with the banks. Why can they not pay the interest bill? It is because the interest bill is too high as a result of this Government's monetary policy. That is a point of the motion that nobody on the Government side of the chamber has attempted to address tonight. Honourable senators opposite have failed to attempt to address it because they cannot. Simple economic facts have proven this Government to be wholly inadequate when it comes to protecting the fortunes of people in provincial Australia.

At the same time as this Government has been subjecting our farmers to all the vicissitudes of a high interest rate regime, Senator Maguire was saying that the solution to the problem confronting primary producers was to improve their efficiency. But primary producers in this country are the most cost efficient primary producers in the world. The only problem is that they cannot sell goods overseas because of the high value of the Australian dollar. That is a direct consequence of the Treasurer's monetary policy. Yet Senator Maguire continued to talk about so-called improvements in efficiency.

Let me tell the Senate what will happen if the Government continues with this high interest policy, and if it continues to turn its back on people in provincial Australia. The consequence is very simple: all the very best farmers will be forced off the land. If the Government wants to see an improvement in efficiency in primary production in this country, it certainly will not be forthcoming as a consequence of what the Government is doing. We are not talking about the bad farmers now; we are not talking about pushing the bad farmers out of business-they went out of business years ago-we are talking about the very best of our farmers, those who have been able to survive for the past two years on the Government's high interest rate regime, those who have managed to struggle their way through floods, through droughts and through bad seasons. Yet this Government continues to talk about improving efficiency, when all its policies will achieve only one thing: declining efficiency in Australian primary production, declining efficiency in the farming sector, and ultimately a decline in the economy of this country as a whole. Yet the Government claims that there is no rural crisis. The Government claims that it is just the farmers and the National Farmers Federation bellyaching. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural Economics (ABARE) produced figures earlier this year showing that average farm incomes in this country would decline by 51 per cent. At the same time as ABARE showed that drop, I was surprised the other week to hear Senator Cook in Question Time egging on his friends in the Australian Council of Trade Unions to ask for an 11 per cent pay rise.

I am not naive enough to believe that farmers always expect the level of their incomes to stay constant; that farmers are not willing to subject themselves to some of the vagaries of the market. But there is something essentially wrong in the morality of a government that lets one portion of the economy, one portion of the population, cop a 51 per cent reduction in income while at another time giving another portion of the population an 11 per cent pay rise. This is one country where we have all to pull one load, yet the Government does not seem to be interested. The sad truth is that whether or not the Government is interested now in what is happening in provincial Australia, it certainly will be interested in what is happening in six months time, because if it is not the farmers coming down to Canberra and having a mass protest outside Parliament House-and sometimes that might be necessary to wake up Ministers-it will be the wholesale decline of the Australian economy. Ultimately, the strength of the economy depends on what we can export. One of the largest areas of exports is primary production, yet the Government is willing to let that primary production slip away; it is willing to let the export dollars of this country slip away. It is willing to let the backbone of this country slowly decline.

Senator Maguire, for all his rhetoric, did not come up with one answer to the substance of tonight's motion. He turned his back on it all the way right from his opening comments, which showed that obviously he has factionalism on his brain. He seemed to believe that the whole purpose of this motion was something to do with a fight between the dries and the wets in the Liberal Party. He seemed to think that maybe there was some difference between the National Party and the Liberal Party and that we were putting this up as some sort of stunt. Maybe that is the way that Senator Maguire looks at the operations of this chamber, but that is not the way we operate on this side of the chamber. We are down here for one reason and for one reason alone: to represent the people of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —And defeat the Labor Party. Don't forget that.
—And defeat the Labor Party. That will be a good thing for the people of this country.
—That won't happen.

—Senator Burns has just interjected. The thought obviously came straight into his mind. It is well known that when a thought crosses Senator Burns's mind, it is the shortest trip in Canberra. What this Government has failed to do is pay any attention to the plight of primary producers in this country. What this Government has done time after time is turn its back and say that the farmers are bellyaching or whingeing. The farmers in this country are fed up, and that is the thing that the Government cannot seem to understand. The Government thought it could keep on kicking the farmers until they died. Finally, the farmers have said, `No, we have had enough'.
—Why do those opposite hate farmers?

—I wonder why they hate farmers. I have been wondering that all the time. I thought that it was just an inability to comprehend what happens outside the capital cities, but at times I start to think that maybe they do hate farmers. This Government needs to take the opportunity to open its eyes, to travel outside the capital city, to talk to the real people of this country. When I was elected to this Senate I made only one promise, and that was to listen to what the people in Queensland had to say and be their voice in Canberra. It is very clear when one travels around Queensland that the people of provincial Queensland are heartily sick and tired of what this Government is doing to them-with its increases in excise charges; the higher sales tax on four-wheel drive vehicles; the increases in indirect taxation on such things as oils and lubricants, which hit the farmers very hard indeed. They are sick and tired, too, of Government documents like the national drought policy, which seems to suggest that drought should be neglected and that we should do absolutely nothing to assist farmers suffering from drought.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the press release issued on 15 August by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, who said:
Many of these issues will underpin our considerations on sustainable agriculture.

The suggestion in the national drought policy that we should do nothing about drought, nothing to assist farmers through the hard years, signals a willingness on the part of this Government to write off farmers who suffer from a drought or from a couple of bad seasons. The Government is willing to write off the production of those farms as non-sustainable agriculture. Agriculture in this country is indeed sustainable if the country has a government with the intestinal fortitude to do something about it. Yet this Government has failed the people of provincial Australia, it has failed the farmers and it has failed the long term viability of our economy. That is why we on this side of the chamber have put forward this motion. That is why we on this side are so concerned at what the Government is doing. Once again I can only take the opportunity to agree with the courageous Mr O'Neil, who said that the great tragedy was that there were no Ministers in the Parliament who came from country areas. The sad truth is that the Government does not understand or care. It is time that it started to care before it is too late.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not my intention to enter this debate, but I thought to myself-after listening to Senator O'Chee say almost nothing in 30 minutes-that I should at least get up for a short time and say something. If Senator O'Chee had a brain it would be lonely; that is fairly obvious. If it is a short trip across my mental process, then it is a much shorter trip across his.

SPEECH.PARA: He talked about interest rates mostly and the value of the dollar. For many years people in the National Party, or the Country Party, as it used to be known, and the Liberal Party talked about deregulation and about the free market: let the market decide the value of the currency; let the market decide the value of commodities; that is the way to go-capitalism in its rawest form. They were vitriolic in their opposition to socialism or any sort of regulation that would guarantee markets, or any regulation that would mean that people who were in real need would not starve to death and their children would not get an education. Their attitude in the main has been: those who have money and the ability to exploit other people in the community will get their children educated and will have health care and other things. That has been their attitude. They have no concern at all for people in the community.

The Labor Party did have the courage to float the dollar-something that the Opposition parties talked about for many years but never had the guts to do. Once the dollar is floated, then of course we are in the position where the market does decide the value of the dollar. It is true that there can be some intervention by the central bank whereby the currency can be bought and sold to bolster or to reduce the value of the dollar.

Senator O'Chee also talked about interest rates. It is fairly obvious that, if we want to encourage capital to come into Australia and we want to maintain the capital inside the country in terms of its capacity to create investment opportunities and take advantage of those, then I guess we have got to reward people who are prepared to make that investment with reasonable levels of interest rates. But it is a well-known fact that, as interest rates come down in a particular country's fiscal or monetary situation, it is normal for the value of the currency to be reduced. But we had in Australia something quite contrary to that: interest rates have been reduced as far as possible in a way that will not introduce and encourage a further heating up of the economy and thus force a position where interest rates would have to go up again fairly quickly. We found ourselves in a position where the interest rate paid to those people who had their money invested in the banking system came down some 4 per cent, but at the same time the value of the dollar went up.

One of the many things that Senator O'Chee did not tell us was what the Opposition would do in these circumstances. He quite blithely ignored the many things that the Labor Government has done, beyond freeing up the dollar and beyond deregulating the banks to encourage banks to come into the country to make finance available in terms of investments so that we could generate wealth in this country through various business enterprises. This Government has done that in a way that no government has done for many years.

The importation of various items of machinery and other capital goods into this country, which had been fairly heavily protected by tariffs over many years by the National Party that Senator O'Chee represents, had created a problem for the country people; and they have been very vocal about it for many years. But they wanted the right to buy machinery and other equipment from overseas which would be cheaper than the local product because of wage levels and, of course, protection by way of tariffs.

This Government has reduced tariffs consistently over recent years, and has a policy of continuing to do so. This Government has looked at the question of deregulation and allowing the market to operate. We have deregulated the wheat industry. We have eliminated total protection for the sugar industry by way of removing the embargo on the import of sugar. These are steps that one would have thought would have been taken by a Liberal-National coalition over time but were never taken, and so were taken by the Labor Government.

It is true that there are some very great and grave problems in the rural industry. There are many people within the Australian Labor Party, including Cabinet Ministers, who have freely indicated that that is the position. It would be stupid to say otherwise when one looks at the reduced price for grains and when one looks at the wool crisis, whereby most of the wool being offered for auction is being bought and retained in the stockpile. Of course, the wool industry operated for many years on the basis of a price that was offered at auction with no protection at all and no attempt to regulate it. But it was the Whitlam Government in its period of office between 1972 and 1975 which introduced the floor price for wool. Senator O'Chee does not make that point. I do: it was a Labor government in that period of time that established the floor price for wool.

I go back to the question of tariffs and the introduction of imported machinery at a price which enables those in the rural industry to operate much more efficiently; that is, their inputs are cheaper and therefore they are in a better economic position to get a return at the end of the day or at the end of the year.

There has always been a problem in the area of manufacturing. There is no doubt that any farmer or anyone in the rural industry who had any brains at all-someone who would not reflect the sorts of views held by Senator O'Chee, for instance-would want to buy local goods on the basis that they would be quality goods, that they would be delivered on time, and that they would be at a competitive price. The back-up that comes as a result of a product being locally produced and of having people who can attend to problems and the availability of spare parts is a very desirable position for local people in the rural industry, as it is for other people in other industries such as transport. That has been stated by people in those industries over time.

This Government has set in train the sorts of plans which have enabled people in the various industries to begin to make progress in that direction. The steel industry plan of $500m turned the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) around from a company which publicly stated that its return on investment in the steel industry was 2 per cent, which gradually reduced its capacity to export, and which recognised itself in that particular area as being totally inefficient. That $500m grant, which was given not to BHP but to people who purchased BHP steel, to subsidise prices, was instrumental in turning BHP around to a stage where it now exports more steel than ever before in its history as a company.

It also gave BHP an opportunity to have a return on capital, which I have read and heard BHP people say is in the area of 15 per cent. It also indicates a situation where it is assisting the balance of payments-a particular area of economic activity and Government decision which is helpful to the whole nation in terms of the value of the currency and in terms of our reputation on the international market. It is only beginning, but it is continuing and BHP has shown confidence in regard to that.

For many years the trade union movement indicated that there were too many people in our car manufacturing industry. The Liberal-National Party Government was in power and took no notice at all. We continued to have too many car industry companies, too many products, too many models. It made it very impractical to produce a quality car at a given price. This Government set in train a car manufacturing plan whereby there was a rationalisation of the way in which cars were manufactured. There have been reductions in model numbers. That is all to the good and benefit of the community. It should lead to an industry that will have a future which is solid and ongoing rather than in crisis. Those are some of the things that we have done.

In other areas of general productivity and manufacturing, we have set about turning back the developments that were created and were ongoing when the coalition was in office: the gradual destruction of our car manufacturing industry, and the total faith that was pinned on the agricultural industry to produce the goods in terms of creating wealth and providing a balance of payments that was beneficial to us. Anybody who has studied the value of manufactured goods in terms of import replacements or the use of those goods inside this country and against our capacity to create wealth and earn income from other countries, again affecting the balance of payments, knows that were we able to produce a shipload of computers and export them or manufacture them and use them in this country as import replacements, that would have a very stark result compared with sending six shiploads of wheat to Iraq, for instance, or two shiploads of sheep, or three or four bulk carriers of coal. The added value of those particular commodities is tremendous and it is beneficial to us.

We have had in place a system where manufacturing companies have operated in the very worst way, where we have had traditional methods of production and management that could never in anyone's imagination be considered to be practical or efficient. People have attempted to lay a lot of blame at the door of the trade union movement about this in terms of demarcation disputes and awards that were way in advance in conditions and wages, which meant high labour costs. The trade union movement is looking at the attitude of people to their jobs as compared with people of other countries. Japan is a classic example of different attitudes to work. People are absolutely dedicated and committed, almost enslaved mentally, to a responsibility to their employer, quite often against the interest of their family. The trade union movement has also looked at how we deal with the problem of bad work practices and bad management practices. It was the trade union movement's initiative to look at restructuring in industry. Recently it introduced the proposition of neutral results in terms of wage increases. For instance, the second tier 4 per cent gave increases to people but the cost was neutral to industry because there had to be a trade off.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has this got to do with rural industry?

—It has a lot to do with the crisis in Australia. I do not want for a moment to take the rural industry on its own and suggest that if we solve the problem in the rural industry, that will fix everything. The Opposition has chosen to use that argument; it has chosen to highlight the question of rural industry. But the things I am talking about impinge on the ability of the rural industry at the end of the day to make a profit, to get a result, and to provide a reasonable living standard for the people in that industry. It does not mean that because we get a high price for products, we automatically retain earnings. There are other ways. We can have a low price and a low input cost and do very well. We can have a high price and a high input cost and do very badly. We have to look at the whole picture. We cannot be mental pygmies, as some Opposition senators would demonstrate. These are some of the things that the Labor Government has done in terms of the whole picture, which has a very heavy influence on the ability of people in the community to compete and to create wealth, including in rural industry.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been many occasions over time as a result of some of these changes when people in the manufacturing industries in the cities have had a very bad experience of losing their jobs and never being able to be re-employed because they may be of an age at which they are no longer attractive to an employer. Again, the Labor Government has moved in the area of retraining, of broad training, so that people, having had their skills in a particular area supplemented by additional training, can go into other areas of endeavour in which they can be gainfully employed. Again, this is a saving and a real asset to the community.

Those people have suffered very drastically, some of them never to be employed again. We have not heard too much from the other side of the chamber, nor have we had any great crisis meetings, about those problems. I guess those people just have to manage; that is their way of life. I suggest the rural people have to manage but, as a government, we have to do what we can to help them manage, as we have helped other workers. To suggest that the Labor Government is responsible for the price of rural commodities on the world market is absolutely ridiculous. This Labor Government, in a way in which the coalition has never done in its time, has gone out and battled for the free market in terms of world sales of agricultural commodities. We have had the successful talks in the Uruguay Round. Michael Duffy has worked so hard and so effectively to get together the Cairns Group. He argued like hell for our right to compete in a marketplace that was not distorted by the European Community's bounties to help its farmers to produce agricultural commodities that were not saleable or useful in terms of a proper undistorted market. The Americans brought into play their version of the bounty to compete against the European Common Market. We, as a small country, have very efficient farmers and, as I said and will repeat, will be assisted by all the machinations which have been put in place in terms of better facilities for them: cheaper imports and better quality goods internally. They have been very efficient; but efficiency will not answer the challenge of high bounties. We have gone out in the marketplace and Michael Duffy has done a tremendous job in that regard to seek those positions.

Government of the Labor Party persuasion, which very clearly represents workers, including those in the rural area, could be influenced by argument from trade unionists and other people about the need to maintain protection for the manufacturing industry. After all, the great bulk of jobs are in that industry. People talk about the flight of people out of the agricultural industry. People have been leaving the rural industry over the years in great numbers, not because of any particular problem of the price of the commodities on the market. The exit from the sugar industry was caused by the development, and correctly so, of the mechanical harvester, which destroyed the jobs of tens of thousands of sugar industry workers. It was the development of more efficient and effective ways in the pastoral industry generally which saw thousands of people leave the wool industry and the cattle industry.

All those things have occurred. The Government has done whatever possible in that area, but if we had listened and said, 'All right. Okay. Let us not only stop reducing protection but we will increase it somewhat', then we would have been in a position internationally where we would not have had any credibility to argue for the right of people in the rural industry to sell their goods on the international market at a competitive price, free of the distortions that are brought into the market by the use of bounties by other countries.

So the people in the rural industry should understand-people on the other side of the House, I guess, never will because all they want to do is to make cheap political points-that the Labor Government has seen its constituency suffer because of the reduction of tariffs and the loss of jobs. It has seen the need to do something for the people in the rural industry and to make sure that we can create the best possible position to enable them to compete and get markets for their commodities.

As far as the wool industry is concerned, I believe it is fairly clear that at a time when it was decided to increase the floor price it was being greedy; the floor price was increased above what it should have been at the time. It is not a crime to be greedy; it is a lack of judgment. It is a wrong feeling to succumb to and, as a result of that, it had a problem where it could not sell its wool. The Government was forced, through the Minister, to make a decision to reduce the floor price. It was not something that the Government wanted to do. It knew what the situation was-that we could not forever sustain that floor price.

The Government could not continue to allow the levy to be increased. It could not allow the industry to borrow to protect what the industry felt was a fair price for wool, because anybody who understands anything about the industry knows that if the wool is not sold within a certain period of time it will be not only worthless but also will owe the woolgrowers money. The storage cannot go on forever and something has to be done. When we go amongst people in the industry, we find that they talk about the free market. They do not want protection. Of course, the free market is there when prices are good, and we want to keep all the profits. When prices are not good and we feel we need some assistance or protection from the Government, then suddenly the free market is a good idea but maybe we should distort it a bit. Well, we either have it or we do not. I personally have some problems with the free market, but as a Government our position is that we support it.

We have a problem with wheat. We can hardly blame the Government for the problems in the Gulf, which are going to have some effect in terms of our market with Iraq. The Government cannot be blamed for the fact that there are people using bounties to destroy the proper value of commodities and making our position untenable. I believe that I have canvassed a number of issues, some of which may seem to those on the other side of the House not to be related to the rural issues. But in the Senate we cannot in isolation talk about the problems of one group of people in this community and truly represent people in the State that we come from.

The fact is that it is all interconnected. If we had a very prosperous rural industry and the manufacturing industry was destroyed, we would still be in awful trouble. We need to look at all the issues across the whole spectrum and at our endeavour and ability to create wealth. This is not only in the rural industry but also in the manufacturing areas, in the newly developed area of tourism- the area of services-in terms of our capacity to win contracts throughout the world such as in the area of telecommunications, and in areas where our skills are recognised and being taken advantage of. The Government realises that there is a problem in the rural industry. We will deal with it in a way which is fair and equitable and in any way that is open to us so that this country gets a benefit from it right across the spectrum of the Australian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — What we have just heard illustrates with amazing clarity the lack of understanding this Government has of the situation in rural Australia. The perambulations we have just had through Broken Hill Propriety Co. Ltd and the car industry, and the assertions that the crisis which this Government has masterminded is not only limited to the rural industry but extends throughout Australia, is an assertion which I am sure the leader of this Government would thank Senator Burns for making.

SPEECH.PARA: I will address the motion. The motion asks that the Senate:
(a) notes with concern the State Bank of South Australia's Rural Report . . .
We, the Australian Democrats, agree that that should be noted. It asks us:
(b) notes that the above calculations assume that the rate of exchange of $A/$US is $0.70 . . .
Yes, we agree that that should be noted as well. In (c) we are asked:
(c) further notes that the United Farmers and Stockowners of SA Incorporated attributes the disastrous state of the South Australian rural economy . . .

We, the Democrats, believe that the word `attribute' is a little bit suspect there. This group, the United Farmers and Stockowners of South Australia, attributes this particular disastrous state to the Federal Government's monetary policy. Whether it is the monetary policy or not is a matter of argument. We note the opinion and we agree with the motion that the opinion should be noted. But the whole of Australia has noticed that all Australian farming is in trouble. The question really is: What has this Government done? We saw here today that it legislated against drought. We saw that this was the Government's effort in that area. We heard Senator Maguire give us the profound observation that commodity prices are down and world production is up.
