Well, wow, that is overwhelmingly profound. We want to know what action the Government will take.

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't you know that?

—It is an observation which ironically-and I think all other honourable senators are capable of seeing the irony in the expression I made there-was a profound observation to make. I would have thought that a government which was concerned, and showed some understanding of the situation in rural Australia, would have been able to come up with a better observation and I would not have had to use the ironical expression then.
—It was the truth.

—If that is the truth, then it is not something that should trouble a senator who is responding to a motion moved in this place. It should not trouble him too much to go further and note that, in Tasmania, a place about which I can speak with some authority, the whole community is aware that the retail price of potatoes is advertised in our capital daily newspapers at 5c a kilogram.
—I gave this one a run yesterday.

—Senator Sherry gave it a run yesterday. I gave it a run a month ago, and I am still concerned that the only return the farmer can get for his potatoes in Tasmania is 5c a kilogram. If Senator Sherry thinks that is funny, I will remind him that it costs 8c to produce the things. Now, nobody can make a living at that sort of rate.
—I was not laughing.
—Sniggering, perhaps. I was in South Australia the other day and farmers and fruit processors told me of their plight. They are unable to sell their produce.

SPEECH.PARA: Today in South Australia there are 60 tonnes of last season's dried apricots that cannot be sold because this Government is encouraging Turkish apricots to be imported into Australia. Turkey, which is described as a developing country, is being given a positive advantage. As a result of this 5 per cent incentive to bring dried apricots to Australia, our farmers cannot sell their produce.

I was in Perth recently and met several people who are concerned about the situation in which our farmers find themselves. I read in the West Australian newspaper that farm machinery dealers believe that 5,000 people could leave country towns by Christmas as the rural crisis bites in Western Australia. I want to know what the Government is doing about that. Senator Button has cooked up some deal to sell subsidised sports cars to American teenagers. I suppose that has something to do with a plan to help the people who sell such cars. But I cannot understand it.

Yesterday I was in Beenleigh where some farmers with initiative have spent considerable time and effort conducting extensive trials and tests which demonstrated that ethanol is a viable practical additive to petrol for motor vehicles.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it isn't.

—If the honourable senator listens he might learn something. An ethanol industry would bring stability to our sugar industry and increase opportunities for rural employment in Queensland and New South Wales. But what does this Government do? Yesterday while I was in Beenleigh seeing what these farmers were prepared to do and how they were prepared to help themselves, Senator Cook was in here ridiculing their efforts and whingeing about revenue loss to government. He gave no consideration to the benefits to this country that such an industry would bring, such as reduced imports, replacement of lead in super petrol, less polluting emissions and the invaluable strategic advantage of being able to be more self-reliant in motor fuel supplies. That advantage is invaluable. Whether it is economical to produce the stuff or not is irrelevant to the strategic advantage.

SPEECH.PARA: Speaking of Queensland, recently Senator O'Chee gave the Senate an example of another enterprising Queenslander who made an effort to expand her market base. After successfully negotiating with overseas markets and developing a product, which I understand was packaged peanuts, what did the Government do? It slapped a bunch of inspection fees and charges, an export licence and other mumbo jumbo on that exporter. That effectively wiped out the meagre profit and destroyed the export opportunity.

The other day I was in Dunalley near Hobart and I saw the initiative and enterprise involved in developing agro-forestry. Agro-forestry provides diversity and increases productivity in farms. This Government has removed funding for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's research into agro-forestry. All this demonstrates its shallow level of understanding of what rural Australia is all about. It demonstrates that this Government does not understand and does not care and that its actions are not beneficial to our primary producers.

I will support this motion, as will the Australian Democrats. I intend to move one slight amendment to the final paragraph which calls on the Federal Government to adopt a monetary policy which will give Australian exporters a reasonable chance to compete internationally. I would like to add the words `farmers and' so the paragraph calls on the Federal Government to adopt a monetary policy which will give Australian farmers and exporters a reasonable chance to compete internationally.

The motion calls on the Federal Government to adopt a monetary policy. I would like to amend it so that it calls on the Government to take immediate action on a number of fronts. However, I will not do so because it matters little whether the Government adopts a monetary policy. It is obvious that the monetary policy it is following now is not working. It probably does not matter what monetary policy it tries; it could not be worse than the one it is adopting at the moment. I move:
Paragraph (d), after the word `Australian', insert `farmers and'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that anybody has a copy of the amendment you have moved, Senator Bell. It might be helpful to have a copy.

—I want to include the words `farmers and' in paragraph (d) of the motion so that Australian farmers and exporters will be given a reasonable chance to compete internationally. As I seek to add only two words I did not think it necessary to provide an amendment in written form.
—It might be worth while making sure that everybody has a copy of the amendment next time the matter is considered because the time for General Business has now expired.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX AMENDMENT BILL 1990MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1990TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (RATES AND PROVISIONAL TAX) BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Collins) agreed to:
That these Bills may proceed without formalities, may be taken together and be now read a first time.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That these Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
INCOME TAX AMENDMENT BILL 1990

This Bill will amend the Income Tax Act 1986 to formally impose the rates of income tax payable by individuals, and trustees generally, for 1990-91 and, until the Parliament otherwise provides, for the 1991-92 financial year.
It will also impose for the same period the rates of tax payable by companies, registered organisations and unit trusts treated as companies.
In addition, it will impose rates of tax on superannuation funds, approved deposit funds and pooled superannuation trusts.
The rates of tax to be imposed are those declared in the Income Tax Rates Act 1986 as amended by the Taxation Laws Amendment (Rates and Provisional Tax) Bill 1990 which I have just introduced.
The provisions of the Bill are explained in the explanatory memorandum that accompanied the Taxation Laws Amendment (Rates and Provisional Tax) Bill 1990.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1990
This Bill will amend the Medicare Levy Act 1986 to impose the basic rate of Medicare levy for 1990-91 and, until the Parliament otherwise provides, for the 1991-92 financial year.
The basic rate of the levy will remain at 1.25 per cent of taxable income.
That has been the rate since 1 December 1986.
The Bill will also increase the low income thresholds below which people are not required to pay any levy.
For 1990-91, individuals with taxable incomes of up to $11,745, and married couples and sole parents with family incomes of up to $19,045 will not be required to pay the levy.

The income threshold for married couples and sole parents will increase by a further $2,100 for each dependent child or student. For example, a married couple with two dependent children will pay no levy until their combined taxable incomes exceed $23,245.
The estimated cost of the increased low income thresholds is $35 million in 1990-91 and $80 million in 1991-92.
The new low income thresholds will be reflected in provisional tax raised for 1990-91 and tax instalment schedules from 1 January 1991.
The Explanatory Memorandum on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Rates and Provisional Tax) Bill 1990 about which I have just spoken contains an explanation of the provisions of this Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (RATES AND PROVISIONAL TAX) BILL 1990
This Bill will give effect to the reduction in the personal tax rates announced in the February 1990 Economic Statement, and to some other measures announced by the Treasurer in his Budget speech.
It will declare the general rates of income tax payable by individuals and trustees generally for 1990-91 and for 1991-92 and subsequent financial years.
As a consequence of the reductions in the personal rates of tax, the Bill will also reduce the level of the rebate of tax available for payments of net medical expenses exceeding $1,000.

The Bill will also amend the income tax law to provide a method of calculating provisional tax for 1990-91 and subsequent income years and to give effect to the Budget announcement requiring the payment of provisional tax on certain salary or wages.
I will now outline in more detail these measures.
Personal tax rates

The reductions in the tax rates announced in the February 1990 Economic Statement have effect from 1 January 1991. At the lower end of the rate scale the level of the threshold at or below which tax is not payable is to be increased from $5,100 to $5,400.

The top of the first rate step is to be increased from $17,650 to $20,700 and the 29 per cent rate will be removed, so that the lowest marginal rate of 21 per cent applies in the income range $5,401 to $20,700.
The Bill will reduce the 39 per cent rate to 38 per cent, to apply in the income range $20,700 to $36,000.
A new rate of 46 per cent is to apply in the income range $36,000 to $50,000.

Finally, the existing top marginal rate of 47 per cent is to apply only to incomes over $50,000. As these changes apply from 1 January 1991 a composite rate scale will apply for the 1990-91 financial year.

That scale will comprise a weighted average of one half of the present rate scale applying from 1 July 1990 to 31 December 1990 and one half of the new rate scale that is to apply from 1 January 1991 to 30 June 1991.
These tax cuts will be reflected in lower pay-as-you-earn deductions from 1 January 1991.

Changes will also be made to the rate scale for non-residents with the existing rate of 29 per cent to apply on incomes up to $20,700, and above that amount the reduced rates as for residents will apply.
The cost to the revenue of the personal tax cuts for residents is estimated at $1,230 million in 1990-91 and $2,585 million in 1991-92.
The changes with respect to non-residents is estimated to cost less that $0.5 million in a full year.
Rebate for medical expenses

As announced in the Budget, the level of the rebate of tax for net medical expenses exceeding $1,000 will be reduced from 29 per cent to 21 per cent for 1991-92 and subsequent income years consequent upon the removal of the 29 per cent marginal tax rate.
The level of the rebate for 1990-91 will be 25 per cent.
The revenue savings from this measure are estimated at $7 million in 1991-92 and $15 million in a full year.
Provisional tax for 1990-91 and subsequent years

The Bill provides for 1990-91 provisional tax to be calculated on the basis of the 1989-90 taxable income increased by 10 per cent, and applying the 1990-91 rates of tax, Medicare levy and the increased low income thresholds for Medicare levy that are to apply in that year.
Subject to the exceptions I will announce, rebates and credits will be allowed in the provisional tax calculation at the levels allowed in the 1989-90 assessment.
Any rebate of tax allowed on franked dividends and any credits for foreign taxes will be uplifted by 10 per cent.

Concessional rebates claimed in 1989-90 for a dependent spouse, daughter-housekeeper, invalid relative, parent or parent-in-law or for a housekeeper and the sole parent rebate will be adjusted to reflect the new higher levels for 1990-91 as a consequence of indexation.

Changes will also be made to some claims for zone rebates and rebates for Defence Force members serving overseas or civilians serving with the United Nations. Provisional tax will be calculated after increasing any such rebate by 20 per cent of the adjustment made to the taxpayer's 1989-90 concessional rebate claim.

Taxpayers who estimate their taxable income for 1989-90 will increase by less than 10 per cent, or who consider that their rebates or credits will be at a higher level in 1990-91, will continue to have the right to ``self-assess'' and have the provisional tax for 1990-91 recalculated on the basis of their own estimates.

By this Bill the method of calculation of provisional tax using a factor to uplift income will be incorporated in the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. This course will obviate the need for the Parliament to consider each year the largely repetitious rules under which provisional tax is calculated.

Further, the Bill also provides that the uplift factor for subsequent years may be prescribed by regulation, up to a percentage not exceeding 12 per cent. Where a regulation is not in force the uplift factor will be 10 per cent.

Finally, the Bill also gives effect to a Budget announcement to authorise the raising of provisional tax in respect of 1990-91 and subsequent years of income, where the assessable income of the taxpayer in the year preceding the year for which provisional tax is payable consists wholly of salary or wages. This will overcome the advantage that arises from the deferral of tax where sufficient tax instalments to cover liability are not deducted from salary or wages.

The amendment by the Bill will apply only where two conditions are met in relation to the preceding year. The taxpayer has a balance of tax to pay on assessment of $3,000 or more, and the shortfall in tax instalment deductions from the salary or wages in the year is $3,000 or more.

Where the two conditions are met, the existing method of calculating provisional tax payable, used by the Commissioner of Taxation to allow a reduction for the salary or wages content of assessable income, will be changed. The change will apply where the assessable income of a taxpayer consists wholly, or in part, of salary or wages.
The reduction for the salary or wages content of assessable income currently proceeds on the assumption that sufficient tax instalment deductions are made to cover the tax liability on that income.
Following the change the calculation will, in effect, take account of the actual shortfall in the tax instalment deductions of the taxpayer in the preceding year.
Of course, taxpayers have the right to ``self-assess'' their provisional tax liability where they consider sufficient tax instalment deductions will be deducted from salary or wages in a year.

In this regard, it has been foreshadowed in the Budget papers that a new interest-based penalty will apply where a taxpayer over-estimates the tax instalment deductions in an application to ``self-assess''.
The necessary amending legislation will be introduced in a Bill later this sittings.
The gain to revenue from this measure is estimated at $370 million in 1990-91.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum, which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: ARTS, ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Collins) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The Arts, Environment, Tourism and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 amends 8 Acts of my portfolio.

It amends the Arts, Territories and Environment Legislation Amendment Act 1989 to rectify a minor error in the Australian Film, Television and Radio School Act 1973. The bill also makes a correction of the Canberra Water Supply (Googong Dam) Act 1974 via the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Act 1988.

Amendments to the Australian Tourist Commission Act 1987 will allow for the addition of one extra member to the Board of Directors of the Australian Tourist Commission, which will make it possible for a more broadly-based representation of persons with relevant skills, experience and background to be on the Board.

Amendments to the National Gallery Act 1975 will permit the introduction of flexible, workable and responsible disposal mechanisms for works of art from the National Collection, by removing the requirement from the Act that two independent experts be consulted as part of the disposal process. The requirement that all disposals require Ministerial approval will remain in the Act.

Part 4 of the bill will repeal section 67 of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975. Section 67 is concerned with the prosecution of offences committed against the Act or against the Regulations in force under the Act. It deals with the distinction between summary and indictable offences and provides protection against being punished more than once for the same offence.
Repeal of section 67 is appropriate because the Crimes Act 1914 already deals with these matters. They are covered by sections 4c, 4g and 4h of that Act.

Because the Crimes Act clearly defines the difference between summary offences and indictable offences, an unfortunate consequence of the present situation under section 67 of the National Parks and Wildlife Act will be eliminated. As it is currently worded, section 67 can operate in such a way that even a minor offence is prevented from being heard summarily and offenders can evade prosecution by failing to attend court.

Under the new situation, where the Crimes Act applies instead of section 67 of the National Parks and Wildlife Act, any offence committed against the Regulations that are in force under the National Parks and Wildlife Act will automatically be defined as a summary offence. This is because the prescribed penalties under the Regulations are of a monetary nature only and do not involve imprisonment.

The normal situation in law is that a summary hearing can proceed even if the defendant fails to appear in court. This means, for example, that a person who commits an offence against the Regulations in Kakadu National Park and then returns home to another State cannot evade conviction simply by failing to appear when the case against him or her is heard in court in Darwin. The court will have the power to continue with the summary hearing despite the absence of the defendant.

Amendments to the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Act 1986 (the PMCH Act) are designed to overcome administrative difficulties which have arisen in the operation of the heritage export control scheme.

The amendment of section 10 of the Act will enable the principal public collecting institutions to apply for a general permit to loan material for the purpose of research, exhibition or similar purpose, without having to seek a permit on each occasion they wish to export objects. The amendment is appropriate because the collections are already controlled and protected by Acts of either the Commonwealth, State or Territory Parliaments.

A further amendment provides that an application for a permit to export a cultural heritage object must specify an address in Australia. There is also a provision to simplify the service of notices under sections 10 and 12 of the Act.

An amendment to section 14 of the Act will exempt completely from the operation of the Act all cultural heritage objects temporarily imported into Australia under a loan agreement with a foreign government or foreign collecting institution. This amendment will assist the import of international touring exhibitions visiting Australia that have been arranged by principal collecting institutions and specific exhibition coordinators.

The amendment of section 17 of the PMCH Act is to provide for the nominee of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs who is appointed to the National Cultural Heritage Committee to be an Aboriginal. Aboriginality is defined for the purpose of this section.

Amendments to the Public Lending Right Act 1985 will permit the Public Lending Right Committee to conduct its meetings by telephone conference, closed circuit television or other method of communication determined by the Committee, and will permit the Committee to exercise its powers without being affected by a vacancy in its membership.

The bill makes one last amendment to legislation covering self-government in the Australian Capital Territory. The Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910, which confers on the Governor-General the power to make Ordinances for the Territory on matters of retained Commonwealth responsibility, is amended to correct an error which appears to have caused the Ordinance-making power on some matters still retained, to expire on 1 July 1990.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Messages received from the House of Representatives intimating that it had agreed to the amendments made by the Senate to the following Bills:
Australian Maritime Safety Authority Bill 1990.
Commonwealth Serum Laboratories (Conversion into Public Company) Bill 1990.
Administrative Services Legislation Amendment Bill 1990.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Back in November 1988, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure completed an inquiry into the role and functions of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. In its tabled report, the so-called Saunderson Committee identified what it saw as desirable objectives of the broadcasting legislation. These objectives were:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) to maintain the viability of the broadcasting system;
(b) to maximise diversity of choice;
(c) to discourage concentration of media ownership and control;
(d) to restrict foreign ownership and prohibit foreign control of commercial broadcasting;
(e) to encourage Australian content;
(f) to provide services that are relevant and responsive to local needs;
(g) to improve quality; and
(h) to protect the public and particularly children from offensive material by the setting of appropriate standards.

The Australian Democrats see the application of each and every one of these objectives as vital to a healthy broadcasting industry in this country. Unfortunately, however, the reality of Australian broadcasting has not always lived up to these objectives.

The current viability of Australia's television industry is looking very shaky indeed. We now have two television stations in receivership and the third recently being bought back by its previous owner for less than 50 per cent of the price he originally sold it for. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, acting in the public interest, needs to regulate the broadcasting industry in such a way that the industry as a whole remains profitable and that, in the public interest, those profits are returned to programming to increase diversity and Australian content amongst other things.

The concentration of media ownership in Australia, we believe, is at an alarmingly high level and this is a matter of great concern to the Australian Democrats. It is a worrying situation which has come about largely because of changes in media ownership laws since 1987 and it seems it is now impossible to go back and sort out this particular mess.

The diversity of Australian media is, to a large extent, determined by diversity in ownership and control. Overall, a lack of regulation and/or regulatory power on Australia's media has allowed this diversity to diminish significantly. Ownership of our print media, for example, is the most concentrated amongst developed nations and an American citizen now controls a large percentage of our print media- over 60 per cent. It was only through Australian Democrat action that ownership of radio stations was restricted to 16 stations Australia-wide. Perhaps of greatest concern, however, given its very influential power, is the fact that ownership of our television industry resides primarily with just three people, or their receivers.

For television broadcasting, we have audience reaches far in excess of those found in overseas countries. In the United States of America there is an audience reach limit of just 25 per cent and relationships between the major networks and their affiliates are very strictly controlled. By comparison, in Australia we now have a theoretical maximum audience reach of 60 per cent. Indeed, in the past the Opposition was supporting a 100 per cent audience reach limit.

The current 60 per cent limit means a single owner can hold commercial television licences in four of our five mainland metropolitan centres. Further, through networking agreements actual audience reach can be much greater. The Australian Democrats believe that the maximum audience reach limit should be set at 43 per cent. We believe this lower limit is essential for a number of reasons. Firstly, we believe it is necessary to restrict the social and political power that inevitably resides with licence owners. Secondly, a lower limit is vital in encouraging new entrants to the industry. Finally, it will serve to redress the power imbalance between the regional stations and the networks.

Looking at the foreign ownership of Australian media, we see that existing regulation is inconsistent and, since the infamous Murdoch amendments, we would say totally inadequate. We agree with the statement by the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley, in the other place that the situation whereby foreign owners, through elaborate corporate structures involving holding companies, are able to control up to 49 per cent of Australian television stations is totally unacceptable. The Australian Democrats look forward to legislation closing this loophole and, indeed, Senator Powell will be introducing a private member's Bill later in the year dealing precisely with this issue.

Given these difficulties in the current status of broadcasting in this country we believe it is clear that we do need a powerful and flexible regulatory body. This is especially true given that broadcasters are basically in the industry for the purpose of making money and not for the purpose of protecting the public good. Consequently, the Australian Democrats are working to ensure that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has sufficient resources and legislative support in order to perform its job of regulating this very strategic and influential industry and of attempting to implement the Saunderson Committee's objectives.

Over the past 14 years, the power of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has, I believe for purely short term political reasons, been weakened by successive governments, to the point where the previous chairperson of the Tribunal, Deidre O'Connor, made that now well-worn observation that the Tribunal is a `toothless tiger', an opinion recently endorsed by the acting chairperson of the Broadcasting Tribunal, Mr Peter Westerway.

The Australian Democrats have pledged, in our alternative budget, to increase funding to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal by $1m in the first year. Of this, $364,000 will be used to conduct an inquiry into the effects of aggregation and the remaining funds will go to establishing a networked computer system at the Tribunal. At the moment, the Tribunal has around 100 Pcs but these machines are unable to access each other. So masses of information is being collected which is becoming increasingly less accessible. As one of the major functions of the Tribunal is to act as an information collection and dissemination service, the maintenance of an efficient database service is essential.

The Bills we have before us this evening will give the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal additional options in the exercising of its powers and will decrease the number of transactions requiring Australian Broadcasting Tribunal approval. These Bills are a stopgap measure only and need to be seen as such, as they do not address the major problems in this industry. The Australian Democrats welcome some aspects of these Bills but have strong reservations about others.

The Minister has stated that a major reform package for the Broadcasting Act 1942 is expected later this year. We welcome that. However, the review of this legislation began three years ago and was meant to take just six months. What the industry, and indeed the viewing public, needs from the Government is a greater commitment to more rapid, yet comprehensive, reform of the broadcasting legislation.

With the many advances being made in information technology, our laws are becoming fast outdated and some services currently in operation in this country are broadcasting basically in an unregulated fashion. I speak, of course, of the so-called `narrowcast' services licensed under the Radiocommunications Act using video and audio entertainment and information services (VAEIS) provisions. Such services are currently in existence aiming at, for example, ethnic communities, doctors, tourists and hotel patrons-for example, the use of Sky Channel.

Our broadcasting legislation needs to be overhauled in such a way that it allows for the many technological developments that will undoubtedly occur in the industry but that does not encourage the type of legislative avoidance behaviour that has occurred in the past. The Democrats recognise that this is by no means a simple task but it is one that is essential and one that must be completed soon.

I turn now specifically to the Bills before us, looking firstly at the Broadcasting Amendment Bill 1990. This Bill inserts in the legislation certain suitability requirements for the holders of radio and television licences. Further, the Bill provides the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal with a number of options where it finds a television or radio licensee not to be a fit and proper person to hold a commercial licence or where it finds that person to be unable to provide an adequate and comprehensive service.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I will speak about the wonderful opportunity I was recently able to take up to visit the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) at the invitation of the Soviet Women's Committee with a group of women parliamentarians. Senator Crowley has already spoken about this. I will speak about slightly different aspects of our visit. No doubt, other people will talk about other aspects.

SPEECH.PARA: It was a fantastic opportunity. We are very grateful to the Soviet Women's Committee for making that opportunity available to us. There is so much to say about it. In general terms, the impression that we picked up from the people about the market economy which is being thrust on the Soviet people was that they are very worried indeed, especially women, who feel that they will suffer first because they know that unemployment will be involved in the restructuring of perestroika. They feel very concerned about that, particularly at the moment as there is not an abundance of food in the shops in the Soviet Union. There is no shortage of food generally, but getting it to the right places for people to buy easily is not common. In fact, there are queues all over the place for basic food items.

People are very worried. Even though they are very interested in the political process that is unfolding, over and over again we heard that they are less concerned about the particular kind of political process that will flow from Mr Gorbachev's perestroika, or whether it be another model; they are more concerned about having food on the table for their children. Of course, that is what it comes down to when the pressure is great.

One of the first things I noticed in my 12 days in the Soviet Union was an amazing resurgence of religious freedom and religious enthusiasm. In fact, the first night I was in Moscow I was wandering along getting a bit of fresh air and I came across an Orthodox church. It was very cold in the street, so I wandered into the church service. I was very interested to see that there were many younger people as well as older people very enthusiastically participating in this service.

We were taken to visit the Svyato-Danilov monastery-the home of the Russian Orthodox Church-by the Soviet Women's Committee. There is a huge restoration program going on here, as there is in many churches and cathedrals throughout the Soviet Union, which are decreasingly being seen as museums and increasingly being used as places of worship. That was one very pleasing first impression.

It was borne out by visits that we had to the wonderful cathedrals, some of which were in the Kremlin complex. I think that many people are unaware that there are cathedrals in the Kremlin. People think of the Kremlin as the seat of Soviet power. It is also full of Soviet history dating back to the twelfth century and it includes many wonderful cathedrals.

There is a lot of restoration work going on in Leningrad as well, again cathedrals taking pride of place. The Soviet Union could be a feast of cultural activities. I was very lucky to have an afternoon wandering around the Pushkin Gallery, which has a great collection. The whole delegation very much enjoyed a visit to the Hermitage Museum in Leningrad.
We were also treated to an evening at the ballet, where we saw the Kirov and Minsk ballets and also a company from Prague. Another evening we were delighted with a folk dancing concert.

We also went to the first annual conference of religious music to be held in the Soviet Union. Again, that indicated the great interest in all things religious. Interestingly, an orthodox priest who had taken the initiative to get under way this first annual conference of religious music had barbarously been murdered a couple of weeks before the concert took place. So the concert was preceded by a religious service. It was not until the concert was over and we had stood through this very moving spectacle that we understood what it was actually all about.

We had some very interesting visits to all kinds of groups organised for us by the Committee. Senator Jocelyn Newman and I asked for a briefing by the military. I was very pleased, in Senator Newman's company, to speak with Major-General Anatolie Bolyatko, who is a Deputy Chief of the Soviet forces. This was a very interesting couple of hours. We had a really interesting time with him. He told us a lot about the Soviet military doctrine and how the old order is being replaced by a new order in the military also.

He talked about the system of universal prevention of war, the preparation for military actions and war for defence. He said that this was in contrast to the recent past, in which the main aim was conducting and winning warfare. The emphasis is now very much on prevention, especially since 1985.

There are many practical steps to implement this new thinking in the military, such as the Soviet's very strong commitment never to start warfare and to fight only if attacked; never to use nuclear weapons first; not to engage in any territorial claims; and not to consider any country as an enemy.

The General was fascinating on many issues, particularly the changes that are taking place; the reduction in military expenditure; the reduction in military forces; and the decrease in military weapons production, particularly in nuclear weapons production. He gave us some figures for that. The production of nuclear weapons has been reduced by almost half in the last year from 2.3 billion roubles to 1.3 billion roubles, and it is still going down. This was all very encouraging. The 500,000 reduction in personnel has been under way since 1988. That will be completed by the end of next year.

This means that there are many problems for the resettlement of Soviet military. For example, there are 25,000 officers' families-not individual conscripts, but families-to resettle. They will be added to the 75,000 servicemen who are already lacking housing in the Soviet Union. There is the big group coming back from the Warsaw Pact countries for which housing has to be found.

There is a great deal of debate on the abolition of conscription in the Soviet Union at the moment. It was also interesting to note that there is now a committee on defence and State security, which until recently was hardly critical at all of defence forces in the Supreme Soviet or in the press. But now there is increasing criticism. The aim of the committee on defence and State security is to reduce the quantity of the Soviet armed forces but to improve the quality.

One thing the general did not tell us about is that there is a party in the Supreme Soviet of military democrats. That was a very interesting item of information that we picked up later. They are not strong in number but they are there in the Russian Federation and in the Supreme Soviet. They are seeking military reform. They are seeking to make the army professional, that is, to do away with conscription, to reduce the numbers, to separate the military from political policy, which of course would be a huge change for the military in the Soviet Union.

We talked to a number of people about the Gulf crisis. It was very interesting. We were quite thirsty for news about what was happening in the Gulf while we were in the Soviet Union. The General's view was that, although the United States of America is ready to go militarily, the fact that the Soviet Union had urged constraint on that and certainly was not ready to engage in military force usage may have helped push towards a diplomatic settlement.

There is a big body of public opinion-and the general was talking about this; the Soviet Union now has public opinion surveys, which is very encouraging-strongly in favour of the return of the military technicians, 150 of whom are still in Iraq and who I believe are coming back right now. A public opinion survey in Moscow News, one of the many newspapers now quite critical of the CPSU, discovered that 64 per cent of people surveyed, out of 1,330 respondents from 24 centres in 11 regions of the USSR, were opposed to the deployment of Soviet warships in the Persian Gulf to help carry out the naval blockade.

This kind of information is really very interesting and very different from the kind of talk that there was when I was in the Soviet Union in 1976. The time with the general was very interesting indeed.

We visited various enterprises, one being a shoe factory-a joint venture with West Germany. To engage in joint ventures is now a quite common practice in the Soviet Union. This was quite an up-market shoe factory intending to extend into a network of stores throughout the Soviet Union, but still there were queues.

People get invitations to go to a shoe shop on a certain day but, even with an invitation, they still have to queue up for some time outside. The workers in this joint enterprise were paid 400 roubles a month, which is quite a big incentive in itself to offer service to their customers. It is about twice the salary that teachers in the Soviet Union get-about five roubles to the dollar, which gives honourable senators an idea of the wages system.

Another enterprise that we visited was an oil cloth factory which had been going and nationalised since 1917; so it certainly was not one of the new ones. It was very interesting. I did not get the second name of the gentleman in charge, but his first name was Boris. He had a lot of very interesting things to say. One of his better quotes was that bitter truth is better than a sweet lie. We heard that repeated several times while we were in the Soviet Union. He also made a very interesting comment about life in the Soviet Union. He likened it to living in a glasshouse where the roof has been smashed in: previously the plants in the glasshouse lived in a protective environment, but suddenly the cold air is coming in and they are very worried about their survival.

At one stage when we asked how the market economy would affect his enterprise, he said: `Our system is very hard for foreigners to understand; in fact, we cannot grasp it ourselves', at which we all fell about laughing, including Boris.

The centralised market economy was on the agenda wherever we went and there were varying responses to it. This particular enterprise offers a great deal of social services to its workers. The people who work here are very lucky indeed because they have services provided at work, which means that they do not have to queue up, like most people do, for all goods that they want to buy. They have services such as dry cleaners, shoe repair, massage, opticians, household repairs, a shop where they can buy food, tickets to the theatre, travel service, tailor facilities, a day care centre provided and a gymnasium-all kinds of facilities were offered.

It was interesting, too, to learn from Boris that two of the workshops in this very large plastics factory mainly producing plastic tablecloths-that is what we saw anyway-had been closed on environmental grounds. That was a self-regulating process because there are environmental laws on the way but not in effect as yet. He knew that in a couple of years time the law would demand that these particular parts of his enterprise close down, so he did it ahead of time; and, of course, that was, to some degree, to protect the workers from very toxic chemicals. In fact, when we went into the factory itself where these tablecloths were being produced, we nearly got blown back outside by the fumes. It is very difficult for them to enforce worker health and safety even if safe work practices are available because there is not the attitude that people need to be careful, even with their own health. We heard this over and over again, particularly as far as women were concerned.

As I said, it is very interesting to see the surveys in newspapers and hear people like the General quoting public opinion. The social barometer is in the Moscow Times each week. I want to read one particular part of it which was about consumer shortages. It states:
Lately, consumer items have been disappearing from the shelves. WHAT WAS THE PRIMARY CAUSE OF THE SHORTAGE OF CIGARETTES, BREAD, ETC.?
the socialist plan economy-18
the so-called perestroika-12
sabotage by perestroika's opponents-33
the mafia in the trade sector-36
undecided-6

That was a very interesting list of options that people were given about why goods were not available in the shops. So there is quite a lot of opposition to the whole question of perestroika. In fact, Mr Gorbachev, who is so popular internationally, is not at all popular domestically. It is because people feel that the changes are being forced on them without them really understanding the full implications; and there are some people who obviously want perestroika to fail. It is interesting that the two highest percentages-36 and 33-were people considered to be committing sabotage; that is, the opponents of perestroika and the Mafia in the trade sector. I am afraid that it is very obvious that there is a lot of wheeling and dealing going on, but it is largely due to the general shortages of consumer products. I guess it is a bit of a chicken and egg situation.

Other interesting people who were lined up by the Soviet Women's Committee included Yuri Drosov from the Soviet Peace Committee. I asked him about the situation of the Government's line on Iraq and how the Soviet Peace Committee felt about that. He was quite happy that the Government was not prepared to engage, at that stage anyway, in the military boycott. Interestingly, the Soviet Peace Committee had been in touch with the Peace and Solidarity Council in Iraq. It had made very plain to this Iraqi committee that it took a strong line calling for the Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. It got a less than warm response from the Peace and Solidarity Council in Iraq.

The Soviet Peace Committee had also sent proposals for the resolution of the conflict to its own department of foreign affairs. We also talked about the Afghan veterans, many of whom are involved in the Soviet Peace Committee. It was Yuri Drosov's view that about 99 per cent of Soviet people believe that the whole Afghanistan exercise was a grave mistake.

Another very interesting person we met was Valery Borschov, who is a Moscow City councillor and a member of the Helsinki Group. He worked with Sakharov on the committee which defended the rights of believers. This is before the thaw in relationships with people who maintained their belief in some religious system. They have obviously reached a breakthrough in attitudes towards believers, but all is far from right as far as human rights issues are concerned.

He told us that in prison camp 35 there are many political prisoners still housed under article 64 of the criminal code relating to treachery; for example, illegal border crossings. The Helsinki Group has the names of all such prisoners. To the best of their knowledge, there are 120 people on that list. That is a very far cry from the thousands and thousands that there were until recently. So certainly the situation is improving.

The Helsinki Group also takes a position about conscientious objectors to conscription on religious grounds. The Moscow City Council, which is now dominated by democrats, has worked out a statement supporting alternative service for those who are opposed to conscription on religious grounds. There is still the death sentence on statute books in the Soviet Union, but it is seldom used. The Helsinki Group opposes this and is working to change it. Amnesty International also operates in the Soviet Union canvassing against the death penalty and is about to open an office for human rights organisations. So all of that was quite encouraging.

As far as psychiatric prisoners are concerned, there is still a problem. In the 1970s many believers found themselves in psychiatric hospitals, and when Valery Borschov cancelled his membership of the CPSU it was suggested that he go for psychiatric testing. He refused to do so. When we asked him how he got away with not showing up, he told us that it was because he was a well-known journalist and it probably would have been very publicly embarrassing for the authorities had he ended up in a psychiatric hospital. The Commission on Human Rights in the Moscow City Council is pressing for a check of all psychiatric institutions. It is not sure what it will find, but it is certainly trying to get to the bottom of that particular situation.

Valery told us that there is still some reluctance, despite the much greater openness that is evident in the Soviet Union now, to be critical of the leadership. But at public rallies, where there is safety in numbers-and there have been numerous public rallies now-people have spoken out quite boldly. He also told us that racial and religious tolerance was generally fairly good in Moscow, but not so good in the provinces. The recent Moscow City Council election was very successful for the democratic bloc: 300 of the 476 deputies are from the democratic movement and only 70 to 80 deputies are from the CPSU.

He told us that it is very hard for them to learn democracy, and we heard this over and over again. They are not used to pluralism, and they are not used to many different groups having to make compromises and listen to each other. In fact, there are three kinds of democrats in the Moscow City Council-liberal democrats, social democrats and Christian democrats. So I think they are in for some fun.

We also met three deputies from the Supreme Soviet in the Kremlin, including two women who were on the Commission for Women's Issues. There are 26 major commissions in the Supreme Soviet and one of them is on women's issues. As with many other groups, we raised with them the issue of birth control because there is an appalling level of abortions-about eight to 12 abortions on average for Soviet women. It is the most commonly used form of birth control, which we found quite horrendous. There is little access to birth control. To the horror of Kim Yen Um, the male deputy who was present at this meeting, and to the surprise of the two women deputies, we asked about vasectomies. `Nyet' was the sharp response to that. We felt it was important to point out that men should take some responsibility for birth control but, obviously, it will be a long time before the attitudes change.

We also met members of the political club of the Soviet Women's Committee. That was a very interesting session during which we exchanged information. The six Australian MPs spoke about our political involvement, how we got involved and how it all operates in Australia, as a way of encouraging Soviet women to get involved in electoral politics. Until recently there has been a quota system so that women have had very big representation at all three levels of government in the Soviet Union, but recently, with the increased democratisation, the quota system has been dispensed with and women's representation has gone right down to about 6 to 8 per cent. We saw that in the Leningrad and Moscow city councils and in the Supreme Soviet as well. We were asking why that is so and encouraging women to take up the challenge to get involved in electoral politics and earn their places, because the places will not just be given to them.

Another very interesting person we met was Zoya Krylova, the editor of Rabotnitsa; she is also a deputy in the Supreme Soviet. She is the editor of this 86-year-old monthly magazine-so it pre-dates the revolution-with a circulation of 24 million and a much greater readership. It gets 150,000 letters a year, about a third of them from men. Although it is meant to be a women's magazine, it is very widely read by men as well. It has 17 people employed answering all the letters, so it has a very good gauge on public opinion.

One of the most interesting things that Zoya Krylova told us was that that magazine was the first to write about abortions in the general media. It published a letter from a Leningrad woman about the evils of abortion-just one letter in this magazine-and got 2,000 letters back. She invited gynaecologists to read these women's stories. They gave the letters to Raisa and Mikhail Gorbachev and then to the Minister for Health. Every letter was verified. All republic health Ministers met and discussed this issue and 40 million roubles were given to the Health Department to deal with this question three years ago. That started the process of change.

We heard very disturbing things about birth defects increasing, due, I think, to poor working conditions. According to Zoya Krylova, 30 million jobs have very bad working conditions below acceptable levels, and there are 700,000 jobs where people work with faulty equipment. According to her estimation-and this came from the Ecological Social Association-100 cities in the Soviet Union are called zones of ecological disaster, and Zoya thinks that there might be more than that. The magazine has a phone hot line for readers to phone in their environmental stories. These are obviously very important issues for people in the Soviet Union. That was a very fascinating visit indeed.

Another very important person we met was Alexander Gelman, who is a writer who resigned recently from the CPSU after he had been asked to be a member of the inner presidium by Mikhail Gorbachev. He is a personal friend of Gorbachev but, for various reasons, he was fed up with the Party and resigned. He is in there at the moment representing writers. He was very interesting, particularly when talking about the democrats. He is not actually aligned with any group. There are a lot of people floating independently in the Supreme Soviet not quite sure which way to go and, of course, this is all part of the unfolding democracy which they are finding so challenging. He says that the new democrats are making many mistakes, and the differences between them can be exploited by the old guard. Many of the people who are speaking out know what they are up against, but they are often unclear about a positive program. This is very understandable, I think, given the fact that they have had a very strong bureaucratic influence for 70 years and, in fact, the military and the bureaucracy are going to be the most disaffected by the rapid changes. It is those two groups plus, perhaps, the fascists who are also emerging, or the republicans in the various areas of the Soviet Union, who could create a huge upset.

We also met with Anaida Bestavashriti, who is a refugee worker. She made an appeal through us to the Australian Government for people who are victims of the Armenian earthquake to be resettled in Australia. That was a very moving plea and I am not quite sure how it will be received. We also met with Titania Kaletskaya, who is head of the initiative group association Mutual Trust, who wants to set up an international institute in the Soviet Union which would deal with disasters on a global scale-not just after the event, but in anticipation of disasters which may occur. That was a very interesting idea.

We shall be able to send a lot of information to people that we met in the Soviet Union about some of the models that are already going in Australia-for example, the Commission for the Future material and information about some of our aid agencies which already do a lot of the things that people in the Soviet Union are looking for. That was very interesting too.

I would like to pay tribute to the Soviet Women's Committee for its excellent organisation and, particularly, to Galina Negrustuyeva and Vera Soboleva, from the Soviet Women's Committee, who organised our program, and to Ellen Mitriaeva and Tania Anisimova, who were our interpreters and who did a great job for us. Also, the Australian Embassy helped us out on a couple of occasions and gave us a briefing-James Wise, Kyle Wilson, and Victoria, who also did some interpreting for us. We were very well cared for.

I certainly had very positive impressions overall, but I feel great concern about what the future holds for the Soviet Union, because its people are being thrust headlong into a system for which they are not really psychologically prepared. It will be a very challenging time indeed. Anything that the Australian Government can do to help will be welcomed, including a very sensible offer which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made a couple of years ago-which has not been taken up yet-which was for young Soviets to come to Australia for three or six months for training programs in marketing, management and democratic processes. This is the very sensible kind of practical help which the Australian Government could give the Soviet Union. It is in our interests, of course-it is in the interests of the global community-to ensure that this transition that Mr Gorbachev has set under way occurs as calmly as possible without a massive revolution taking place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier tonight the Senate conducted a very important debate on the rural crisis. Such was the interest in the debate that many of us on this side who wished to make a contribution-particularly Senator Panizza, Senator Crane and myself-were unable to get the call in the time allowed. There were a number of matters that I wished to mention in that debate, but there will no doubt be opportunities later on for those matters. There was one matter, however, that I particularly wanted to mention and I will take only a few minutes of the Senate's time. It relates to an answer that Senator Cook gave yesterday in the Senate regarding ethanol. I want to briefly mention that as soon as possible in the hope that it may assist Senator Cook in his knowledge of just how important ethanol could be to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know who is advising Senator Cook as to his knowledge on ethanol, but it seems to me that the advice is sadly lacking. There are, in fact, contrary to what Senator Cook mentioned in his answer-and it seemed to be a prepared answer that ethanol was environmentally bad-certain environmental benefits in the use of ethanol, which reduces carbon dioxide emissions by 10 per cent if a 10 per cent ethanol-90 per cent petrol blend is used.

Senator Cook also made yesterday what I consider to be a quite ridiculous comment about the waste from ethanol production turning rivers black. I think this shows a complete misunderstanding of the by-products of ethanol and how they are dealt with. Any by-products from ethanol and from the crushing of sugar are used and re-used, and they are a very much sought after soil additive and a fertiliser substitute.

There is an ethyl alcohol plant at Sarina in the Mackay area. The residue from the cane and molasses after the ethanol is taken from them is sought after in that area as a soil additive and is carted around the Mackay district. It does not pollute the rivers and streams in that area as Senator Cook seemed to suggest.

In a time when I thought the Government might be trying its very hardest to support the rural industries, Senator Cook seemed in a prepared answer to do nothing but denigrate one of the facets of primary industry that could assist the country and assist primary producers. The sugar industry is not in as bad a state as some other rural industries at present. Sugar prices have been reasonably good in the past year, but a decline is forecast for this year and the future is always very uncertain. But if ethanol were able to be produced cane production could be increased markedly, and this would allow a much better use of the enormous infrastructure and machinery costs that farmers and millers have to go to to crush cane at the present time.

Senator Cook seemed to think that there was some problem in having a 10 per cent blend. He said that that would double the land used for cane farming in Australia to produce an efficient product and would increase pressure on marginal lands and on the environment. The Fraser Government a decade or so ago implemented the construction of the Burdekin Dam. A lot of Commonwealth money and Queensland Government money went into that project. With any investment made in that way, one must get a return on the money invested. Just now, so many years after the Fraser Government first implemented the initial stages to construct the Burdekin Dam, the Queensland Government is selling land that is benefited by the dam.

A number of types of primary production is being planned for that land, including the production of rice and other grain crops, but one of the things to which that land is very well suited is the production of sugar cane. The Queensland Labor Government has acknowledged this in giving away 80 hectare assignments on land which it recently sold in the Burdekin delta, which has been opened up as a result of the Burdekin Dam.

The doubling of cane farming land in Australia for the production of more cane for ethanol would mean a great boost for the Burdekin and Ingham areas, where spare land is available. As I mentioned, it would lead to a far more efficient use of the enormous capital costs that farmers and millers have to go to to produce the cane they now produce. The extra income they could get from ethanol would support employment in the farming areas surrounding those rural towns and in the milling areas. I would have thought that increasing employment opportunities, particularly in rural towns, was something that the Government would dearly want to encourage rather than denigrate as Senator Cook seemed to do yesterday.

At a price in the mid-70 cents per litre, ethanol production from sugar cane becomes an economic proposition. The Queensland canegrowers organisation has been conducting trials with a 10 per cent ethanol and 90 per cent petrol blend. The Federal Minister for Resources, Mr Griffiths, has agreed that the Iraq-Kuwait situation highlights the need for Australia to give higher priority to finding other sources of fuel. It seems to me again that the Government should be encouraging rather than laughing at or denigrating proposals to use ethanol as a fuel substitute or as an additive to make fuels go further. The technology for the 10 per cent ethanol and 90 per cent petrol mix is tried and proven and it can be used without any modification of motor vehicle engines.

Senator Cook mentioned that the experiment had not worked in Brazil. I do not think that information is correct either. The Brazil experiment used a complete ethanol component as a fuel rather than as the additive which we are looking at in Australia. But even in Brazil, where Senator Cook suggested the experiment had failed, I understand that the Brazilian President recently announced that he was going to buy an ethanol car because he thought that was the best way to go in view of the Middle East crisis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly considering that he does not have to pay for the fuel that goes into it.

—That may be right. Senator Cook may not think it is not a good idea, but his colleagues in the Queensland Labor Government support it. I think this is good. It is one of the few decisions that that Government has yet made. Most of the things that Government was put into power to do it referred to committees, pushing everything aside so that it did not have to make the hard decisions. But at least in this instance it agreed. The Townsville Bulletin this morning reported that the Government is pledging support for an ethanol plant to be built in north Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply say that, in these times of real crises in rural industry and real crises in employment in the rural areas of Australia, it behoves the Government to encourage anything that may assist rural industries, assist employment in rural areas and assist in giving us an alternative supply or source of fuel. The Government should be supporting very seriously proposals for investigations or further research into ethanol production, rather than denigrating them as Senator Cook appeared to do yesterday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Macdonald has already indicated, a motion concerning the rural crisis was debated earlier this evening. The format for discussion was altered somewhat and, while we were privileged to hear an economic expose from the Government's resident mastermind on monetary matters, Senator Burns, it disrupted the agreed schedule of speakers. While I am very pleased to have heard Senator Macdonald espousing the advantages of ethanol-I honestly am pleased to have heard that and I endorse his comments-I am only saddened that they could not have been made as part of that debate, because that is where they rightly belonged.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Burns in his contribution mentioned something about deregulation of the banks being a wonderful achievement in bringing banks into this country and making money available for investment. All we have seen as a result of that has been an escalation of interest rates, speculator investments, takeovers, share market manipulations and eventually bankruptcies and ballooning overseas debt. I did not hear in his contribution any justification of those events.

I want to speak very briefly about something I was unable to raise in the course of my contribution to the debate. This afternoon, not unusually but by a coincidence, I received one of the many contributions I have been receiving from people in Australia's country areas. The one I received this afternoon was a facsimile transmission from South Australia. It dealt with six case studies which would bring tears to the eyes of anybody who understands the country.

These case studies illustrate a variety of traditional, well-managed farms in reliable geographical locations. The farms have been well established and have well-established records of profitability. But all the case studies I received this afternoon revealed a sudden increase in liabilities and a sudden decrease in cash flow, which in many ways is the straw that has broken the camel's back. The sender of the fax to me asked in his covering note the following:
Sir, you can now take this factual information back to Canberra. The people here will ask,`What will you do with it? What will the Government do with it? Can we expect a reply?'

The feelings of hopelessness and failure accompany overwhelming stress of emotional and financial pressure, and are causing wives and families to leave husband and farm. Thus, the farmer is left to face the stress of desertion and depression all alone.
Later in the covering letter, the sender says:

My plea to you, Sir, is that you will express to your Government the urgency of these matters. Country people and the community at large are running out of time. They wouldn't hesitate to say that your Government is also running out of time.

It saddens me that I have to bring this facsimile to this chamber. I cannot answer any of the concerns that have been expressed in it, because they are overwhelming in the magnitude of economic malaise. They are beyond answering from a person in my position. I was disappointed that I could not incorporate the facsimile in the debate which was originated by the Opposition. Like Senator Macdonald, I think that is where it rightly belongs. I wanted to take time to read into Hansard this plea from people in the country and to say, in honest sadness, that I am very sorry to have received this information and to have to put such a contribution into the record of this place.

I also advise honourable senators that two Estimates Committees will be meeting tomorrow. Estimates Committee A will meet in Committee Room No. 14 at 9.30 a.m., and Estimates Committee C will meet in Committee Room No. 16 at 9 a.m.
